## sacrifice paddock
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  The farming technique known as the `sacrifice' paddock, in which one paddock on a farm is heavily stocked during the winter to save pastures elsewhere on the farm for use by cattle after calving was criticised by the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals in the Palmerston North Magistrates' Court today. ... in Dalefield's case it had been the stock rather than the paddock which had been `sacrificed' <i>(Aug 14, 1958,Christchurch Star-Sun,13</i>)

>  <i>sacrifice paddock n. N.Z.</i> a grassed field which is allowed to be grazed completely, so that it can be cultivated and resown later. <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1015</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 428]]

>  His practice of putting his herd in a "sacrifice" paddock is common among dairy farmers. Rather than damage all his farm moving his herd around in the mud, he opts to sacrifice poorly performing paddocks and later cultivate and resow them with a crop followed by new grass when the weather improves. <i>(Sep 9, 2004,Dominion Post,C7</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a fenced area on which a farmer will bring in silage, hay or other feed to stock in very wet weather , causing the sward to be pugged and trampled.

>  We fed 118 cows for a full month on this crop, supplemented by a 'sacrifice' paddock adjoining.. In wet weather we left the cows in the sacrifice paddock and fed hay out to them. <i>(Jun 10, 1958,NZ Dairy Exporter,29</i>)

>  <b>MCMEEKAN</b> The 'sacrifice paddock' system of wintering would be employed for the feeding-out of hay and silage during winter. <i>(1960,Grass to Milk,187</i>)

>  I used to think sacrifice paddocks were bound to be very fertile the next year and the heavier the stocking, the richer they'd be. <i>(Sep 10, 1970,NZ Farmer,61</i>)

>  Fortunately, the herd had to walk some distance from a 'sacrifice' paddock to the barn through a shingle bottomed stream, which is a first-class indicator of founder, or overheating of the feet. <i>(Sep 1973,NZ Journal of Agriculture,61</i>)

>  Sacrifice paddocks with feeding racks on platforms on the race-side border may be worth considering. <i>(Sep 27, 1973,NZ Farmer,7</i>)

>  I intend to throw away the backing wire, revert to the old 1950s practice of a 'sacrifice paddock' on the bad grub areas and really trample hell out of them. <i>(Jul 1983,NZ Journal of Agriculture,69</i>)

>  MAF is encouraging farmers to watch their image after complaints from townies and tourists over cattle being held in muddy sacrifice paddocks. <i>(Aug 1, 1996,NZ Farmer,4</i>)

## safen
 
 <i>v.</i> to make safe

>  David Gregorie of Waikanae quotes a letter in his local paper from Niki Trotter, of Raumati Beach: "I find it hard to see why anyone would be against safening a very dangerous piece of road with an extremely bad accident history." Now that's a truly marvellous word. "Safen". to "make safe", follows all the best precedents, using that Germanic -en ending to make a verb out of an adjective. It mimics fasten, worsen, harden, sweeten, sharpen, shorten, stiffen etc. <i>(Apr 28, 2004,Dominion Post,B5</i>)

>  The job may be small, such as ring crutching, but those heavy sheep have to be handled. Ideal for full crutch, ringing and wigging, dagging or sale crutch of prime lambs. <i>(Jun 1982,NZ Journal of Agriculture,49</i>)



## sale day
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a regular day of the week on which a stock sale is held at a particular venue. [also saleday]

>  <b>Batistich</b> The casuals came and went as usual, the Sale Day visitants flooded us briefly. <i>(1987,Sing Vila in the Mountain,156</i>)

>  <b>SILK</b> For the last few years, the farmers in general found that sale-days were by no means 'Red Letter Days', but days of gloom and disappointment. <i>(1923,History of Puhoi,85</i>)

>  <b>MCNAUGHTON</b> Next morning was sale day, and Stewart went to the saleyards with his hack and his dogs. <i>(1970,Tat,104</i>)

>  <b>MACINTOSH</b> The busiest day was on 'saleday' when farmers and agents gathered for the fortnightly stock sale. <i>(1974,Never a Dull Moment,18</i>)

>  <b>MACINTOSH</b> Saledays often brought added diversions ... <i>(1974,Never a Dull Moment,35</i>)

>  <b>WATERS</b> Stock sale days from the mid-1920s were quite a cockies' gathering. <i>(1976,Mostly a Farmer,105</i>)

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> If the weather was suitable, sale days turned into a 'picnic day' or a get-together for all the families. [saleday] <i>(1991,Off the Sheep's Back,54</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> in country towns, the day on which a farm livestock sale is held [also saleday]

>  ROBT. SCOTT, DENTIST, TAY STREET, INVERCARGILL. VISITS Otautau every fortnight, and may be consulted at Mrs Jaquiery's Buildings on Sale Day and second and fourth Fridays. <i>(Dec 10, 1929,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,4</i>)

>  Why, Sale day was Otautau's Gala day! <i>(Mar 29, 1932,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,4</i>)

>  Stratfordites are beginning to recognise the necessity of having a more substantial bridge over the Patea river, and teamsters are a bit frightened about crossing over with a load of medium weight. And no wonder. It is surprising to many it has not collapsed before this. At all events to a town like Stratford it is an unsightly structure, whether fit to carry the traffic or not, and it is a menace to pedestrians when there is much traffic in the streets, especially on sale days, when cattle are being driven across. <i>(Apr 4, 1896,Hawera & Normanby Star,2</i>)

>  The supply of medium horses has been good, but vendors looked for an advance; whereas prices ruled, upon the whole, lower. Consequently, a smaller number than is usual on a regular sale-day, was disposed of. <i>(Jan 13, 1875,Taranaki Herald,2</i>)

>  The required quorum of 10 ratepayers not being present at the annual meeting called for Tuesday, the chairman (Mr. E. Constable) adjourned the meeting to Wednesday, the 14th instant, the cattle sale day. <i>(Oct 9, 1868,Daily Southern Cross,3</i>)

>  <b>TURNER</b> <i>(1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,150</i>)

>  An owner is wanted for a Hereford calf, left in the yards last sale day. <i>(Mar 12, 1918,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,3</i>)

>  September 2: first cattle sale day. <i>(1988,From Bush-Burn to Butter,52</i>) [NOTES: 1881 John Hurndall's Diary in 1988 Warr From Bush-burn to Butter 52]

>  Sale day, Christmas week, and not a beast to be got for love or money. <i>(Dec 1904,NZ Illustrated Magazine,251</i>)

>  <b>SCANLAN</b> The little market town, with its handful of shops, its public house, its saleyards, was only two miles away. Thursday was Sale Day, when the farmers came in to buy and sell sheep or calves, heifers and pigs, and the farmer's wife to trade her butter and eggs at the grocer's for stores, and to buy towels and sheets and shoes. Market day, they would call it in England, but there was no market in these small New Zealand towns. There were no stalls in the street or square, where the farmer and his wife sold poultry and apples, eggs and butter, fruit and cream. The cows and sheep and horses and other farm stock were gathered into pens at the saleyard, and sold by auction. <i>(1949,Rusty Road,10</i>)

>  Tell him I'll be wanting another pup and I'll look him up next saleday. <i>(1978,Listener Short Stories,2/40</i>) [NOTES: 1956 Middleton in 1978 Listener Short Stories Vol 2 40]

>  <b>TURNER</b> [In winter] a farmer does not have to be mindful of <i>cow-time</i> or milking time on <i>town day</i>(or <i>sale day</i>, equivalent to English `market day'). <i>(1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,161</i>)

>  <b>McNAUGHTON</b> Next morning was sale day, and Stewart went to the saleyards with his hack and his dogs. <i>(1970,Tat,104</i>)

>  <b>KEENE</b> Sale Day was always exciting in Kaitaia - especially in those early times when wild frightened cattle from the most northerly stations - cattle that had seen few human beings - were driven down the main road to the saleyards, then into the A. & P. grounds. <i>(1982,Myrtle and Sophia,45</i>)

>  Sale Day causes a hive of activity in our village. <i>(Dec 1, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,63</i>)

## sale draft
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a group of livestock for sale that are separated from a larger group.

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Unless they are aged sheep they aren't likely to be in his sale draft ... <i>(1972,Sheep Thief,127</i>)



## sale muster
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) the gathering of stock in preparation for drafting or a clearing sale.

>  <b>SHARPE</b> One the rare occasions on which a back-country property changes hands the sale muster, in which the sheep are brought in for counting, leads itself to all sorts of devilment. <i>(1962,Country Occasions,129</i>)



## sale night
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) an evening following a stock sale day [usually a social occasion in a rural area.]

## sale stock
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) farm livestock to be sold on the hoof.

## salmon
 
 <i>n.</i> New Zealand salmon, see KAHAWAI. (obsolesc) usu. with descriptive epithet MAORI, NATIVE, NEW ZEALAND salar, =KAHAWAI [cf AND <i>Arripis trutta </i> 1790 Collins (1798); salmon trout young of A <i> trutta or <i> A esper 1848 Tasmania]

>  <b>BIDWILL</b> Other shell-fish are also abundant, particularly Cockles - of these I have seen more than a man could carry collected by one woman during the space of a tide; Scallops are also tolerably abundant, and are most delicious eating. There are no Lobsters nor Crabs, but a great abundance of fish of all kinds; one, the Salmon of the English, or Carwai (Carwhy), is a most excellent fish, the best I have tasted in the Southern Hemisphere; ... <i>(1841,Rambles in NZ,115,1952 ed.</i>)

>  <b>POLACK</b> Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called <i>para[as-acute]<i> paraua</i> [a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale, <i> mungu nui</i> (black physeter); right whale, <i>tohora</i> (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark, <i> mango</i> (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes. <i>(1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/202 fn</i>)

>  <b>MORRIS</b> <i> Salmon, n</i> . The English Salmon is being acclimatised with difficulty in Tasmania and New Zealand; the <i>Trout</i> more successfully. But in all Australian, New Zealand, and Tasmanian waters there is a marine fish which is called Salmon; it is not the true Salmon of the Old World, but <i>Arripis salar</i> , Gunth., and called in New Zealand by the Maori name <i>Kahawai</i> . The fish is often called also <i> Salmon-Trout.</i> The young is called <i> Samson-fish</i> (q.v.). <i>(1898,Austral English,400</i>)

## salube
 
 <i>adj.</i>

>  To offset these rather gloomy expressions there are those that derive from <i> salubrious.</i> They are J.D. Pascoe terms and were brought by him from Canterbury to Wellington. They obviously arose from the habit of describing sunny, pleasant weather or places as `salubrious'. First is the <i> salubrium</i> , a rest or sunbake in salubrious conditions. This first appeared in <i> The Tramper</i> in 1937. About 1939 people were <i> salubriating</i> , or taking a <i> salube</i> in the sun. The previous year Te Matawai was described as a `salube hut'. By 1943 trampers were sunbathing and <i> salubing</i> . So far as Tararuas are concerned,<i> salube</i> as a noun and a verb is the word that has survived. <i>(Sep 1958,Tararua,28</i>) [NOTES: 1958 Sep Ruth Mason `Track and Trail' in Tararua 28]



 
 <i>n.</i> a period of relaxation (in the sun) [(Ruth Mason: from <i> salubrious</i>)]

## Samoan cricket
 
 <i>n.</i> [see also Pacific cricket] (See [kilikiti](../K#kilikiti))

>  I presume you do not know that in a Samoan cricket match there will be fifty or sixty players aside [sic], and one match will probably last several days. <i>(Mar 31, 1888,Te Aroha News,4</i>)

>  When it is added that the bowling is fast and throwing, at which Samoens [sic] are most expert, is allowed, that the bat is shaped like a long and heavy broomstick, tapering from four inches to two, and the ball is made of hard and heavy wood bound with cocoanut fibre, it will be seen that Samoan cricket presents many novel features. <i>(Dec 27, 1901,Poverty Bay Herald,1</i>)

>  [Arthur Tyndall] was impressed by the luxuriant plant growth in Samoa and by the great abundance of of amusements, Samoan cricket, singing, dancing and the King's Birthday sports at Apia. <i>(Apr 1987,NZ Journal of History,148</i>) [NOTES: (Boyd)]

>  KILIKITI: Samoan cricket bears about as much resemblance to the ... territory of Lords as the sound of the word does to English. ... For one thing the bat - fashioned in triangular shape from the springy fau tree, decorated in gaudy splashes of colour and bound with coconut fibre - has nothing to do with the sissy wider blade of the willow. It's an out-and-out war club of such bold length ... The ball, spun by hand from liquid rubber tapped from a living tree and compressed to rock-hard consistency, bounds down the pitch with a dangerously unpredictable velocity. ... [T]eams are of indefinite size - 15 a side is considered a minimum for serious competitions... When the batting team reaches 35 runs, to keep the action alive, the teams swop over. <i>(May 1987,Metro,110</i>)

## Save Manapouri
 
 <i>n.</i> (Environment) a term used from 1959 for a nationwide protest against the raising of Lake Manapouri to high levels for hydroelectricity generation. [also Save Manapouri campaign]

>  MANAPOURI stickers seem to come in a number of different forms. There is the common "Save Manapouri," a simple plea from the heart. "Help Save Manapouri," a call not to be just sympathetic but do something about it. Then there is "I Want to Save Manapouri," a pitiful cry by someone who feels impotent to do anything. But my favourite is the cynic's sticker indicating that he is tired of the whole business: "Drain Manapouri." <i>(Mar 2, 1970,Evening Post,32</i>)

>  The 1970 Save Manapouri petition was the third to be drawn up with the object of preserving the lake and was the largest petititon ever to be presented to Parliament. <i>(Aug 1970,Forest & Bird,8</i>)

>  Within the past 12 months we have received powerful support from "Save Manapouri" committees, which have been organised throughout the country. <i>(May 1970,Forest & Bird,10</i>)

>  <b>Neville PEAT</b> Save Manapouri is a cry deeply embedded in the collective consciousness of New Zealanders and is still capable of being dusted off. <i>(1994,Manapouri Saved,10</i>)

>  PLEA MADE FOR PRESERVATION. 'Swift Action Needed to Save Manapouri' [hdg]. <i>(Oct 21, 1959,Evening Post,22</i>)

>  Exploratory Talks Here on How to Save Manapouri [hdg] Substantial interest had been shown in the activities of the Save Manapouri Committee ... <i>(Jan 20, 1970,Evening Post,15</i>)

>  <b>Roger WILSON</b> The turning point of the opposition to the raising of the lake came when a crowded and lively public meeting was held in Invercargill on 30 October [1969]. As a result of that meeting, the first "Save Manapouri" committee was set up. Similar groups were quickly established in other centres around the country. <i>(1982,From Manapouri to Aramoana,15</i>)

>  The movement to "Save Manapouri" is a case book example of how trends are adopted in a democratic society. <i>(Apr 1970,Comment,4</i>)



## Save Manapouri campaign
 
 <i>n.</i> (Environment) an extensive nationwide campaign to prevent high level raising of Lake Manapouri for hydroelectricity generation.

>  The Save Manapouri campaign has been lauded as "the birth of the modern conservation movement" in New Zealand. The Save Manapouri campaign began in the late 1950s with the proposal to build a power station to supply power to an aluminium smelter in the far south of New Zealand and gained momentum in the 1960s when it was proposed that the level of Lake Manapouri would be raised 8.2 metres to harness its hydro-electric potential for the project. <i>(May 7, 2008,Internet - see Notes,1</i>) [NOTES: www.forestandbird.org.nz/what-we-do/publications/forest-bird-magazine/article]

>  Among other things he was - with his wife - a driver of the Save Manapouri campaign, which succeeded in preventing the Crown from raising the level of the lake by some eight metres to generate electricity for the Bluff smelter. <i>(Feb 26, 2009,Dominion Post,B3</i>) [NOTES: from obituary of Dr Ian Prior - refer dawn raid and overstayer]

>  <b>Neville PEAT</b> The Save Manapouri Campaign lifted the lid. New Zealand had seen nothing of its kind before. It was a phenomenon in public awareness, concern and agitation. <i>(1994,Manapouri Saved,3</i>)

>  In an effort to discern basic attitudes to the issue of the southern lakes' exploitation for power, members of Parliament are to be sent questionnaires by the Save Manapouri Campaign. <i>(Aug 21, 1972,Evening Post,3</i>)

>  And he [Mr R J McLean] said he thought that out of the Save Manapouri Campaign would evolve a permanent organisation to fight for the people of New Zealand when their natural environment was threatened by foreign or local industrialists, local bodies, or by their own Government. <i>(Feb 21, 1970,Evening Post,7</i>)

>  <b>Roger WILSON</b> The Save Manapouri Campaign was well funded and had a professional approach to publicity. <i>(1982,From Manapouri to Aramoana,11</i>)

 <i>n.</i> a marble game

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> It is important to distinguish these `Action-Terms' of marbles from the innumerable merely descriptive marble terms which have no effect on the course of the action - terms such as Ringer, In, Smug, Dead Stick, Skun, Skinned, Sported off, Scat, Cannons, Dubs, Kills, Funs, Keeps, Pink. <i>(1953,Unorganized Games,2/770</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs. (marbles) <i>Ibid.</i> 176 [Waitara, Taranaki, 1899: reference, game of Little Ring] Many heated arguments arose as to who said `everythings' or `nothings' first. If a player's `taw' touched a marble and lay alongside it, the others would shout `knuckle down' just before his turn. ... `Knuckle down' meant that the player had to hold his taw close to the marble attacked and fire it in that very inconvenient position. ... When a boy lost all his marbles at play he was `scat' [?related to skint ?HWO] . ... A `ringer' was a taw which, when fired at the commencement of the game, lodged in the track of the ring itself; that, and knocking a marble out when he `fired' were the perfect shots. ... To fire a shot while holding the hand nearer to the ring than where the taw had lain, was to `funk', an unforgiveable crime. <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,175</i>)

## schnapper
 
 <i>n.</i> variant of snapper q.v.

>  <b>WILSON</b> SNAPPER ... The common name `snapper' was given to the fish by Captain Cook in 1770. He mistook it for a member of the true snapper family <i>Lutjanidae </i>, a group of fish with which he had become familar in American waters. Although he did mistake the fish Captain Cook spelt the name correctly, whereas many subsequent writers have used `schnapper' - an erroneous spelling of unknown origin. Perhaps some of the early snapper fishermen took bottles of schnapps along on their outings, hence going `schnapping'! <i>(1981,Fisherman's Bible,226</i>)

>  <b>PARROTT</b> The name `Snapper' is frequently spelled `Schnapper', but there appears no sound reason for this spelling; older authors especially, have used the spelling, but it is seldom seen in modern works on fishes. <i>Ibid.</i> 170 Snapper Chrysophrys auratus Schnapper <i>(1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,99</i>)

>  schnapper A large common edible sea fish of Australia and New Zealand. <i>(1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),355</i>)

>  Wilkins went down town to.. beg the necessary meat for bait with which we were to catch the unsuspecting schnapper. <i>(Apr 26, 1890,NZ Observer,12</i>)

>  ...I thought I should economise and not buy schnapper, which is ridiculously expensive and which I still can't spell. <i>(Jun 29, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17</i>)

>  <b>DEVANNY</b> Sometimes as many as twenty schnapper would be caught. <i>(1928,Dawn Beloved,102</i>)

>  His sorrow at the struggles of the dying schnapper was pitiful to behold. <i>(Mar 5, 1904,NZ Observer,7</i>)

>  The barns were stored with glorious schnapper. <i>(Jun 28, 1913,NZ Observer,17</i>)

>  Poor Hansard, known as the "Dying Schnapper", was there. <i>(Oct 1, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,7</i>)

>  Instead, I got some freshly cooked pipi and raw schnapper. <i>(Oct 6, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),93</i>)

>  Bellamy's menu has qualified as the most snobbish of all State papers. Whenever the well-known New Zealand fish called snapper is an item of Parliamentary diet it is invariable [sic] spelled `schnapper.' The gourmets of the Food and Wine Society could be forgiven for such literary heresy, but the old prosaic spelling should be good enough for the dining-room in Parliament House. Incidentally, the legend is that the fish was given the name `snapper' by Captain Cook when he was here on his voyage of exploration in 1770. As he and the members of his crew leaned over the side of their galleon two centuries ago and threw their fishing lines into the waters off the New Zealand coast the fish used to snap at the bait. Hence the name snapper. <i>(Mar 5, 1956,Dominion,8</i>)

>  My reference in last week's column to the snobbishness of Bellamy's in using the spelling `schnapper' when that fish was on its menu has brought `bites' galore - from fish merchants to schoolmasters. Most of them, it is fair to say, have taken up the cudgels on behalf of Bellamy's, but none of them has disproved my argument that the correct spelling is `snapper.' ... Some historians support my Captain Cook theory, though there are others who place the first use of the name `snapper' at a later date, certainly not earlier. They think the name may have been given the fish by Captain W. L. Edwardson, the commander of a New South Wales Government cutter called the Snapper which was in New Zealand waters in 1822 and 1823 investigating sealing prospects. He gave the name Port Snapper to an inlet on Ruapuke Island in Foveaux Strait. Whatever the origin of the word, the fish served at Bellamy's is indigenous to New Zealand and is spelt `snapper.' <i>(Mar 12, 1956,Dominion,8</i>)

>  The fishing off the island is very good, there being abundance of hapuku, kohikohi, maumau, schnapper, kahawai, tarakihi, in addition to plenty of shell-fish such as koura or cray-fish, crabs, paua,etc. <i>(1885,TrNZI,17/419</i>) [NOTES: (Goldsmith)]

>  <b>SHERRIN</b> SCHNAPPER (<i>Pagrus unicolor </i>). ... Dr. Hector says: `There are few fishes better known in the northern parts of the Colony than the schnapper. It represents in these seas the braize of the European markets, ...' <i>(1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,85</i>)

>  <b>SARA MATHEW</b> ... very fine fish they are [off Whangarei] - schnappers, gurnet and what is called salmon in these seas. <i>(Apr 20, 1840,Journal</i>) [NOTES: 1840 Apr 20 Sarah Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 121]

>  <b>MORRIS</b> <i>Schnapper </i> or <i> Snapper </i>... a fish abundant in all Australasian waters, <i>Pagrus unicolor </i>, Cuv. and Val. The latter spelling was the original form of the word (one that snaps). It was gradually changed by the fishermen, perhaps of Dutch origin, to <i>Schnapper </i>, the form now general. The name <i>Snapper </i> is older than the settlement of Australia, but it is not used for the same fish. `O.E.D.,' s.v. <i>Cavally </i>, quotes: ... In New Zealand, the <i>Tamure </i> (q.v.) is also called <i>Schnapper </i>, and the name <i>Red-Schnapper i </i>s given to <i>Anthias richardsoni </i>, Gunth., or <i> Scorpis hectori </i>, Hutton. <i>(1898,Austral English,404</i>)

Wedde of Oamaru, for the Otago museum. The Museum boasts a particularly fine collection of glassware going back to the days of the early Egyptians and the Director, Dr H.E. Skinner seemed overjoyed that such a famed drinking measure as the `Greymouth Schooner' should find a place in such select company. ## Scotch
 
 <i>adj.</i>

>  <b>SUTHERLAND</b> Another discovery was that the word `Scotch' was worked much harder in New Zealand than in Scotland. It might be used with degrees of meaning ranging from praiseworthy frugality to out-and-out niggardliness. It [41] might be: ``A' will make a farm out of that place if anyone can - he's pretty Scotch.' Or it might be `B's' too Scotch to feed his kids properly.' ## scotia
 
 <i>n.</i> a (usually concave) moulding between a wall and a ceiling. [Jim Cameron writes: NSOD, Collins and Chambers define <i>scotia</i> as a concave/hollow moulding, esp. at the base of an (ionic) column. The OED definition is "a hollow moulding = casement". The latest citation (1878) reads "another kind of base is frequent in which a bead is subsituted for the scotia". <i>Casement</i> in turn is defined in the relevant sense as "a hollow moulding, a cavetto, not exceding one quarter round". <i>Cavettos</i>, it appears, are "principally used in cornices". All this is a bit obscure, but the definitions in NSOD etc would suggest a fairly uncommon word. The ordinary NZ use is specialised though common, and familar to most homeowners - a (usually concave) moulding between a wall and a ceiling. In NZ, it is standard and as well-known as <i>skirting board</i>.]

## Scottish alley
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies. <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,174</i>)



## Scotty

There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies. <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,174</i>)

They scraped it with a shell, having sometimes previously steeped it in water to soften the skin; they then soaked it in water for from two to four days, heated it with stones while it was wet, and scraped it again, then soaked it again, and then bleached it and dried it on poles ... <i>(Jul 13, 1870,Daily Southern Cross,3</i>)

## scratcher
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a bunk or bedding in a musterers' or hunters' hut.

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> scratcher: a bed; a bed-roll; a sack. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,70</i>)

>  <b>CURTIS</b> I had that S.A.S [sub-area supervisor] bloke out of his 'scratcher' as we called our sleeping bags. <i>(1997,Murphy's Law and the Hunter,50</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (informal) bed; a (makeshift) bed, bunk, sleeping bag;(also phrase HIT THE SCRATCHER = hit the sack) [ca1940 Les Cleveland espec. trampers', but also WW2 in 2NZEF (? from fern beds in tramping huts) --ca1945-48 popular in Weir House, VUW.]

>  Take one cuddly middle-aged couple clutching each other's hands over the marital scratcher. <i>(Apr 13, 1999,Dominion,21</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> Mich efficiently putting me to bed in my blankets on the hard stone floor. _ Come on stick your feet down there. Get into the scratcher. <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,92</i>)

>  <b>CRUMP</b> We lit a fire and discussed how we were going to get our sleeping-bags. Jack said someone should ... distract Allan's attention while the others zipped in [to the hut] and grabbed our scratchers. <i>(1960,Good Keen Man, A,33</i>)

>  <b>HELMER</b> [sleeping bag] `After all, getting out of this old scratcher takes a lot of effort.' He hopped back to his bunk ... Then we wash up and crawl into our scratchers. Scuppers has a surplus American Army mummy bag that zips up tight around the head, eh? <i>(1964,Stag Party,56</i>)

>  <b>LELAND</b> <i> scratcher</i>: or Grunter After along and tiring day when you finally lay your wearly bones to rest, you do it on a scratcher. BEDS can of course be used for other activities. <i>(1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,89</i>)

>  By this time I was far too heavy of lid to stay up and retired to the scratcher... <i>(Jun 17, 2003,Dominion Post,B7</i>)

## scroggin
 
 <i>n.</i> a mixture of dried fruit, chocolate, etc., eaten by trampers as a high energy snack. (trampers'); a mixture of dried fruit, chocolate, nuts, etc. carried by trampers as a high-energy snack [? SCRAN + HOG] [ca1945 NCC Small, Les Cleveland, R. Mason (`orig Canterbury ?')]

>  We are two poor students who otherwise would have had to stow away in a depressurised baggage cabin and bring our own 'scroggin', playing 'I spy' for inflight entertainment. <i>(May 2000,Cuisine,No. 80 : 21</i>)

We coax the boys regularly - a barley sugar at half past each hour, a scroggin stop on the hour. <i>(Nov 1, 2005,NZ Herald,E8</i>)

>  If any word originating in the mountain clubs deserves to be incorporated in the language it is perhaps scroggin. That mixture of raisins, sultanas, chocolate, nuts, boiled lollies, a mixture of bits and pieces of whatever one fancies, was evolved to fill the need for a sustaining, palatable, easily-carried food, one as readily available for a bite snatched in a cold, wet, momentary halt as for a welcome spell in the warmth and sun. The word seems to come from Otago but its derivation is not clear. There is a Scotch and North of England dialect word scrog which refers to stunted bushes, and if some Otago Scot had this in mind it prompts dark thoughts as to what the original comestible may have been like. Perhaps it is one of those words that have no known ancestry, that come out of the blue, such as children sometimes so happily coin. <i>(Sep 1958,Tararua,26</i>) [NOTES: 1958 Sep Ruth Mason `Track and Trail' in Tararua 26]

>  SCROGEN 1 cup peanuts 3/4 cup dried apricots 1 + 135 gram block energy chocolate 1/2 cup mixed dried fruit 1/4 cup sunflower seeds 1/2 cup coconut 2 tablespoons powdered glucose. Roast the peanuts at 180 degrees C for 10-15 minutes, or until lightly golden. Cool. Chop the apricots and chocolate coarsely. In a strong plastic bag, put the penuts, apricots, chocolate, mixed fruit, sunflower seeds, coconut and glucose. Shake to combine. Secure closed. Use as a high energy snack food. Makes about 4 cups. <i>(Jan 7, 1980,NZ Woman's Weekly,83/2</i>)

<b>2</b> <i>v.</i> to treat or regard a thing or idea as worthless; cancel irrevocably, write off; wipe; wash out, in racing (of a horse) `to scratch; write off' esp. exclamation: scrub it `forget (all about) it; wipe it; `it doesn't matter'. [[The NZ senses, if not variants of imported Austr (cf P. above) would seem to be orig. associated with, if not originated in, the racing slang: (phs cleaning the bookmaker's slate): scrubbed or scrub (a horse) to have lost; be scratched: or scratch. But the senses also parallel those of words with similar meanings: to wipe (off) (a person or thing), get wiped; wash out (sthg), a wash-out; to write off (sbdy or sthg), a write-off. The word seems noticeable after WW2, so perhaps it was popularised by NZ servicemen who may have picked it up from British Servicemen (or Australians): cf P.4. The connotation of contempt may have derived in part by association with SCRUB n and aj `poor, mean' etc, scrubby etc; and the particular uses of this in Australasia: scrub-bull; scrubber, scrub along.]]

>  <b>GRAHAM</b> JOHN DORY (KUPARU)<i> Zeus australis</i> Richardson <i>Ibid.</i> 180. For some obscure reason the local abundant Seaperch, or Jock Stuart, has been termed the John Dory by Otago commercial and sport fishermen and others. <i>(1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,178</i>)

>  <b>GRAHAM</b> SEAPERCH (POHUIAKAROA) JOCK STUART, HIGHLANDER, FIVEFINGER, SOLDIERFISH or SCRODDIE <i>Helicolenus papillosus</i> (Bloch and Schneider) The seaperch is a fish well known to all fishermen both sports and commercial fishermen alike, who give it quite a number of vernacular names, a few of which are as follows: Jock Stuart, Highlander, Fivefinger and Soldierfish. These names have a bearing on some distinguishing characteristic of the fish. For instance the first two names are supposed to be given on account of the colouring of the fish resembling, in some ways, the tartan of a Scot; while Fivefingers is given on account of the so-called five (really more) fingers (rays) of the pectoral fins, on which the fish has a habit of resting on the floor of the aquarium tank. The name Soldierfish is derived from the similarities of this fish to the activities of a soldier or picket on sentinel duty. I have often seen Seaperch stand or, rather, rest at attention on its pectoral fins for lengthy periods. When it did move, it moved to the right or to the left with the precision of a well-trained soldier. The name Scroddie, commonly used at the northern end of the South Island, is derived from the word Scrod which means a young Dogfish. It appears from my researches that when the early colonists first saw a small Seaperch they at once named it Scrod and later the `ie' was tacked on to make Scroddie. <i>(1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,344</i>)

## seagull
 
 <i>n.</i> a loose forward who positions himself around scrums, line-outs, rucks etc.; a forward who preferring to play very loose, away from the pack; a loose forward or breakaway scavenging for pickings on the outskirts of tight play [ca1950's (F. McKay, St.Patrick's College, Wellington)]

>  `Seagulls' Not Wanted (heading) `Cut out the `seagulling'. There's been too much of it in provincial matches this season.' <i>(Aug 1958,Christchurch Star-Sun,16</i>)

>  <b>HOWITT</b> Probably because he was a loose forward himself and appreciated the need for a `seagull', he chose me for the North Island team four years in a row, from 1953 to 1956. This was the warning given to the New Zealand fifteen forwards prior to their Rugby match with the Maoris last week at Auckland. <i>(1975,NZ Rugby Greats,37</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a useless person or thing [1953 18 M A40 Thames DHS 10 SEAGULL]



 
 <i>v.</i> to work as a seagull q.v.

>  <b>IHIMAERA & LONG</b> we.. drank in streets / and out-ran policemen, / seagulled and played poker <i>(1982,Into the World of Light,256</i>)

>  <b>Owen Marshall</b> The three of them had met as casuals at the woolstores, but more recently seagulled on the Lyttelton wharves. <i>(2005,Watch of Gryphons,59</i>)

>  As a lad in the late 40s, I "seagulled" on the Auckland wharves and I can remember some deliberate "slowing" of cargo-loading operations. But I also recall unloading very hot, dusty cemenet bags from an Auckland scow. <i>(Mar 17, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8</i>)

>  <b>MIDDLETON</b> Bill had been seagulling on the wharf since he got back from the war. <i>Ibid.</i> 217 (Not for a Seagull) Some of the men seagulled on the wharf. Once ... I had teamed up with a stocky little Rarotongan called Steve. <i>(1964,Walk on the Beach,215</i>)

>  <b>GARNIER et al.</b> During the evenings, when he wasn't working night shift on the ferry, Kirk `seagulled' on the Auckland waterfront for one shilling an appearance. <i>(1978,Hunter and the Hill, The,34</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a casual worker on the waterfront [gull ca1935 Auckland Wharves (Mr T.S. Tiller, NZ Railways)] (See [gull](../G#gull))

>  As a rule, the "permanent sea-gulls" were being left on the wharves, unless they were particularly fitted to carry out some essential job in industry. <i>(Sep 20, 1943,NZEF Times,III/117 : 5</i>)

>  <b>IRELAND</b> My father had gone to work as a seagull on the wharf. <i>(1998,Under the Bridge & Over the Moon,137</i>)

>  We troop away to begin our job as "seagulls". <i>(Jan 29, 1947,NZ Observer,9</i>)

>  To all and sundry they [sc. non-unionist watersiders] are known as "seagulls," and they are there in search of food. <i>(Nov 24, 1938,NZ Observer,7</i>)

>  For a time he worked on the wharves as a "seagull" - a casual labourer. <i>(Jul 13, 2000,Evening Post,5</i>)

>  The days of hemp nets and five-ton steam cranes are long gone, as are the early-morning lines of men - "seagulls" - fronting up outside the Waterfront Industry Commission's labour exchange on the chance of a day's work. <i>(Sep 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 65/62</i>)

>  Why are these men regular "sea gulls"? <i>(Jul 14, 1945,Timaru Herald,3</i>)

>  [Hdg] Wharfies v Seagulls : Scene setfor big stoush on the Aucklandwaterfront... Auckland stevedoringcompanies are limited by collectiveemployment contracts to the amount ofcasual labour they can hire and the typeof work carried out by "seagulls", asthey're known. <i>(Mar 24, 1995,Independent (Auckland),6</i>)

>  During the years I have been a "sea gull" I can show a good return for the timekeepers who engage non-union labour in both ports. <i>(Jul 14, 1949,Dominion,6</i>)

>  ... Lest a wharfie should suffer a strain; / Seagulls unsavory / National knavery. <i>(1939,Auckland University Carnival Book,24</i>)

>  <b>MINDY</b> The words have been coined and used by the disgruntled section of the Watersiders' Union ..... A Seagull may be classed as a permanent casual worker who puts in a good deal of his time sitting down upon the stringers on the wharf for the purpose of being able to say that he is a watersider and thereby gain a fictitious status as being one of the best paid workers in the country. <i>(1945,Body-Snatcher and the Seagull, The</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> Ended up as a seagull on the Wellington wharves loading up the Home boats. <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,225</i>)

>  <b>CASEY</b> His father had been a sea-gull - a casual wharfie who had earned enough in three days of the week to keep him in the pub the other four <i>(1963,As Short a Spring,275</i>)

>  <b>MIDDLETON</b> Down on the wharf. I'm what they call a seagull. That's a wharfie who's not in the union. <i>(1964,Walk on the Beach,207</i>) [NOTES: (Not for a Seagull)]

>  <b>TURNER</b> The watersiders have their own special language, but the only term I know from experience is <i>seagull</i>, the casual non-union labourer who picks up a job during busy times on the waterfront. <i>(1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,150</i>)

>  <b>LELAND</b> <i>seagull</i>: a PART TIME or seasonal STEVEDORE on the docks. <i>(1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,89</i>)

>  <i>sea gull ... 2. N.Z. inf.</i> a casual dock worker. <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1039</i>) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 687; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 438]]

>  <b>Owen Marshall</b> The union men were the aristocracy of the shift; anyone else was a seagull, no matter how regular. The wharfies kept jobs like tally-clerk and winchman to themselves. <i>(1984,Day Hemingway Died, The,38</i>) [NOTES: (Late Call)]

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>seagull</i> casual non-union wharf labourer, often a student, accepting the scraps of work the union men did not want; made obsolete in 1970s by stiffening of union and port rules and contraction of wharf labour following containerisation. (see: <i>wharfie</i>) <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,97</i>)

>  <b>HENDERSON</b> The wharfies sat on forms at the tables. ... `She called us seagulls,' said Alec Morrow. <i>(1975,Log of a Superfluous Son, The,33</i>)

>  <b>JACKSON</b> I was a seagull, I said; I picked up casual work on the wharves. <i>(1988,Rainshadow,134</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>T.J. TILLER</b> `Not heard in recent (post-war) years because so few turn up now for a day or two's work. Originally many seamen or temporarily out-of-work watersiders came to the Railways for fill-in jobs' perhaps the origin is suggested by (stringer bird) <i>(1935,Personal Communication</i>)

>  `No! they'll never try to help you, / And they show it everyone. / As they sit upon the stringer / While the stop-work meeting's on. / What a study ! Let us paint it / As the seagulls fly about/ While the stringer birds are anxious / For the meeting to come out. / And the `pannikins' are gathered / Round their rostrums, one by one, / To complete the picture - `Waiting!' / While the stop-work meeting's on' that is, non-union labour (? scabs) who <i>would</i> not join the Union and who sat on the stringers during meetings etc; or perhaps after Compulsory Unionism, sat wating for jobs to turn up like seagulls waiting for scraps. <i>(1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,44</i>)

## seal's ballast
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  Anyone who had ever been about old whaling and sealing stations must have seen collections of round smooth stones of various sizes but mostly about the size of cannon-balls, lying on the beach. On asking any of the `old hands' what these are, you will at once be told that they are `seal's ballast' ... You will probably be gravely told that the seal is a migratory animal, and that when it is about to take a long journey it will trim itself to exactly the proper weight for long and easy locomotion through the water. It picks up one of these stones and swallows it and goes into the water to try the effect. If it finds it requires more ballast it comes ashore again and repeats the dose. If it has too much weight .... it vomits one or two of the stones out on the beach. Hence the stones are always termed `seals' ballast' <i>(1871,TrNZI,4/417</i>) [NOTES: (Otago)]

## second cut
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a group of stock left after the faster-moving leaders or first cut has been separated off. (It is possible to have a third cut.).

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a second attempt at shearing an area of wool from a sheep.

>  <i>second cut NZ & Austral.</i> second blow made to remove badly cut fleece, inferior piece of wool resulting from this. <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,688</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

## selling a horse
 
 <i>phr.</i> a bar game to determine who in a group is to pay for drinks [ca1920s p.c. W.H.B. Orsman (Marlborough): similar to Hokitika Swindle.]

>  A riot occurred at an hotel about 5 p.m. yesterday, when a young man from the country entered into a game called "selling a horse," but then withdrew. <i>(Jan 7, 1909,Wanganui Herald,5</i>)

>  Another form of gambling ... is that known as `selling a horse' ... A member of the party thinks of, or writes down a number and another member starts counting, beginning at any number below ten, and the party takes it in turn to count, much as in the Army a platoon is numbered off. The member saying the number thought of or written down collects the pool. <i>(1948,Auckland Capping Book,16</i>)

>  <b>BELTON</b> The procedure is sometimes referred to as `selling a horse' Each person pools so much money and a number is written down and hidden from view. The person who writes a number down requests one of the others to start counting, commencing at any number desired, provided that it is lower than the winning number. The counting is then carried on in rotation and stops when the written number is reached. The winner then takes the pool and pays for whatever has been purchased .... <i>(1939,Outside the Law,139</i>)

>  <b>HYDE</b> `That doesn't buy our drinks,' said Sam. Another man said: `We'll sell a horse, and find out who pays.' They were selling the horse, when a big black car slid up against the kerb. A voice called: `What's the trouble, you men?' <i>(1938,Nor the Years Condemn,85</i>)

>  Another form of gambling which I view much less harshly is that known as `selling a horse.' The process is as follows. A member of the party thinks of, or writes down a number and another member starts counting, beginning at any number below ten, and the party takes it in turn to count, much as in the Army a platoon is numbered off. The member saying the number thought of or written down collects the pool. This game, though coming under the heading Games of Chance is probably the one really honest game in that category. I myself usually win it, especially in parties where there is no one with a pencil and I think of the number. <i>(1928,Auckland University Carnival Book,16</i>) [NOTES: 1928 Auckland U.C. Students' Association Souvenir Programme Revue `Tilly in the City' 16-17]

>  The matter came to light in the issue of Specialist Education Services employee Celia Lashlie. SES was paying an agency more than $800 a day, long-term. <i>(Jul 25, 2001,Evening Post,2</i>)



## sesh
 
 <i>n.</i> abbrev. of session espec. of jazz, gambling or drinking [ca1945 esp. Varsity undergrads]

>  Another party where there will be boys in the corner sculling neat spirits, where there is no food to soak up the alcohol, where people will be having a "sesh" in the garden, where bad music plays on the stereo, where 14-year-old girls try and bribe someone older than them to buy alcohol. <i>(Oct 1999,North & South,14</i>)



## sesqui
 
 <i>n.</i> short for "sesquicentennial"

>  Just when we were all nicely getting over Sesqui and the cost of the new stadium, we have this unspeakable mess to contend with. <i>(Aug 14, 1999,Dominion,18</i>)

>  A lot of people get a glazed look in the eye when you talk to them about 1990 and say, `Oh yes, sesqui' and we say it's slightly different. <i>(Nov 15, 1989,Dominion,15</i>)

>  I look forward to the next two films in the same series [sc. a film on Pigeon Park] - Action at the Abattoir and Sliding into a Sesqui. <i>(Mar 13, 1992,Evening Post,4</i>)

>  The shadow of Sesqui inevitably hangs over every decision council makes. <i>(Feb 26, 1992,Dominion,9</i>)

>  <b>sesqui</b> (ses'kwe), n. An event doomed to failure, an abandoned place, a secret or unmentionable occurrence, v. t . To inflict severe personal or corporate damage, to induce trauma through the provision of an unwanted service, dry as a sesqui: unprofitable, to be away with the sesquis: to be forced to complete only one-third of a task. to get a good sesqui ing: (colloq.) to be duped, to lose heavily in a gambling situation, to become or take on the appearance or nature of a gittus. <i>(Mar 17, 1990,Evening Post,56</i>)

>  Explaining the planning disaster called Sesqui, one of the organisers was blaming the basic uncertainty inherent in human affairs these days. <i>(Mar 26, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8</i>)



## session
 
 <i>n.</i> period of time occupied with one activity, espec drinking and gambling; a bout of drinking [AND drinking only 1949]

>  <b>COLE</b> Bit of a session, eh ? <i>(1949,It Was So Late,10</i>)

>  Late two-up sessions. <i>(1950,Landfall,14/125</i>) [NOTES: Middleton]

>  <b>JOHNSTON</b> `Moody bugger when he's had a session on the top shelf,' Jamie put to Pop. <i>(1981,Fish Factory,32</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>session</i> period of drinking in a group. ANZ and Brit. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,98</i>)



## set
 
 <i>adj.</i> ready, right, espec, in collocations: all set, I'm set, etc [ca1935 Havelock]

>  <b>BENNETT</b> `I'm set' is ... a variant of the widespread `all set' - to be distinguished from the same phrase used in some Southern English dialects with the ... meaning ... `I'm stuck' <i>(1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,90</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a (solid) foundation (for a timber-jack)

>  <b>REED</b> In bullocking, if a log became stuck while being drawn out of the bush, a good `set' - a solid foundation for the toes - would be obtained for the jack .... <i>Ibid.</i> 175 Great skill was required in obtaining a good `set', both with the jaws which penetrated the log, and the toes which must have a firm foundation. <i>Ibid </i>186 (R. Ross) Simmie Simmons had a set with his jack to try to hold that cat from shooting back ... . <i>(1953,Story of the Kauri, The,176</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>MAHONEY</b> Loaded and almost ready to roll, the two bogies and their log load were called a set by the bushmen. <i>(1998,Era of the Bush Trams in NZ, The,24</i>)

>  We run out on to the main line and pick up six bogie sets, close coupled for running light. We stop at the slab heap and load up the bunker with short slabs. We also load the sets with long slabs for the two log haulers in the bush. <i>(1964,NZ Railway Observer,00</i>) [NOTES: Check page and month]



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [heading dogs] to fix a sheep with a strong, concentrated fix.

>  <b>HARTLEY</b> .. in the case of excessively strong-eyed dogs, it gives the trainer greater command where there is a likelihood of the dog 'setting' sheep and failing to lift or pull. <i>(1949,Shepherd's Dogs, The,3</i>)

>  Mac again raced out on a good cast, but came in slightly at the shoulder and was inclined to set his sheep. <i>(Jul 5, 1951,NZ Farmer,33</i>)

>  <b>MILLS ET AL</b> Young strong-eyed dogs are inclined to 'set' their sheep, eyeing them in a state of frozen immobility so that they show great reluctance to move forward into the lift and pull. <i>(1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,37</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Stinking with eye, Rock 'set' them about six feet from the mouth of the pen. <i>(1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,83</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Eye: common to our heading dogs. This is the action of 'setting' sheep. A very strong-eyed dog ('stinking with eye') works sheep in a manner similar to a cat stalking a bird. <i>(1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,168</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a seed potato, or part, for planting



 
 <i>n.</i> a dislike; prejudice espec have a set on, against, to have a down on, a prejudice against (often used adverbially: have a person set)

>  The feeling is growing here that the Wellington officials have a "set" against the Otago men, and this is given colour to by the fact that the selected sculler, Chapman, being unable to go, they have communicated with M'Cormack and passed over M'Grath. <i>(Apr 16, 1896,Evening Post,2</i>)

>  `There's two girls go to the Kaiapoi. They've got to go clean and tidy, or the other girls will have a set on them.' <i>(Apr 2, 1910,NZ Truth,249/6/1</i>)

>  <b>BENNETT</b> `To have a set on or against someone' represents a conflation of the old-established `to have a down on' and the Australian `to have (a person) set'. <i>(1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,90</i>)

>  <i>to set someone, to have a set on</i> (phrase) intend to do harm to a person. <i>(1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),624</i>)

>  <i>have a set on NZ & Austral.</i> have a grudge against <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,699</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>McCARTHY</b> They were all good miners ... I was bogging the stone, Herbert was getting ready to bore the face again while Jimmy and Jack were putting up the set, that is, were timbering the walls and roof, which was necessary to prevent the walls and roof collapsing when the next `blow' took place. <i>(1973,Listen...!,52</i>)

>  <b>McARA</b> <i>Sets</i>: Basic timbering units, such as drift-sets, square-sets, shaft-sets, cribbing-sets. <i>(1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),332</i>)

>  <b>THOMPSON</b> There was a bad flood in the mine, ... The miners at the face laboured mightily still; they were on a bonus. But the shiftmen, responsible for maintaining `sets' of timber in the mine, grew steadily more shiftless about their work while the truckers ... sat uneasily between the two extremes in alternate bursts of laziness and zeal. <i>(1980,All My Lives,61</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>HARGREAVES</b> The places we put the nets out are called sets. I named one set the Three Sisters after three big cliffs down at South Head. <i>(1998,On the Next Tide,72</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to leave herd or flock to graze uninterrupted in one paddock for a long period, or in several paddocks with gates open

>  <i> Set stock</i>: To leave herd or flock to graze uninterrupted in one paddock for a long period or in several paddocks with gates <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,7</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (a certain) tendency, habit

>  The observer will probably notice that [the saddle-back's] attitude is peculiar, or, in colonial phrase, `it has a queer set on it' <i>(1873,TrNZI,5/183</i>) [NOTES: (Potts)]



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [sp.use] [possum hunting] an elevated site on which to trap possums that is out of harm for kiwis and wekas.

>  <b>MARSHALL</b> Operators working in areas harbouring numbers of kiwis and wekas are urged to try to locate their traps on 'sets.' <i>(1984,Possum Hunting in New Zealand,42</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>v.</i> not to move sheep; ?to settle stock down instead of moving them

>  <b>HARTLEY</b> The system I have devised in the case of excessively strong-eyed dogs, ... gives the trainer greater command where there is likelihood of the dog `setting' sheep and failing to lift or pull. <i>(1949,Shepherd's Dogs, The,3</i>)

 <i>phr.</i> to get something started (also as set it alight! get a move on!, hurry up!

<b>1</b> <i>phr.</i> (Rural) [dog trials] to start a dog on its run.

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Set alight: a slang term referring to the act of starting a dog on its run. <i>(1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,169</i>)



## set in
 
 <i>v.</i> to get settled into, or occupy, a claim [goldmining]

>  I know of one instance of a party..who "setting in" promiscuously on the beach, about three miles from Greymouth, divided GBP198 after a week's work. <i>(Jan 4, 1866,Evening Post,No. 283 : 2</i>)

>  <b>ROCHFORT</b> Our first hole, where we `set in', produced more than a pound of gold. <i>(1853,Adventures of a Surveyor,64</i>)

>  A party of four men .... who, `setting in' promiscuously on the beach ... divided 198 pounds after a week's work. <i>(1866,Evening Post,1/283/2</i>)

>  <b>PYKE</b> Here they halted, and proceeded first to encamp, then to explore the diggings and make necessary enquiries for a likely place `to set in' <i>(1873,Wild Will Enderby,Bk I ch iii 15</i>)

>  <b>McPHERSON</b> They duly pegged off and `set in' on a piece of ground where nobody supposed they would get the colour. .... They shifted their pegs and again `set in' <i>(1892,Gully Wardon,14</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> v.i. to meet and keep company

>  <b>O'REGAN</b> I mind how first we two set in. <i>(1894,Voices of Wave and Tree,14</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> of whales, to bays for calving

>  <b>BELL</b> The black whales visit the bays and coasts of New Zealand for calving, and begin to set in about the beginning of April and remain till about the beginning of September. <i>(1831,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1831 Nov Bell Letter in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 3]



## set in a crack
 
 <i>phr.</i>

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> [The] following [was] employed by those who served in the [Great] War ... set in a crack, to settle (a matter) quickly; <i>(1935,Slang Today,286</i>)

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> <i>Set</i> (something)<i> in a crack</i>. To settle (a matter) quickly; e.g. <i>set a bet in a crack</i>, to wager smartly at two-up; <i>be set in a crack</i>, (of persons) to be comfortably placed (lit. or fig.), to be very pleased with circumstances: New Zealanders': from the 1890's. Perhaps ex. the idea of doing a thing as sharply as the crack of a whip. <i>(1937,Dictionary of Slang,746</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>set in a crack</i> to settle something quickly, perhaps a wager in two-up, or to be well off or fortunate; Partridge suggests it might be from the notion of doing something as smartly as a whip is cracked; c.1890s. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,98</i>)

## set-stock
 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) to graze stock in the same location all season.

>  The dry stock are set-stocked in one or two paddocks, except when they are brought in to clean up after the herd in its grazing rotation. <i>(Feb 1, 1954,NZ Dairy Exporter,12</i>)

>  The flock is set-stocked at tupping time ... <i>(Sep 28, 1961,NZ Farmer,3</i>)

>  Ewes and lambs are set-stocked from lambing until weaning. Ewe lambs are then rotationally grazed until mid-May when they go on to kale. <i>(Jan 1965,NZ Journal of Agriculture,45</i>)

>  Now why does Dave Watt set-stock his milkers rather than graze them rotationally? <i>(Jan 13, 1977,NZ Farmer,4</i>)

>  Hinds are set-stocked or mob-stocked over winter at about 10 to the acre. <i>(1899,NZ Deer Farmer,Summer 8/3</i>)

>  <b>GORDON</b> The ewes are set-stocked, put in paddocks at 2.2 and 2.6 an acre, depending on their age and the class of country ... <i>(1987,People, Places & Paddocks,60</i>)

>  <b>RENNIE</b> Previously animals were set-stocked all year. <i>(1988,Agriculture in NZ,30</i>)

>  Ewes and cows are rotationally grazed together but separated and set stocked during lambing and calving. <i>(Sep 16, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,14</i>)

>  Cattle are set-stocked in the winter at the back of the farm so we have to buy cattle that are used to the terrain. <i>(Mar 29, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,17</i>)

>  Farm Management Spread animals widely if you are set-stocking. <i>(Feb 10, 2002,RD1.com</i>)



## set-stocked
 
<b>1</b> <i>adj.</i> (Rural) [of stock] grazed in one location all year or all season.

>  Set-stocked cows in a Ruakura trial are more relaxed than those on rotational grazing. <i>(Feb 1990,NZ Dairy Exporter,10</i>)

>  Set stocked lambs can increase in live weight by 8%. <i>(Jun 1, 1994,NZ Farmer,23</i>)

>  Set-stocked lambs may need cattle added to their paddocks to reduce the pasture mass. <i>(Jun 1997,AgFact,No 182</i>)

>  It can be diffcult to realise your feed surplus during spring if ewes and lambs are set-stocked. [set stocked] <i>(Nov 22, 2001,Fencepost.com,Expert farming</i>)

>  They are usually old family farms, mortgage-free, and what is called `set-stocked', i.e., not intensively grazed paddock by paddock. <i>(Dec 1952,Here & Now,50</i>)



## set-stocking
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) grazing of the same stock in the same location all year round.

>  <b>STEVENS</b> During the last thirty years two methods of grazing management have been adopted. The first and oldest is 'set-stocking.' In some areas cattle will be carried as a floating grazing unit or 'set-stocked' to deal with surplus growth. <i>(1958,Sheep.  Part 1, Sheep husbandry,59</i>)

>  <b>STEVENS</b> Set-stocking allowed the ewes to become too fat at times of the year.. The most satisfactory solution appears to be a compromise between the two systems, using set-stocking from lambing to weaning, and controlled rotational grazing during the summer, autumn and winter. <i>(1958,Sheep.  Part 1, Sheep husbandry,61</i>)

>  Set stocking is the opposite method [to mob stocking or rotational grazing] used quite commonly on hill country, where the stock is spread out over the whole farm, or most of it, the individual paddocks grazed continuously. <i>(Apr 2, 1959,NZ Farmer,15</i>)

>  .. the smallest-leaf cultivar (tahora) outyielded the larger-leafed pitau and kopu under set-stocking. <i>(Nov 1987,NZ Dairy Exporter,55</i>)

>  <i>set stocking NZ & Austral</i>. grazing of livestock in one or more paddocks for a continuous period of time (cf. <i>mob stocking</i>); <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,699</i>)



## settle
 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) [sp. use] to take over or establish ownership on land that has belonged to the government.

>  <b>PULLEN</b> We stayed managing until August 1975, then the block we were on was due to be settled so we had to find other employment. <i>(1996,On the Road Again,5</i>)



## settlement
 
 <i>n.</i> [Also village settlement report]

>  <b>ELDER</b> In drawing up these drastic regulations, it is plain, Marsden practically confessed, that `the settlement system,' which depended upon the missionaries growing enough to support themselves, had failed. <i>(1932,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,412 ed. fn</i>)

>  <b>WAKEFIELD</b> But I am satisfied ... that the more and greater settlements there are in New Zealand ... the better for the Wellingtonians. <i>(Jan 8, 1840,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1840 E.G. WAKEFIELD Letter Jan 8 in 1901 FAWCETT Sir William Molesworth 173]

>  NO. I, a Specimen Number of the NEW ZEALAND GAZETTE, a Newspaper for the First and Principal Settlement of the New Zealand Land Company, which it is supposed will be at <i>Port Nicholson</i>, in <i>Cook's Straits</i>, is now presented to the public. <i>(Aug 21, 1839,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,1</i>)

>  With the passing of nearly three-quarters of a century since the venturesome pioneers commenced to push their way into the unexplored portions of Southland and laid the foundations of that settlement which has resulted in the largely cultivated province of to-day, it cannot be expected that a great many of these hardy explorers will remain much longer with us and the death of any one of them makes an irreplacable [sic] blank in a band of people which has called for the respect and admiration of the generations who have succeeded them. <i>(Nov 8, 1932,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,3</i>)

>  The Bill provides that all moneys [sic] received on account of the purchase of the freehold of settlement lands (i.e., Land for Settlements holdings) is to be paid into the Land for Settlements Account, when it will automatically be devoted to the acquisition of further areas of private land for closer settlement. <i>(Sep 7, 1910,Evening Post,7</i>)

>  LETTERS RECEIVED .. "W.J.," on Our Frontier Settlements and Rifle Practice" .. Mr. R. McEwen, on Pollok Settlement Highway Board ... <i>(Jun 16, 1871,Daily Southern Cross,2</i>)

>  Amended regulations for village special settlement on perpetual leases, is gazetted. <i>(Jun 4, 1886,West Coast Times,4</i>)

 <i>n.</i>

## settler
 
 <i>n.</i> a var iety of mullet

>  This variety of mullet [which feeds in the ocean and shoals along the coast] is known to the fishermen and the [Northland] settlers as the `clean-gut', `clean-run', or `sea-mullet'. ... The other variety [which stays in the harbour] is known to the fishermen as the `settler' or muddy fish'. When opened they are not clean and bright ... but full of slimy mud ... <i>Ibid.</i> 7 The fishermen in Kaipara distinguish between `school fish' and `settlers'. ... The `settlers' are those mullet of moderate size which stay in the harbour and run up rivers. <i>(1897,AJHR,H-17/2</i>) [NOTES: Hector Protection of Mullet]



 
 <i>n.</i> an immigrant who set up home in NZ, cf. early settler

>  We would also draw your Honor's attention to the fact that the Government reserve near the mouth of the Kaitangata Creek is admirably suited for the site of a Jetty, having natural facilities nowhere else to be found in the district, and being near the proposed Railway Station will thus enable up-country settlers to forward or receive goods with the least possible delay ... <i>(Jan 30, 1874,Bruce Herald,4</i>)

>  To Emigrants and Settlers in particular, during the passage, it [Eamonson's inodorous chamber convenience] will be found invaluable. <i>(Aug 21, 1839,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,1</i>)

>  The above results are due largely to the great intrinsic worth of the country which the new settlers adopted as their home, but they are also due to the sturdy, industrious, and upright character of the men who came out from Scotland in the John Wickliffe, Philip Laing, and other vessels to form a Scottish settlement in the New World. <i>(Mar 23, 1898,Poverty Bay Herald,2</i>)

>  It appears that the Times had again opened its columns to assailants of the Port Nicholson settlers, and had lent its influence to bolster up the tottering clique at Auckland. <i>(Feb 26, 1842,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,2</i>)

>  The roads and necessary public works are being prosecuted with vigour, under the direction of Captain Thomas, and the various towns, with the suburban lands contiguous, laid out for the reception of the settlers. <i>(Jan 5, 1850,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,175</i>)

>  A number of settlers were coming here for their own good, but who at the same time were desirous of leaving an evidence of their industry to those who came after them, and establishing for themselves some reputation as colonists ... <i>(Feb 9, 1865,Otago Daily Times,5</i>)

On arrival in Wellington he acquired laud in the present suburb of Taitville, on the western heights of the city, and he was the first settler there, being generally regarded as the founder of the present residential area in the district. <i>(Sep 27, 1926,Evening Post,10</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a farmer

 <i>n.</i> (Rural) [sp. use] a rehabilitated soldier farmer.

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) an occupier of a small holding of land [ usually that which has not been previously farmed.]

## sevens
 
 <i>n.</i> a ball game

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Ball-bouncing games have come into their own on the asphalt playgrounds of modern schools and are played in many schools throughout the country. There is no evidence of such games before 1900, but a number of instances between 1900 and 1920 are recorded. The games were known as Fives, Tens, Sevens, and Walls and have been recorded more often since under the names O'Leary or Sevens. Before 1920 there is only one report of the game being played with a rhyme, and this was a rhyme more often used in skipping. <i>(1981,History of Children's Play,273</i>)

## shagroon
 
 <i>n.</i> an immigrant esp. from Australia, but also from other settlements) to the early Canterbury settlement, often applied to one settled there before the main influx of PILGRIMS (contrast PILGRIM, PRE-ADAMITE, PROPHET) [History: an early non-Canterbury Association settler in Canterbury. (hist) [OED2 (following Morris) Phs f. Irish <i>seachra'n </i>wandering.:<i> searchan</i> transliterates <i>shaughraun </i>=?/sh |r n/: I have not been able to find Walls's<i> shabberoon</i>, etc., but if these forms exist they are more likely to be alterations of <i>shagroon</i> towards a play on<i> shab</i>, a common English dialect variant of <i>scab</i>, the dread sheep disease of early NZ, which would fit in with the usu.derogatory or dismissive connotations of the word.b But <i>shab, shabbaroon </i>are not yet otherwise attested in NZ contexts and must be ruled out; as must Sinclair's suggestion of <i>shagreen</i> (rough exterior) spg also <i>shagaroon, shagrun;</i> ?erron. spg or misprint <i>shaproon</i>; cf Walls's <i>shabberoon etc</i>. occas. cap. Morris 1898]

>  In a letter dated 8th March 1850, in mentioning a visit to the Taieri Plain, the writer says: "We visited the warri or hut of a Shaproon - <i>ie.,</i> one of the retired whalers 'who have married Maori wives.' Can you tell me the meaning and derivation of the word Shaproon, and why the retired whalers were so called?" <i>Ibid</i> 22 September. 24 Shaproon is from the French <i>chaperon</i>, and originally meant "little captain." ..There is no doubt that the term was used by French sailors and those in contact with them with the same meaning as English sailors use the word mate. Mispronounced and misspelt by its adoption into the English of rough-and-ready sea-faring men, shaproon would have this signification, and even under certain circumstances might reassume its original acceptation of little leader, and be addressed to the captain of a small band, and become equivalent in a new country, as this was 50 years ago, to the word pioneer. <i>(Sep 15, 1892,Otago Witness,24</i>)

>  <b>WALL</b> Who first called these immigrants by this opprobrious name is not stated, but it seems to me most probable that the Pilgrims used it as a term of contempt, and [110] that the immigrants took it to themselves much as the `Old Contemptibles' ... adopted their enemies' names in a spirit of defiance. ... There arises the further question as to the origin of the word which ... has been explained as an Irish `shaughraun'. Now why should an Irish word have been used at that time by the English settlers in Canterbury? ... My belief is that the word was not originally `Shagroon' but `Shabroon', `shabberoon', `shabbaroon' (all spellings occur) which is on record from the 18th century onwards, meaning `a mean, shabby fellow', `a disreputable or mean-spirited fellow', and this, which would be probably familiar to the English Pilgrims, is just the sort of term which would naturally be used to describe their rivals. This `shabroon' derives from the slang `shab', a low fellow, recorded as early as 1637, and no doubt closely alied to the standard `shabby', and ultimately from `shab' and `scab', two forms of the old English word. ... I conjecture that the `shabroon' [?does Wall mean `shagroon] of the English Pilgrims was by some pronounced with the `b' and by others with the `g', nobody ever having seen the word written or printed. [EDD records only `shaggareen' from east Yorkshire `an untidy, slovenly person'; possibly f. shabrag] <i>(Nov 25, 1948,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1948 Nov 25 Arnold Wall letter in 1947 Reed Story of Canterbury 109-110]

>  <b>REED</b> It appears to have been the Australian squatters [let in to Canterbury by Godley to provide capital and flocks for unsold land] who jocularly termed the pioneer English settlers the `Canterbury Pilgrims', ... [Quotes Webster and Funk and Wagnall: both definitions erroneous] <i>(1947,Story of Canterbury, The,109</i>)

>  The pilgrim toiled for his crop. ... [title of Poem] 9.[NOTE 1866] 125. During the first year of the Settlement, Canterbury was invaded by a body of sheep-farmers from Port Philip (Victoria) who were regarded by the settlers partly with admiration as successful Colonists, and partly with horror as disbelievers in the art of colonisation and the `Canterbury System'. The visitors found the country admirably adapted for sheep-farming, and they treated with some contempt the raw emigrants from England who looked to agriculture as the foundation of their fortunes. One of the vistiors, who seem to have delighted in the soubriquet of `Shagroon', ventured to prophesy, in a letter, which found its way into print, that the `Canterbury Pilgrims' would soon be ruined and their country left for occupation by his more enlightened comrades. The `pilgrims' sought no harsher revenge than to nickname their Port Philip visitors `prophets' and to take example from their experience in pastoral pursuits. The Canterbury pasturage system was quickly adapted to the requirements of sheepfarming on a large scale, and `pilgrims' and `prophets' were soon merged into one class of Canterbury runholders.]

## shaker
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>CARR</b> When the flax arrives at the mill it is weighed and credited to the cutter. The `bench loader' then takes two or three bundles and puts them in a barrel (heavy end down). He then takes the longest leaves and places them on a bench convenient to the `feeder'. ...[44] The `feeder' takes each blade separately and places the butt end into the `stripper' which takes the green outer covering off. ... The fibre as it leaves the stripper is caught by the `fly boy', who collects enough to make into a hank, which he places convenient for the `shaker'. The latter, with a motion like cracking a whip, gets rid of as much rubbish as possible, after which he places the hank handy for the `washer'. This man places the fibre in a vat, through which ... clean water is running. <i>(1913,Country Work,43</i>)

## shanty
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> a rough wooden hut or shack, often in the bush (See [cf. bush shanty](../B#bush-shanty))

>  A TYPICAL NORTH ISLAND BUSH SHANTY. <i>(Dec 19, 1906,Otago Witness,15</i>) [NOTES: Photo Caption]

>  Virtually every settlement in the youngcolony originally clustered around itstaverns - even if they were only tatteredcalico shanties. <i>(Jan 12, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26</i>)

>  Kororarika is still the principal settlement, and contains about [296] twenty houses, ... and many shanties, besides tents. It is chiefly inhabited by the lowest order of vagabonds, mostly runaway sailors and convicts, and is appropriately named `Blackguard Beach'. <i>(1852,U.S. Exploring Expedition,1/295-296</i>) [NOTES: 1840 Mar in 1852 Wilkes U.S. Exploring Expedition]

>  <b>HAY</b> There are shanties and shanties. It is necessary to explain. Primarily, in its Canadian and original sense, the term means a log-house - a hut made of rough squared logs, built up upon each other. Such log-huts are not common in this country, though they may be seen here and there. ... The native whare[e-grave] of thatch is quickly and easily raised, serves all requirements, and lasts for years ... A shanty here, is a name applied to almost any kind of nondescript erection, which would not come under the designation of [117] whare[e-grave], or be honoured by the ambitious title of house. Rough edifices of planking are the common form. a hut (cf <i>built a warre </i>Jan 6) <i>(1882,Brighter Britain,1/116</i>)

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> He [the pioneer pastoralist] has built a domicile of some sort, be it of canvas, calico, bagging, sticks, ferntrees, grass, slabs, mud, clay, stone, or wattle and daub. He may call it various names according to its materials, but three names would not enter his head - i.e., crib, bach, or shack. He may call it a cabin, a shanty, a cottage, a warrie [whare], but probably he would use the commonest term of all - hut. <i>(1947,Early Runholding in Otago,38</i>)

>  <b>REED</b> A shattered site having been selected near to running water, an advance party would be sent to clear the necessary space and build a `shanty' which, in the earlier days, served inclusively as dormitory, dining hall and cookhouse. 1953 <i>op.cit.</i> 142 (Mrs. Brown's account) On our first arrival at a new camp we generally lived in a nikau whare until my husband could split the palings and build a shanty for us; the men lived in another and larger shanty. <i>(1953,Story of the Kauri, The,130</i>)
