## sharemilker
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a sharefarmer who part-owns and shares the profit of a herd's production with a landowner.

>  Taranaki heifers have established a reputation for their milking qualities. Already three hundred have been sent from Stratford to a Canterbury run-holder who is cutting up his sheep run into milking farms and putting on sharemilkers. <i>(Jun 4, 1910,Hawera Star,4</i>)

>  Wanted at once, strong sharemilkers to hand milk 60 cows. <i>(Dec 31, 1918,Hawera Star,1</i>)

>  Many a successful dairy farmer in the dairying districts of New Zealand today gained his initial experience in dairying as a sharemilker and was able to obtain sufficient capital to commence operations on his own. <i>(Dec 15, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,621</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a cow that doubles as a house cow while rearing a calf.

>  <b>GORDON</b> sharemilker: a cow that doubles as house cow while rearing a calf. <i>(2000,Other Side of Farming, The,6</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a person who shares work on a dairy farm for a share of the profits, and sometimes has his or her own herd of cows.

>  Mrs. Share Milker was the first toarrive. <i>(Sep 1, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,84</i>)

>  The sharemilker starts out at any old time around about 5 a.m. <i>(Jun 30, 1944,Te Awamutu Courier,4</i>)

>  Under the merger proposals as they now stand, the sharemilker won't own shares in the mega corp. <i>(Jul 28, 1999,Independent (Auckland),7</i>)

>  On November 1, New Zealand's leading sharemilkers will be invited to compete in the 2000 Bank of New Zealand Sharemilker of the Year... One of the great advantages of the competition is that sharemilkers learn a great deal from taking part. <i>(Aug 27, 1999,Dominion,Farming Advertising Feature : 14</i>)

>  Take the sharemilker who is milking his 100 cows. He rises at half-past two a.m., and musters his cows, has to get them miked by seven o'clock, take his milk to the factory; and after that has to feed over 90 calves, and about thirty pigs. He has to provide root crops for his pigs, and see that he has a sufficient supply of hay, etc., for his cows in the winter, keep his fences in repair, and stump what ground he requires to grow his crops. There is no eight hours for that sharemilker. <i>(Mar 9, 1905,Hawera & Normanby Star,2</i>)

>  When you're playin' these Sons of the Sharemilkers, yous have to make real sure that if anythin' niffs even slightly of dried milk powder, yous knock it over, stamp on it until it stops squeakin', and then jump on it again just to make sure. <i>(Oct 18, 1998,Sunday Star Times,B3</i>)

>  As for the last verse.. it's so much thefarmhand and the sharemilker and everyoneexcept the boss that it just isn't true. <i>(1955,She'll Be Right Record Sleeve,00</i>)

>  <b>BACON</b> <i>sharemilker</i>-One who contracts to milk a herd of cows for a share of profits. In general, sharemilkers fall into three categories: first, the 29 per cent sharemilker, second, the 39 per cent man, third, the 50 per cent man. The 29 per cent man contracts to milk the farmer's herd and attend to their wants only; he helps at haymaking, etc. as part of the herd's `wants', but in general, once the cows have been attended to for the two daily milkings, his time is his own. The 39 per cent man contracts to milk the herd owned by the farmer and to do all the other general farm work. For this he receives 39 per cent of the herd profits. The 50 per cent sharemilker runs his own herd of cows on another man's land. He does all the farm work, and receives 50 per cent of the profits. Many farmers who today have their own farms in New Zealand started off as 39 per cent share milkers, saved enough to buy their own herds and so became 50 per cent milkers, then saved again to purchase land themselves (or on which they put sharemilkers!) <i>(1963,In the Sticks,183</i>)

>  A feature of dairy-farming in New Zealand has been the development of share-milking, akin to the old French system of me[acute]tayage or the sharefarming common with annual crops such as cotton in the United states of America. Under this system the owner usually provides the land, plant, and herd, while the share-milker provides labour and receives in return one-third to one-half of the gross returns. In other cases the sharemilker also provides the dairy herd and receives two-thirds of the gross receipts. <i>(1943,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,24/231a</i>)

>  <b>POWDRELL</b> The share-milker's remuneration consists of 1/3 of all milk moneys, 2/5 of calves sold, and 1/2 of the profits from the pigs sold. <i>(1920,Dairy Farming in NZ,9</i>)

>  <b>BENNETT</b> The pastoral life of New Zealand also has its own vocabulary. <i>Share-milker</i> is explained by its Australian and American parallels <i>sharefarmer and sharecropper.</i> <i>(1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,86</i>)

>  <b>SCANL;AN</b> Not until Grandpa had handed over the arduous work of dairying to a share-milker ... had they moved to the big house ... <i>(1948,Dusty Road,7,1949 ed.</i>)

>  I would include among New Zealand English words: <i>share-milker </i> <i>(May 6, 1952,VUC First Year English Class</i>)

>  <b>SHADBOLT</b> <i>(1966,Short Stories (various authors),302</i>)

>  <b>SHADBOLT</b> <i>(1965,Among the Cinders,158</i>)

>  <b>SARGESON</b> <i>(1966,Memoirs of a Peon,271</i>)

>  ... a <i>sharemilker</i>, a man who milks cows on another's farm for a share in the profit ... <i>(1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,150</i>)

>  Sharemilking [heading] The sharemilker represents the greater part of the experienced, stable farm labour that is available to the New Zealand dairy farmer. A sharemilking agreement allows men with little capital to share in a dairy farm's production and profits. <i>(1974,NZ Agriculture,88</i>)

>  <b>MANTELL</b> Mr Robinson was a share-milker on a local farm. He lived by himself in a bach on a back paddock. <i>(1980,Murder and Chips,153</i>)

>  <i>share-milker n. </i>(in New Zealand) a person who lives on a dairy farm and milks the farmer's herd in return for an agreed share of the profits. <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1061</i>)

>  <b>KEENE</b> When the Slump hit the country, he could no longer afford a sharemilker, so with the help of a boy had to do the milking himself. <i>(1982,Myrtle and Sophia,64</i>)

>  <b>MANTELL</b> <i>(1984,Murder in Vain,73</i>)

>  There is something about the dairy industry that sparks personality changes when sharemilkers become farm owners, and farm owners morph into cooperative directors. <i>(Mar 25, 2000,Dominion,13</i>)

>  Sir, - I read `The Dominion's' second editorial of Jauary 25, `Our `She'll-Be-Right' Attitude,' with interest, but as a Grim Dig I feel that it is my duty to point out to the younger generation the origin and meaning of the expression `she's right' `She's right' or `She'll-Be- Right' originated in the Army and was only used when the person using the saying was satisfied that he had done his particular job to the best of his ability and took pride in it. If, on the other hand, he had done the job to the best of his ability but he was not satisfied with the job, he used the phrase `She's not too good' or `She's pretty poor' Never was the phrase `She's right' used in the sense that politicians and various other people not in the know use it to refer to a job badly done or done with a `couldn't-care-less' attitude. This was never necessary because in the Army we had other phrases to cover such contingencies when things did not go according to plan, such as NAFU and SAFU, the first being a non-adjusting fiasco, and the second being a self-adjusting fiasco. To say the least of it, I feel strongly that it is disrespectful to the originators of the saying `She's right' to use it in the present accepted sense, and I feel also that all Grim Digs should rise up in righteous wrath, but `don't do your scone boys.' Belmont. INFANTEER. <i>(Jan 30, 1963,Dominion,8</i>)

>  DRAFTED SHEEP READY FOR THE SHEARERS. THE SHEEP ARE DRIVEN INTO PENS IN THE SHED, AND A CONSTANT SUPPLY KEPT READY AT HAND FOR EACH SHEARER. <i>(Feb 10, 1904,Otago Witness,38</i>) [NOTES: Photo Caption]

>  <b>BUTLER</b> The shearers will want to begin with daylight. <i>(1863,First Light,158</i>)

>  He was a shearer. <i>(Jan 18, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,7</i>)

>  It is understood that the sheep-owners have already discussed what action they will take in the event of shearers refusing employment. <i>(Sep 15, 1921,Ashburton Guardian,4</i>)

>  <b>FITTON</b> The shearing of the sheep is generally done by contract; ... at so much per 100 sheep shorn - their [sc. hands'] rations, in addition to their pay, being provided for the shearers. <i>(1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),220</i>)

>  <b>ACLAND</b> The shearers get through their work with a rapidity unknown in England. <i>(1858,Notes on Sheepfarming in NZ,11</i>)

>  [defined in section 3 The electoral Laws Amendment Act, 1893] <i>(1894,NZ Official Yearbook,252</i>)

>  <i>Shearer</i>.- One who shears (and while so employed does nothing else). <i>Ss</i>., who always work in company and generally stick to the work for years, meet a great many people and see a great many stations; so they have a great store of expressions connected with their work. Some of them have already been noted (<i>rosella, cobbler</i>, etc.) If two <i>ss</i>. are working out of sight of each other, they can tell one another `where they are' (what part of the sheep they are on) to an inch. A shearer first shears the belly (<i>on the b</i>.), then<i> opens up</i> or goes <i>up the neck</i>, then successively does his <i>first leg, first side, up the back,</i> and so on; finally the last blows trim the <i>last leg</i>, and he is <i>off</i>. But they also use a rhyming slang sometimes among themselves; say,<i> `found a nail'</i> for <i>`round the tail', `hutch'</i> for <i>`crutch',</i> and so on. I have always meant to collect these terms but never have. (C.) <i>(Nov 25, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> Otoro was George's first contract shed. ... But all his shed hands, shearers and his wool classer had been with him before. <i>(1986,Off the Sheep's Back,94</i>)

>  <b>OGONOWSKA-COATES</b> <i>Shearer</i>. One who shears. <i>(1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,97</i>)

>  <i> shearer</i>: Like other shed employees, the shearer has many names, for example, `greasy', `gouger', `stooper', `bladesman', `woolhawk', `brute' and `tiger'. <i>(1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/27</i>) [NOTES: Wallace Shearing Glossary]



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> [blade shearer]

## shearing blast
 
 <i>n.</i> Shearing-blast may be of two kinds. True shearing-blast is caused by the comb of the shearing-machine actually damaging the surface of the skin. This defect is seen as numerous lines parallel to each other running in various directions on the skin. The other defect [in pelts] often described as shearing-blast is really due to sunburn.

 <i>n.</i> (Rural) the separating of stock in a mob or herd. [1958 and 1963 citations below belong with the verb shed off]

 <i>n.</i> (Rural) the separating of stock within a mob.

Gordon)]

But some older writers make some surprising slips, and a really noticeable instance is in the inscription in the porch of the Memorial Church at Cave, South Canterbury, which reads: `This porch is erected to the glory of God in memory of the sheep-men, shepherds, bullock-drivers, shearers, and station-hands who pioneered the back-country of this province between the years 1855 and 1895' When I first read this inscription, the word `sheep-men' made me involuntarily flinch. Years later, when I had forgotten it, I suddenly met it again, and again I recoiled. So aghast was I that I spent weeks collecting every old term for `runholders' I could, and I found thirteen, viz., flock-owners, flock masters, pastoralists, run holders, run owners, sheep owners, sheep holders, sheep masters, squatters, station holders, station owners, stock holders and stock owners. ## sheep-oh
 
 <i>n.</i> a shearers' cry (See [penner-up](../P#penner-up))

>  <b>REES</b> The [shearing-] gang [included] ... some boys to act as `sheepo's' - that is to keep the pens in the shed filled up from the yards outside. <i>(1925,BLANK ENTRY,111</i>)

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> The `sheep-oh' (penner-up) also held an important position. In addition to filling up the catching pens, he weighed the bales and recorded them, with their descriptions in the wool book. <i>Ibid.</i> 127 At Waimate there were about 50 men and boys employed for the shearing - 22 shearers, 1 sheep-oh, 4 fleece-pickers, 4 wool-rollers, 1 brander, 1 wool-classer, 1 classer's boy, 3 pressers, 1 waggoner, 1 cook, 1 cook's mate, generally known as the offsider or `slushy' 8 shepherds; and last, but not least the shed boss, ... ## sheepdog

The dogs that bring sheep are called<i> heading ds.</i> (q.v.) and most of these can be taught to <i>lead</i> (q.v.) if desired. So aghast was I that I spent weeks collecting every old term for `runholders' I could, and I found thirteen, viz., `flock owners,' `flock masters,' `pastoralists,' `run holders,' `run owners,' `sheep owners,' `sheep holders,' `sheep masters,' `squatters,' `station holders,' `station owners,' `stock holders,[sic] and `stock owners.' ## shellfish
 
 <i>n.</i> [An Australian lexicographer points out there is a difference between most dictionary definitions and what the public see as a shellfish; likewise in NZ the fishery regulations define for their convenience shellfish as including, from memory, crayfish, sponges and possibly even sea-grass. The sensible thing would be to redefine using as the basic definition the scientific one. The present OED definition is: Any animal living in water whose outer covering is a shell, whether testaceous, as an oyster, or crustaceous, as a crab. This wording is followed by Random House and Macquarie whereas the general public and scientists tend to think of a shellfish as a member of the class Mollusca, i.e. mostly animals with a hard calcareous shell or shells.]

>  <i>Shepherd.</i> ... 3. To be a shepherd, e.g. `Bill is <i>shepherding</i> at __'s.' <i>(Dec 2, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <i>Shepherd.</i>- (1) Man employed to work sheep. Except a <i>lambing s.</i>, or <i>shed s</i>., who are specially employed for a certain time, a <i>s</i>. is a permanent hand. If he is only employed for the busy season he is called a <i>musterer.</i> (C.) (2) To tail sheep by day and yard them at night. The <i>shepherding </i>system of sheep management was much employed in the early days of Australia, where the sheep would otherwise have been exposed to attack from blacks and dingoes. The <i>shagroons </i>(q.v.) carried it on to some extent on the Canterbury plains in the 'fifties, but soon gave it up for a system of <i>boundary keeping,</i> and afterwards fenced their runs. (C.) 3. To be a shepherd, e.g. `Bill is <i>shepherding</i> at __'s.' <i>(Dec 2, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>MACKIE</b> A few miles further brought us to a shepherd's hut; we found the shepherd ... unwell, having met with a serious accident whilst hunting wild dogs. These dogs are of English origin, they are often met with and are destructive to the sheep ... <i>(Mar 11, 1853,Traveller under Concern,86,1973 ed.</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a man employed to drive sheep in from the holding-paddock [ca1951 May 17 Feilding Freezing Works terms p.c. Colin Gordon Shepherds: who drive in stock.]



 
<b>2</b> <i>v.</i> to guard (a claim)

>  The diggers had to encounter very severe weather, it raining in torrents and blowing fearfully, which had much impeded their operations; and many were standing by shepherding their claims until the fine weather set in. <i>(Sep 26, 1857,Otago Witness,6</i>)

>  The miners are still engaged in shepherding their claims, and no work of any kind whatever is being carried on. <i>(Jan 20, 1870,Daily Southern Cross,3</i>)

>  <b>PYKE</b> They were all working miners, and one of them always `shepherded' the claim, whilst the others wrought for wages elsewhere. <i>(1887,History of the Early Gold Discoveries  in Otago,118,1962 ed.</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>v.</i> to watch (a claim) with intent to opportunistically defraud the rightful owner of possession, i.e. to jump it -

>  <b>COOPER</b> The prowling, dastardly enemy ... plants himself at the claim, and there ... he patiently waits during the absence of his future victim. This, in the language of the diggers, is called `shepherding a claim'. At the end of twenty-four hours he seizes it, and ... appropriates ... the hard-earned property of the sick man. <i>(Nov 28, 1867,Digger's Diary,17,1978 ed.</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>v.</i> to tail or shadow

>  I told him, and he said he had been shepherding me for some days, and asked me if I would go mates with him to the diggings. <i>(Jan 25, 1862,Otago Witness,3</i>)

>  <b>PYKE</b> But they're on gold anyhow, ... And there's a whole mob of fellows shepherding them [to discover their claim]. <i>(1873,Wild Will Enderby,Bk III ch ii 77</i>)

>  <b>BARRINGTON</b> About this time there is great talk of a man called M'Girk, <i>alias</i> the `Maori Hen', getting gold somewhere out towards the West Coast, ... He has [?had chk] been shepherded by a dozen men on several occasions, but always managed to give them the slip. <i>(Dec 27, 1863,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1863 Dec 27 Barrington Diary in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 394]

>  <b>LOVELL-SMITH</b> Twice a week the journey was completed by Cobb's coach in one day, and on the other days the coach stopped for the night at Halfway House, shepherding Quick's coach, which also stopped there. <i>(1931,Old Coaching Days,30</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>v.</i>

>  Shepherding forbidden. <i>(1864,AJHR,C-4-8</i>) [NOTES: (1862 Regulations)]

>  <b>WARDON</b> The majority of claims were simply being shepherded, their occupiers waiting till some of their more enterprising neighbours had bottomed in order to decide by the result whether to sink or shift their pegs. <i>(1892,MacPherson's Gully,13</i>)

>  <i>shepherd n.</i> a miner who holds a claim but neglects to work it; -v.t. to do only sufficient work on a mining claim to retain legal hold of it. <i>(1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,10</i>)

>  <i>shepherd v.tr.</i> to guard a mining claim and do a little work on it, so as to preserve legal rights, whence. <i>shepherd n. </i>shepherd, one who so holds a claim. <i>(1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),624</i>)

>  During all this time every one aspiring to a share must have done something to demonstrate the fact that he is an owner. ... He must, in fact, `shepherd his claim', or his claim will be jumped. <i>(1908,TrNZI,40/169</i>)

>  <i>Shep&#769;.-herd&#769;.</i> (sh&ebreve.p&#769;.&etilde.rd), <i>v. t. [Add.] 2. (Mining)</i> To retain possession of (a claim) by bare legal compliance with the labor clauses of the mining act, pending decision of the warden as to right of ownership. <i>(1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2031</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>v.</i> to hold a lease of land not being worked by the leaseholder

>  There are at this moment, many large tracts of land, leased, which are lying, for all purposes of reproductiveness, utterly valueless; in fact, to use an old Victorian expression, being `shepherded', the lesses of which, are Micawber-like, `waiting for something to turn up' in their neighbourhood, before they turn to with a will and work the ground <i>(1869,McLean Papers,31/189,1939 ed.</i>)



 
<b>3</b> <i>v.</i> (someone or something); to guide

>  <b>CHAMIER</b> [She instructed] her brother to `shepherd' him carefully till evening, and to refrain from over-indulgence in strong liquor. <i>(1895,South Sea Siren,95</i>)

>  <b>PFAFF</b> A party of adventuresome white people in 1860 ... arrived at the Buller ... expressed their desire to return to civilisation, and Mackay, after fixing up some Native Reserves at the Buller, agreed to shepherd them to Massacre bay. <i>(1914,Diggers' Story, The,1</i>)

>  <b>BRUNO</b> The supply trucks roared ahead, while the tanks shepherded them. <i>(1944,Desert Daze,67</i>)

>  <b>HOWE</b> His work was often dangerous, as he and his gang shepherded the logs down the valley whenever there was a freshet from the hills. <i>(1964,Stamper Battery,7</i>)



 
<b>3</b> <i>v.</i> to hinder an opponent from tackling the man with the ball

>  <i>shepherd v.</i> in N.Z., protect a rugby player illegally by coming between man and ball, and a would-be tackler; guard a mining claim and do little work on it, so as to preserve legal rights; whence shepherd, one who so holds a claim. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),17</i>)



 
<b>3</b> <i>v.</i> in various senses and applications within the general meaning `look after; watch over'

>  <b>WAYTE</b> Miss Amazon's instructions to her jockey were to `shepherd' the horse around the course. (ie. ride a waiting race .... The philologist would note that the word `shepherding' is of universal application in colonial parlance. If a stranger is lionised about a place, he is said to be `shepherded'. I once heard a man ask his neighbour to `shepherd' his grog while he left the room. It is of course natural that metaphors should be derived from the chief industries of the country.] <i>(1879,Prospecting for Gold,85</i>) [NOTES: 1879 Wayte Prospecting; or 18 Months in Australia and New Zealand 85]



 
<b>3</b> <i>n.</i>

>  <i>shepherd n.</i> a miner who holds a claim but neglects to work it; -v.t. to do only sufficient work on a mining claim to retain legal hold of it. <i>(1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,10</i>)

>  <i>shepherd v.tr. </i>to guard a mining claim and do a little work on it, so as to preserve legal rights, whence. <i>shepherd n.</i> shepherd, one who so holds a claim. <i>(1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),624</i>)

 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> The custom in the old days was to call the buildings on a run `the station,' and the land that went with it was `the run.' On a big property you could find several `stations,' and the principal one was called `the home station,' while the others were `out-stations.' This was the old Australian usage which was carried over to New Zealand at first, but gradually the signification was altered by loosely calling the whole run a station, and then the real station became a homestead and the out-stations became shepherds' huts. In this present book it will be noticed that generally the writer has preserved the olden custom of calling the main buildings the station and the land the run. The runs over in Australia being, as a rule, much larger than those in New Zealand, the `station' and `out-station' phraseology was preserved much longer than over here, where even in advertisements in the late 'fifties we see the English word `homestead' ousting the colonial word `station.' <i>Ibid.</i> 12 . provisions became `rations' ... when served out to the man at the `shepherds' huts' (or out-stations). <i>(1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,11</i>)

## shick
 
 <i>adj.</i> occas. abbrev. of SHICKER n and aj., often applied as a friendly term of address; in mod. German slang and Yiddish [Same or other forms of the word were perhaps used much earlier than the 1890's in Austr and NZ (see <i>shickery</i>), and though Hebrew (? Yiddish) <i>Shikkur</i> is undoubtedly the source of the term (and cf variant spellings) there was probably some associative reinforcement from Eng. or Sc dialect shig, <i>shiggry</i> (see<i> shickery</i>). In September 1977 the word in its various forms was not known by a second-year tutorial at Victoria University of Wellington; nor by an immigrant from England of 12 years standing]

>  <b>H W ORSMAN</b> Hey, shick, stop guzzling. [co-offender to altar boy surreptitiously guzzling wine] <i>(1941,Personal Communication</i>) [NOTES: ca1941 St Patrick's College, Silverstream]

>  <b>LOCKWOOD</b> Yiddish became a main source of <i>Rotwelsch</i> [the cant language of thieves, etc.] In the course of time a number of originally cant words of Hebrew provenance passed into general use in German, though tending to remain at a more or less substandard level. Modern examples are colloquialisms like <i>acheln</i> eat, <i>Chuzpe</i> f. insolence, ... <i>mies</i> ugly, <i>Moos</i> n. money, <i>schicker </i>drunk, <i>schofel </i>trashy. These examples also occur in Standard Yiddish: <i>akhlen </i>(slang), <i>khutspe, ... mies, moes </i>(slang), <i>shiker, shofl. </i> <i>(1987,Informal History of the German Language, An,263</i>)

>  <b>ROSTEN</b> shikker Pronounced SHICK-er, to rhyme with `stick her'. Hebrew: <i>shikor</i>: `drunk1. A drunk. `He's a shikker.' 2. (Adjective) Drunk. `She got a wee bit<i> shikker</i>.' ... [349] <i>Shikkered</i>, to mean `drunk,' is commonly used in Australia [Wentworth and F 1960 p.466] How the word got all the way down to the Antipodes I do not know.] <i>(1971,Joys of Yiddish, The,348</i>)

## shilling
 
 <i>n.</i> to express a degree of intellectual or mental handicap, or eccentricity, on the part of the addressee on a rough scale based on 20 shillings = 1 pound; and graded from say 1/6 IN THE POUND, TWO SHILLINGS IN THE POUND (of low intelligence, highly eccentric) to say NINETEEN SHILLINGS (slightly abnormal or missing): PAY variant from horseracing betting the metaphor resembles those implying that the person is NOT ALL THERE, is MISSING see also BOB, QUID, SHILLING; small entry only at POUND (check)

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>shilling-a-month man</i> a remittance man, paid a shilling a month working his way on the ship out. The remittance man was often the black sheep of an English family, perhaps aristocratic, banished to a colony like New Zealand to live on a modest remittance from home. <i>(1888,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,100</i>)

>  <b>HOWE</b> [MR. A. said] `I don't believe he is the full shilling' meaning, `I don't believe he has good sense' <i>(1913,Travel Letters,112</i>) [NOTES: AC 1942]

 <i>n.</i> a piece of split (now also sawn) wood, usually rectangular used for roofing is general English (OED from 1200) but OED quotations (esp. in combinations) seem to have a provincial, and later a `colonial' flavour, although the sense does not occur in EDD. Certainly in early NZ, shingles were perhaps the commonest roofing material. British observers in the 19th century often feel obliged to explain the term. e.g.

>  <b>FORSTER</b> The latter [sc. argillaceous slate] is commonly found in great quantity, and broken pieces, on the sea beaches, and is what our seamen call shingle, by which name it is distinguished in the account of captain Cook's former voyage. <i>(1777,Voyage Round the World,1/204</i>)

## shingle slide
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a slip on a steep hill or mountain face covered with running angular pieces of rock.

>  Above me, before, slopes up for 1500ft the snow-bright shingle slide, the whiteness of the snow contrasting with the blackness of the stunted scrub on either hand. <i>(Oct 1, 1902,Otago Witness,32</i>)

>  Back on that first day mustering down to the hut, he got lost and tried to come down a shingle slide. <i>(Sep 1985,NZ Journal of Agriculture,43</i>)

>  <b>Relph</b> But, as a teenager employed at Lake Coleridge Station for the shearing, I had cause to be grateful for the presence of one of these shingle slides. <i>(2007,From Tussocks to Tourists,32</i>)

>  <b>THOMSON</b> Where bush and tussock had grown before, bare and barren shingle slides began to fan out. <i>Ibid.</i> 81 Higher up the valley it [the track] petered out completely for several miles, because of the many large shingle slides. <i>(1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,15</i>)

>  A term used in New Zealand for steep mountain sides covered with loose, sliding stones, in England called `screes' <i>(1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),365</i>)

>  The result is that the sides of the stream are merely shingle slides, and the former series of deep holes and strong ripples is merely a chain of shingle bars. <i>(Apr 21, 1928,Evening Post,17</i>)



## shingle slip
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a steep slide of running scree or loose stones [usually on high mountain or hill country. ]

>  <b>COCKAYNE</b> Shingle-slip, in its unstable typical form, is confined to those mountains of South Island with a tussock-grassland climate and is most strongly in evidence in the North-eastern and Eastern districts. <i>(1928,Vegetation of New Zealand, The,289</i>)

## shinplaster
 
 <i>n.</i> (See [see also Southland shinplasters](../S#see-also-southland-shinplasters))

>  Not Government debentures, as for those the sanction of the Governor would be required, but Government "shin plaisters." <i>(Apr 27, 1860,Daily Southern Cross,3</i>)

>  In Victoria in 1844, the only currency was a paper currency which was facetiously called a "shin plaster," and settlers were often put to queer straits in bartering and selling goods. <i>(Jul 16, 1884,Taranaki Herald,2</i>)

>  Votes of thanks were passed to Mr David Stevenson, Caversham, for promissory note by John Jones for GBP1, payable at Dunedin or Waikouaiti three days after date - those notes (sometimes called shin plasters) were in the form of a bank note, and were in circulation until January 2, 1857 ... <i>(Aug 5, 1908,Otago Witness,14</i>)

>  Depend upon it, fellow colonists, if they could not keep their mercurial fingers off the sacred fund of the widows and orphans, they will have small respect for those provisions of the Colonial Ordinance which professedly provide a security for the payment of the shin plasters. <i>(Jun 29, 1850,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,69</i>)

>  He hurled denunciations at the head of Sir John in particular, and the Stock Exchange in general, and in heroic language declared that New Zealand was a self-reliant, non-borrowing colony, and that Sir John and the Stock Exchange could depart for Sheol forthwith, and that he and Seddon and M'Kenzie could run the show by the aid of Consols, Postal notes, and shin plasters of a variety of patterns till further orders, and be d--d to him. <i>(Apr 19, 1895,Evening Post,4</i>)

>  A feature of the exhibit is a number of debentures or "shin plasters" as they were irreverently termed, which were put into circulation during the term of the governorship of Captain Fitzroy... The Government debentures were for 5s, but the private ones were for sums ranging down as low as 3d. <i>(Feb 20, 1890,Otago Daily Times,17</i>)

>  But these war advances we got from J.B. were, perhaps, part of the shin plaster J.B. borrowed from Uncle Sam, and Downie Stewart may have learned from U.S.'s pawnbrokers exactly how England funded her huge war debt with them. <i>(Jun 27, 1925,NZ Truth,5</i>)

>  And Sir Samuel/Hoare - he goes / With shin plaster / On his nose ... <i>(Dec 18, 1935,Evening Post,8</i>)

>  <b>JOSEPH MASTERS</b> Many tradesmen [in the early 1840s] had to make their own money on strips of paper called by the settlers `shin plaisters'. Governor Grey [sic] established a bank issue and issued one pound promisery [sic] notes, to get change for one of these, you would get a hat full of shin plaisters. <i>(1871,Autobiography,26</i>)

>  <b>MACDONALD</b> I do not know exactly how wholesale mercantile business was carried on, but the retail business in the town [?Wellington] was carried on [c1840s] mostly by means of little bits of printed paper, issued by shopkeepers, for from one penny to two or three shillings. This currency went by the general name of `shin plaster'. <i>Ibid.</i> 117 When eggs fell from six silver shillings per dozen to one shilling of `shin plasters', the Hutt, Porirua Road and Karori settlers looked anxious. <i>(1910,Reminiscences,109</i>) [NOTES: c1840s in c1910 Macdonald Reminiscences (TS:VUW) 109]

>  <b>SUTHERLAND</b> <i>Shinplasters</i>.- The fact that private traders found it necessary themselves, to issue paper notes in denominations below five shillings suggests that at the outset ... the Fitzroy notes were not issued for values below five shillings. The private paper notes were issued for small change, redeemable mostly in `Five Shillings, in Government debentures.' Both the debentures and the private notes were issued on poor paper, and soon became known as `Government Rags' and `Shinplasters' respectively. The term `Shinplaster' for paper money appears to have come to New Zealand from America, via New South Wales. *[fn] In the latter Colony the issue of paper money of a denomination lower than twenty shillings was prohibited in 1826 to promote the circulation of sterling instead of a colonial currency, and the prohibition was welcomed by the people as `preventing the Colony being inundated with beggarly rags' and dollar and half-dollar notes `used often as a paltry contrivance to evade payment of debt,' <i>vide "The Australian," </i>19 July 1826. [fn] Various reasons have been given for the origin of this curious term for paper money issued in the forties. The most likely explanation comes from America (p. 650 <i>The Numismatist,</i> 1938), where it is stated that in the good old days post-boys and out-riders, wearing high boots, were required, at times, to pay toll-fees at toll-gates, and in order to facilitate progress they placed paper money or coins in bags in their boot-tops, against their shins - hence the term `shin-plaster.' <i>(1941,Numismatic History of NZ,158</i>)

>  <b>HARGREAVES</b> The [Governor Fitzroy's (1844)] Debentures, popularly known as `government rags', were given various nicknames such as<i> assignats,</i> `shinplasters', and `flash notes'. All these terms had reference to worthless paper money, some of which had been issued in the past. <i>Assignats</i> was the name given to large amounts of paper money issued in France during the French Revolution, but which depreciated to such as extent to be almost worthless. `Shinplasters' - sometimes written `skinplasters' - had its origin in North America, and again referred to depreciated paper money, while `flash notes' was a popular term in use for any counterfeit money or worthless forged paper money. <i>(1972,From Beads to Banknotes,40</i>)

## shooter
 
 <i>n.</i> a marble

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies. <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,174</i>)

>  <i>Shout, n.</i> to stand treat. (1) Of drink. (2) By transference, of other things. The successful digger used to <i>call</i> passers-by to drink at his expense. The origin may also be from noisy bar-rooms, or crowded bar-parlours, where the man who was to pay for the liquor or refreshment called or <i>shouted</i> for the waiter or barman. When many men drink together the waiter of course looks for payment for the man who first calls or shouts out for him to give him the order. Or is `pay the shout' a variant of `pay the shot,' or tavern reckoning? In its first sense the word has reached the United States, and is freely employed there. [1859] <i>(1898,Austral English,416</i>)

## sick
 
 <i>adj.</i>

>  Various chemical modes of cleansing have been tried with only partial success, but recently it was accidentally discovered that a current of electricity would almost immediately expel the troublesome impurities, no matter how abundant or how "sick" the mercury had been rendered. ..With the current flowing, the mercury could not be made sick. <i>(Nov 5, 1883,Evening Post,2</i>)

>  This sick mercury also powders away, or as it is termed "flours," so that the floured fluid metal is carried away and lost, leaving fresh surfaces to be attacked by the injurious ingredients in the ore. <i>(Mar 20, 1890,Otago Witness,12</i>)

>  <b>MAY</b> The mercury plates were seldom perfect: the finest gold was lost by flotation while with cemented gold a thin coating of iron oxide (`rusty gold') often prevented amalgamation. The mercury itself became `sick' or `floured'; both sodium and nitric acid were employed to improve its amalgamating qualities. <i>Ibid.</i> 527 FLOURED MERCURY: mercury that has lost its amalgamating properties because of impurities in the ore or the wash. The mercury is then `sick'. <i>(1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,238</i>)



 
 <i>adj.</i>

>  ... those in the `bush sick' area were inspected and a dozen found to have died ... the herbage grown on the so-called sick country.' <i>Ibid.</i> 40 ... periodical changing of the stock from `sick' to what is known to be `healthy' country every few months. <i>(1928,TrNZI,58/39</i>) [NOTES: (Aston)]

>  [caption] Second crop of lambs from ewes confined to sick paddock, Sherry River. <i>(1938,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,20/195A</i>)



 
 <i>adj.</i> NZ colloquial usage follows US and earlier British usage in assigning a main sense of `ill, unwell, ailing' to this word, esp. in the phrase <i>be sick </i>; contrast modern British usage with main sense `vomit'. That is, NZ usage follows OED a. I 1. Suffering from illness of any kind; ill, unwell, ailing. Now chiefly literary and U.S. [9-19c]. rather than 2. Having an inclination to vomit, or being actually in the condition of vomiting [18-20c]. An ambiguous statement, e.g., `I was sick on Thursday' would usually be interpreted in NZ as `I was ill' etc; in Britain probably as `I vomited etc' (Dr. R. Savage); and this can lead to some immediately horrifying images for Englishmen in N.Z., needing quick reshuffling to extract the correct sense: e.g., I was sick in bed last Thursday. Unambiguous statements naturally assign themselves appropriate senses, mainly on aspectual grounds: I was sick twice before breakfast; I have been sick for months. `Ill' is often used in NZ by, e.g. mothers and nurses, as a euphemism for the `vomit' sense: Little Tommy has just been ill all over his shoes. (When used as a verb, sick is always `vomit': N.Coghill and C. Tolkien have an interesting note to l.71 of their edition of Chaucer's <i>The Nun's Priest's Tale </i> (Harrap pp 94-5). l. 71 Repleccioun [overeating] re made hire nevere sick `sick': `ill', not `sick'. The withering away of the old sense of sick is relatively recent, and has not taken place in America; cf also <i>sickbay, sickroom, a sick man,</i> etc. Chaucer knew the word <i>ill, but for him it was a word characteristic of the North and East of England (it was of Scandinavian origin), and he only used it to give an impression of dialect in the talk of John and Aleyn, the Two Cambridge students from the North of England in the Reeve's Tale; for them, in any case, it meant `bad, evil'. Chaucer's word for being sick (in our sense) was <i>spew</i>.'

>  <b>MARSH</b> ... and I must say he did look a bit sick. <i>(1937,Vintage Murder,96</i>)

>  <b>M.E. ALCOCK</b> I list below the words I can think of [as having different meanings in Britain and NZ]: <i>N.Z. English </i> Singlet Vest Sick Sick in England means to vomit.) <i>(Dec 3, 1957,Letter</i>)

## sickle-fibre
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) an unusual wool-fibre in the birthcoat of Romney lambs, similar to halo-hairs.

>  Shedding is common among hairy sickle-fibres; sometimes all are shed, while occasionally, at the other extreme, all persist, every intermediate condition being found. Many of these fibres are much shorter than any shed hairy sickle-fibres. <i>(Jan 20, 1933,NZ Journal of Agriculture,13</i>)

>  When a name for these intermediates is needed, the term "super-sickle" is used. <i>(Mar 20, 1933,NZ Journal of Agriculture,141</i>)

>  Fibres of this kind that do not grow after birth are called "baby sickle-fibres." <i>(Mar 20, 1933,NZ Journal of Agriculture,144</i>)

>  Other somewhat longer sickle-fibres, it would appear from their length, are shed after growing for just a short time after birth. These are termed "infant sickle-fibres" (Fig 4). Infant sickle-fibres are much less abundant than baby ones. Most sickle-fibres with coarse medulla in the post-natal region sustain this up to some eight weeks after birth. For these it is convenient to use the term "chalky sickle-fibres," from their dull white appearance. Super-sickle-fibres, some with a good deal of medulla in the neck, occasionally remain fine after birth ... <i>(Mar 20, 1933,NZ Journal of Agriculture,145</i>)

>  The stoutest of birthcoat fibres, halo-hairs, are almost all shed and the super-sickle-fibres with necks coarser than those of sickle-fibres, shed the more readily. <i>(Jun 20, 1934,NZ Journal of Agriculture,342</i>)

## sidle
 
 <i>n.</i> an act of sidling; a track that runs at an angle across a slope. [ca1953 R. Mason e.g. make a high sidle to avoid the bluffs, or a broken ridge.]

>  <b>PASCOE</b> When the Whitcombe River is in flood there are many such whirlpools which the usual route avoids by a high steep sidle in the thick bush. <i>(1960,Over the Whitcombe Pass,33fn</i>) [NOTES: 1863 Lauper in 1960 Pascoe (ed) Over the Whitcombe Pass 33 fn]

>  <b>LAUPER</b> [Note]. There are many such whirlpools which the usual route avoids by a high steep sidle in the thick bush. <i>(1863,Over the Whitcombe Pass</i>) [NOTES: The footnote is a 1960 one by Pascoe.]

>  Near the head of the creek, the track climbs over a saddle of regenerating forest to begin a sidle towards Kaitoke... <i>(2008,NZ Geographic,94/30</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to negotiable a steep slope of a hill by going round the side of it rather than straight up to the crest. (probably a back form from SIDELING.)

>  To <i>sidle </i>, to go around the side or across the face of a hill, is a characteristic New Zealand expression, strange to the Englishman or Australian. The example of 1821 in O.E.D.: `Ye know the footpath sidles down the hill', suggests that something of the New Zealand meaning was not unknown in England, but it cannot have been well known, or mountaineers would not have started to use <i>traverse </i>, both as a noun and as a verb, towards the end of last century. <i>Sidle </i> is well known among high-country musterers. As it is a word most likely to be used in open hilly or mountainous country, one may guess that musterers and up-country people gave it currency, whence it was adopted by mountain club people. If ski-ing had not brought its more or less international vocabulary with it we should no doubt be sidling slopes, on skis, that we now traverse... From 1936 to 1938 in <i>The Tramper </i> there are a number of references to `sidling tracks' and `sidling routes'. Towards the end of 1938 comes `after sidling round the head of the said stream', and, a year later, `we sidle the top of Three Johns', and from then on the verb flourishes. In 1940 comes `on a long sidle', and from then on the noun is as common as the verb. <i>Ibid.</i> 41 From the top basin we sidled up tiresome scree, ... and at last emerged on the top of the divide. <i>(Sep 1958,Tararua,29</i>) [NOTES: Ruth Mason `Track and Trail']

>  Often, with back bent low, he must thread [sic] the dirty overgrown bed of a steep little watercourse, or, still with back bent, sidle along the muddy slope of a steep hill, through a tunnel in the koromiko copse; or, straightening his back with a sigh of relief as he emerges on the open shingle-bed, find that he has to ford and ford again and again the cold rapid stream, slipping ahd splashing over weed-covered stones. <i>(Aug 18, 1862,Daily Southern Cross,3</i>)

>  A few blows with the tomahawk, a fire-stick judiciously employed, and, should the brook be high, a little sidling over a low bank or two, is the most that can be needed, though the gorge being very narrow, its aspect may at first appear discouraging for a mile or two. <i>(Jun 2, 1855,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,2</i>)

>  We sidled along the spurs, slipping and stumbling over the steep, wet, frozen, stony ground, for three of four miles, which seemed interminable, there the river Mataura approaches the hills, and made our course more westerly; a little further on we crossed the Otamita, a mountain stream, that came rushing out from between the hills, with a clear stony bottom. <i>(Oct 3, 1894,North Otago Times,1</i>)

>  Come and let us sidle up thes bonnie brae and ha'e a look roond. <i>(Sep 6, 1905,Otago Witness,86</i>)

>  Come and let us sidle up this bonnie brae and ha'e a look roond. <i>(Sep 6, 1905,Otago Witness,86</i>)

>  <b>BLAIR</b> There was heavy snow as we sidled along above Bealey gully. ... and carelessly sticking to the ridge I carelessly continued sidling. <i>(1956,Life & Work at Canterbury Agricultural College,83</i>) [NOTES: (1926 Hilgendorf in) 1956 Blair Life and Work at Canterbury Agricultural College 83]

>  To work one's way round, up or down a facing by an easy grade. Usually sidle out, sidle round etc. <i>(1933,Press, The</i>) [NOTES: Acland]

>  <b>JONES</b> .... sheer precipice for thousands of feet. One could not sidle round in mustering, but had to go under or over the top. <i>(1933,Autobiography,82</i>)

>  <i>Sidle </i>.-To work one's way round, up, or down a facing by an easy grade. Usually <i>s. out, s. round,</i> etc <i>(Jan 27, 1934,Press, The,15</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Sidling to a handy shoulder, he scanned the basin ahead. <i>(1949,High Alps of NZ,30</i>)

>  <i>(Oct 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,295/1</i>)

>  <b>THOMPSON</b> We then sidled for a few miles on a slight uphill grade until we reached a long sloping spur. 1952 <i>Ibid</i>. 55 ... Errol and I ... then sidled round the cliffs until we reached the basin at the head of the stream. <i>(1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,42</i>)

>  <b>R. MASON</b> `To go around the side of; to go along a hill-side. (tramping.) To sidle a hill; to sidle along a valley (not on the ridge, not on the valley floor, but along the hillside.) In common use among trampers. The term was not understood by Dr. I.V. Newman, lecturer in Botany, V.U.C., an Australian.' <i>(1953,Personal Communication</i>)

>  <b>STRONACH</b> Most of the Clarence block is `sidled'. That is to say, the spurs are so big that it is necessary to have several men sidling on the `face' or side of each spur. I have seen as many as ten men on a face sidling along about half a mile apart. The man on the top beat, in all but exceptional circumstances, keeps a little in front, and each man down the face is a little behind the man above. <i>(1953,Musterer on Molesworth,23</i>)

>  <b>SUTHERLAND</b> The ceiling of mist was above us when we gained the range beyond the razorback and sidled to a saddle we could see a mile to the south. <i>(1953,Golden Bush, The,168,1963 ed.</i>)

>  <i>(1958,Tararua,12/29</i>)

>  At the first bluff he [a tramper] sidled up the spur but he got off the discs and had to bash through the lawyers and windfalls. <i>(Apr 19, 1971,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56</i>)

## signal man
 
 <i>n.</i> (See [cf. look-out](../L#look-out))

>  <b>SHORTLAND</b> While passing in front of a hut [at the whaling station], I was invited to visit a sailor who lived within, and who had had a bad leg for many years, which rendered him unfit for any other work than that of signal man. While the rest of his companions were actively engaged in the boats, he was carried every day during the season to the summit of the most projecting point of the cliff, where he sat under a shed, glass in hand, to look out for whales. By means of a mast and yard, and some signals, he was able to give notice to the boats in whatever direction he discovered a whale; and so earned a small share in the fortunes of the fishery. <i>(1851,Southern Districts of NZ,129</i>)

## six o'clock swill
 
 <i>n.</i> a popular name for the 5-6 p.m. drinking rush during the six o'clock closing of bars before 9 October 1967 [[AND see SWILL: six o'clock swill 1955]]

>  I also worked in the Great Northern Hotel in the days of the six o'clock swill - everybody was paralytic at six. <i>(Jun 1999,Metro,56</i>)

>  Sir, - Like the great majority of New Zealanders who finish work at 5 or 5.30 p.m. I like two or three beers and a chat to my friends before I go home for dinner. That is when I feel like a drink, and when I enjoy it. They call it the `six o'clock swill,' but we enjoy it. After all, when service is required by so many at the same time, there must be a crush. <i>(Aug 13, 1963,Dominion,4</i>)

>  New Zealander's liquor hours, notably the `five to six swill' produced gusty debate and plenty of laughs at the National Party Conference yesterday. <i>(Jul 23, 1963,Dominion,1</i>)

>  <b>TURNER</b> This gives in New Zealand the terms <i>vertical drinking </i>(in crowded bars with standing room only), <i>the six o'clock swill</i> and, at least among students in Wellington about 1940, the <i>shicker express</i>, the first tram after six o' clock ... <i>(1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,131</i>)

>  The rich linguistic legacy of the election rituals would draw thousands. Coaches would tour vivid re-enactments of the six o'clock swill, staged by Richard Campion and choreographed after extensive interviews with the survivors.[check with MITCHELL cit???] <i>(Jun 25, 1972,Sunday Times (NZ),35/2</i>)

>  <b>MITCHELL</b> Coaches would tour vivid re-enactments of the six o'clock swill ... . <i>(1972,Half-Gallon Quarter-Acre Pavlova Paradise, The,14</i>)

>  <b>GEBBIE & McGREGOR</b> We had knocked off one Thursday night after [47] the six o'clock swill and were having a drink in the upstairs bar about nine o'clock ... <i>(1979,Incredible 8-Ounce Dream,46</i>)

>  <b>LELAND</b> <i>six o'clock swill</i>: Prior to 9 October 1967, bars in New Zealand had to close at 6.00p.m. (now they close at 10.00p.m., often 12.00p.m. ..) on weekends. <i>(1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,92</i>)

>  <i>Wellington</i> New Zealanders will choose in a referendum later this year between their notorious 6 o'clock swill and a more civilized style of drinking liquor. .. Paradoxically, the appalling conditions of the 5-to-6-o'clock swill have strengthened the opponents of reform. <i>(Jun 29, 1967,San Francisco Chronicle,4</i>) [NOTES: 1967 July 29 Ian Templeton in San Francisco Chronicle 4]

>  <b>HOLCROFT</b> We were then .. in the heyday of the six o'clock swill, an institution so notorious that visiting Americans .. were taken to selected hotels to see for themselves an operation otherwise unbelievable. <i>(1986,Sea of Words,9</i>)

>  <i>six o'clock swill NZ & Austral. colloq.</i> (formerly) period of rapid consumption of alcoholic drinks immediately before six o'clock closing-time of bars. <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,717</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

>  `Privatisation', `Corporatisation' and `market-driven forces' are now as common in our vocabulary as the `six o'clock swill' and `Don Clarke' was to our forebears. <i>(Sep 21, 1987,Salient,5</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>six o'clock swill </i> rapid male drinking in male-only public bars in the lead-up to 6 pm pub closing time, usually from end of work at 5 pm. Perceived as piggish and the closest we got to a direct connection between beer hoses and customers. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,103</i>)

>  Though the six o'clock swill ceased in 1967 .. there was still a powerful linkage between drinking beer and masculinity. <i>(Mar 13, 1988,Dominion Sunday Times,16</i>)

>  We introduced daylight saving time when it suited us, abolished the six o'clock swill and have reshaped the school year into four terms. <i>(Feb 22, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7</i>)

>  They have become booze barns run by a private company which is still in the six o 'clock swill mode . <i>(Jan 20, 1993,Independent Herald (Wellington),1</i>)

>  Maybe one day we'll look back on Sunday closure with the same amazement with which we now view the six o'clock swill, but surely never with the same horror. <i>(Aug 13, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15</i>)

>  <b>GOLDSMITH</b> These establishments [sc. illegal beer houses] catered for those who wanted to drink past the '6 o'clock swill'. <i>(1997,John Banks : A Biography,40</i>)

>  <b>Michael King</b> With the abolition of six o'clock closing of hotel bars in 1967 and an eventual relaxation of restaurant licensing laws, alcohol became available at more civilised hours and in more civilised circumstances than in the days of the 'six o'clock swill'. <i>(2003,Penguin History of New Zealand,389</i>)

>  The teen-age binge-drinking so evident at the New Year is part of a New Zealand tradition that goes right back to the six o'clock swill, known affectionately as the six o'clock spill. <i>(Feb 10, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32</i>)

>  For husbands, release from their emotional repression came only with the "six o'clock swill" at the pub or Saturdays at the footy. <i>(Sep 19, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),31</i>)

>  In the dim glow of yellow lights, you can smell again the perpetually beer-soaked carpets of the six o'clock swill and consider that you are just another battery hen queueing for a fix. <i>(Apr 8, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),52</i>)

>  When licensing laws were relaxed in 1989, and again in 1999, to allow the sale of alcohol in supermarkets and, it turns out, dairies, the changes were supposed to reflect a new, more mature, attitude to drinking. Unfortunately, the attitude of some is unchanged from the days of the 6 o'clock swill; they just don't have to travel as far to buy alcohol. <i>(May 4, 2009,Dominion Post,B4</i>) [NOTES: Editorial]

>  This hurried hour of drinking between 5 and 6 was known as 'the 6 o'clock swill' and the decibels spilling out of the public bar onto the streets got louder and louder as six o'clock approached. <i>(Jun 2004,NZ Memories,No. 48/6</i>)

>  Those were the days of six o'clock swill, when alcohol could not be sold after 6pm and only hotels could operate bottle stores. <i>(Apr 23, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14</i>)

>  <b>WOLFE</b> And so 6 o'clock closing - or the '6 o'clock swill' as it became known - was enforced. <i>(1991,Kiwi,54</i>)

>  For half a century, from 1917 to 1967, the six o'clock swill artificially prolonged the rough male pioneering culture, according to historian Jock Phillips, in his book <i>A Man's Country</i>. <i>(Sep 18, 2010,Your Weekend,9</i>)

>  There's nothing at all to compare with the thrillOf Kiwis unleashed at the six o'clock swill...Oh, the pleasure or rushing to get a new fillIn the sardine-like squeeze of the six o'clock swill. <i>(1964,Matamata District Chronicle,[10]</i>) [NOTES: From a poem by someone called John Reid]

>  These are philosophical matters which could well have been aired had the 25th anniversary of the end of the 6 o'clock swill been properly respected. <i>(Oct 17, 1992,Evening Post,8</i>)

>  <b>BOLLINGER</b> After the Second World War, a returned serviceman termed it the '5 to 6 o'clock swill'. <i>(1959,Grog's Own Country,4</i>)

>  I have some wonderment as to whether we may not have transferred that peculiar New Zealand phenomenon, the 6 o'clock swill, into the 10 o'clock brawl. <i>(1976,NZ Parliamentary Debates,407 : 3569</i>)

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a section of a woolshed where sheep are kept under cover.

>  He looked into his woolshed and said, 'Oh yes, there's plenty of room in the skillions.' [skilion] <i>(Dec 2, 1933,Press, The  (Acland Glossary),15</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> (obsolete) (in pl.)

>  <b>BUTLER</b> The wool-shed .... has a large central space, and an aisle-like partition on each side. These last will be for holding the sheep at night. ... In a wool-shed, the aisles would be called skilions (whence the name is derived, I know not, nor whether it has two `l's' in it or one). All the sheep go into the skillions <k>Ibid.</i> x/158 In a wool-shed the aisles would be called skilions (whence the word is derived I know not, nor whether it has two l's in it or one). All the sheep go into the skilions. The shearers shear in the centre ... [and] pull the sheep out of the skilions as they want them. <i>(1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,139</i>)

>  <b>BARKER</b> ... a constant succession of woolly sheep being brought up to fill the `skillions' (from whence the shearers take them when they want them), and the newly-shorn ones ... being turned out after they have passed through a narrow passage, called a `race,' where each sheep is branded ... <i>(1865,Station Life in NZ,34,1870 ed.</i>)

>  <i>Skillion</i>.- [Variant of 'skillin' and skilling', recorded from the fourteenth century, all late examples being provincial English; origin unknown. --A.W.] In old Australian and New Zealand books (up to about 1880) it is common and means the sheep-holding part of a woolshed. I can remenber an old hand mentioning the word in the 'nineties. I have tried it on several elderly shepherds since the war I and none of them understood it. I imagined the word had gone completely out of use until last month (May 1933), when I bought five tons of chaff from a man and asked him to store it for a few weeks. He looked into his woolshed and said, `Oh yes, there's plenty of room in the skillions.' I felt as if I had met a notornis. ' . . called skillions (whence the name is derived I know not, nor whether it has two l's in it or one). All the sheep go into the skilions.' (Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p. 139). `A constant succession of woolly sheep being brought up to fill the skillions.' ([1874 Lady Barker Station Life], p. 34). <i>(Dec 2, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

## slather
 
 <i>v.</i> box, fight, do battle (See [slather n](../S#slather-n))

>  On the 28th of this month, Gisborne stoush lovers will have another bonzer night, when the Gisborne Association will bring Bert Lowe and Bill Bartlett together. These two are scheduled to slather for fifteen rounds, but this is not going to be nearly all the fun. Viv Lowe and Poesy will try to deal out oblivion to each other during six rounds, while Mellow and Heany and also Harrison and Frurie will put up their 'dukes'. <i>(May 23, 1914,NZ Truth,6</i>)

 <i>n.</i> vigorous 'unscientific' fighting; unrestrained toe-to-toe boxing action [from the idea of slathering or plastering blows on one's opponent (often in the collocation 'slather and whack'); see OED slather sense 3 to thrash, defeat thoroughly; see also open slather; compare slather-up n.]

>  [In the last round they both tired visibly, and casting caution to the winds slathered each other.] ... A wild slather ended when Finnie missed with a left and came in with his head low, owing to the impetus. ... Early in the round, Bennetts emerged from a slather, shaking his head and seemed to forget all about his opponent. <i>(Aug 1, 1914,NZ Truth,12</i>)

>  Then both warriors made a speech, which was lost amid the roar. It was a great slather and whack fight. There is no gainsaying Grim's pluck and ability to take punishment. But there is a big chunk of his reputation gone now that Griffin dropped him. <i>(Dec 12, 1908,NZ Truth,3</i>)

>  Chris. Rusterholz (8.5) versus Cliff Pearce (7.12). This was the tit-bit of the evening and provided five rounds of ding dong slather of a high order. Both are quick two-handed fighters and they went at it hammer and tacks without a dull moment intervening. <i>(Mar 4, 1922,NZ Truth,8</i>)

>  The feathers, J. Whittome (8.7) and C. McCarthy (8.5), followed, and they gave a clean, clever exhibition, more like a professional bout than that of amateurs. There was none of that wild slather, but good, scientific punching throughout. <i>(Dec 24, 1921,NZ Truth,8</i>)

>  Seldom indeed has a crowd voiced its approval of an out-and-out boxing match as it did at Wellington last week. Scientific stuff nine times out of ten leaves the audience cold - it is the slather and whack artists that get 'em on their feet, yelling encouragement. But the exception was bumped into last week when Jack Carroll gained a points decision over Charlie Purdy. Carroll came to us with a reputation of a bit of a killer, but his first fight in Wellington showed he was more of a stylist. He showed up as a nice mover, possessing plenty of speed at both ends, but totally lacking as a purveyor of hefty wallops. <i>(Aug 16, 1928,NZ Truth,10</i>)

>  BOXING AT GREYMOUTH. ...Now, when the time is ripe, it might be mentioned that Cook's exhibition throughout the mill, his genuine smile of good fellowship when picking up his opponent on a couple of occasions when he slipped, and his palpable desire to box instead of indulging in 'slather and whack', bears the impression that when his recent mill with Billy Hannan at Gisborne was declared 'no fight' and he lost his share of the purse, there was some truth in his words, 'I don't profess to be a fighter; I'm a boxer, pure and simple, and I tried my hardest to beat Hannan.' <i>(Mar 28, 1914,NZ Truth,6</i>)

## slew
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) an angle left or right that sheep take when they are responding to a dog's direction to change course.

>  Went clean through first flags without trouble and put in a good clean slew, which landed his sheep across the creek. Made a poor slew at the first flags ... <i>(Sep 1, 1925,NZ Farmer,1343</i>)

>  Slew - the angles - left or right - of a hunt and the new direction sheep take when directed to by a dog. <i>(Dec 15, 1983,NZ Journal of Agriculture,45</i>)

>  <b>GORDON</b> By this time, the sheep would be finishing the first set and a right-hand slew had to be applied to line them up for the second set. <i>(1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,151</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [shepherding] to direct sheep in a particular direction.

>  This dog's sheep drifted through first flags, with the dog not interested, but he slewed nicely and he crossed the creek with firm work. <i>(Sep 1, 1925,NZ Farmer,1343</i>)

>  if the driving was done by a huntaway dog, slewing the sheep would be in order. <i>(May 1933,NZ Farmer,317</i>)

>  <b>ACLAND</b> .. if you slewed a mob of strong merino wethers too hard against a fence, the fence went flat. <i>(1946,Early Canterbury Runs,40</i>)

>  <b>HARTLEY</b> The next lesson is devised to teach a dog in advance how to slew sheep. <i>(1949,Shepherd's Dogs, The,17</i>)

>  The 'Lake' country is mainly open shingle and it's mostly 'topside' work - slewing sheep downhill. <i>(Apr 11, 1968,NZ Farmer,45</i>)

>  <b>MCLEOD</b> Wait would head or hunt or slew with uncanny intelligence. <i>(1970,Many a Glorious Morning,142</i>)

>  <b>KERR</b> Otairi's huntaways were used to lifting sheep; mine to slewing from above. <i>(2000,High Times in the High Country,173</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to beat, outwit, baffle [SOED labels Aust. & NZ]

>  <b>PYKE</b> Of their reputation, the miners spoke with bated breath; ... The general impression seemed to be, that Jack Ketch had been `slued' (<i>anglice</i> - robbed of his dues) by the trio. <i>(1873,Wild Will Enderby,1/xi/41,(1889,1974) ed.</i>)

>  In London the peelers down areas will go, / To make love to the cook and the victuals, /But here there're no areas down which to intrude, / So of course the New Zealand bobbies are slewed. <i>(1875,NZ Songster,No.3/89</i>) [NOTES: Thatcher London and the Diggings]

>  <b>MITCHELL</b> ... or levant from Oamaru/ Without bidding them adieu/ And the merchants we will slew - let them catch us if they can. <i>(1889,Rhymes and Rambles,25</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  "This Scott seems a nice, steady-going sort of a dog. That was a nice slew he made had it been in the right place." <i>(Jun 3, 1897,Otago Witness,34</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> He [a sheep dog] was so fast that I'd have him away out, past, and beyond any sheep almost before they knew he was coming. In this way I could get in good slews ... <i>Ibid.</i> 169 <i>Slew</i>: To turn or change the direction in which sheep are travelling. To top-side slew is to turn or hunt them downhill. Slewing is done mainly with huntaways and in one of the huntaways events at our trials - Class III - the sheep are hunted on a zig-zag course. This is often called a slew. <i>(1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,26</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i>

>  T. Prendergast's Tom hunted his sheep out well about 300yds and slewed to the right, but failed to slew to the left. <i>(Jun 1, 1893,Otago Witness,21</i>)

>  The dog had to head sheep, slew them, drive them a short distance along a ridge, and then pull to ring. <i>(Apr 15, 1910,Hawera & Normanby Star,7</i>)

>  In class 3 Mr Reg. Black's Niss worked steadily in the hunt away, slewing well, was under good command, brought back in good style but should have been steadied more. <i>(Jul 23, 1907,Taranaki Herald,8</i>)

>  <b>ACLAND</b> .. When a dog heads or slews sheep, shepherds speak of his having done a good (etc.) <i>turn</i>. <i>(1933,Sheep Station</i>)

>  <i>Sheep dog</i>.- Dog to work sheep; <i>collie</i> (q.v.). <i>S.ds</i>. run naturally either to bring sheep towards you or to drive them away; and when a puppy shows his preference he is broken in for that work. The dogs that bring sheep are called <i>heading ds.</i> (q.v.) and most of these can be taught to<i> lead </i>(q.v.) if desired. Dogs which take to driving sheep away are broken in to<i> huntaway</i> and are called <i>htwys</i> (q.v.). Some dogs will both <i>hd</i>. and <i>htwy</i> and are called <i>handy ds.</i> They are not generally high-class heading dogs but very useful about hand and sometimes very useful mustering dogs. Some men have a special<i> slewing d.</i>, but a well-trained, <i>hdg</i>. dog or <i>htwy</i>. will usually <i>slew </i>(q.v.). (C.) <i>(Nov 25, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>CRAWFORD</b> If you `slewed' a mob of strong merino wethers ... <i>(1949,Sheep and Sheepmen of Canterbury,40</i>)

>  <b>HARTLEY</b> <i>Teaching Slewing</i> The next lesson is devised to teach a dog ... to slew sheep. <i>(1949,Shepherd's Dogs, The,17</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> <i>Slew</i>: To slew sheep is to turn them in a different direction to that in which they are going. If sheep are sidling round a face and they have to be turned downhill a dog is run out and above them to `slew' them down. <i>(1966,Boss's Story, The,190</i>)

>  <b>McLEOD</b> <i>Slew:</i> A huntaway should be able to cast to the side on command and slew in the desired direction. <i>(1970,Glorious Morning,253</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> A mob of those wethers, slewed out of a high basin, would disappear down a spur in a cloud of dust ... <i>Ibid.</i> 169 <i>Slew</i>: To turn or change the direction in which sheep are travelling. To top-side slew is to turn or hunt them downhill. Slewing is done mainly with huntaways and in one of the huntaways events at our trials - Class III - the sheep are hunted on a zig-zag course. This is often called a slew. <i>(1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,15</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>v.</i> to defeat, overcome, get round (a problem)

## slush lamp
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [used elsewhere but recorded earliest in NZ] a basic light source, being a tin filled with fat in which a wick is placed.

>  <b>WOODHOUSE</b> Then 'twas 'Get the slush-lamp, quick!' <i>(1905,Farm & Station Verse,53</i>) [NOTES: Poem by Baughan in 1967 edition]

>  In other times he used a slush lamp for artificial light. <i>(Oct 14, 1953,NZ Observer,16</i>)

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> Presumably before this.. the hut had been lit with that abomination of pioneer life - a slush lamp. <i>(1947,Early Runholding in Otago,112</i>)

>  The slush lamp was alight when found by the police. <i>(May 18, 1936,Evening Post,11</i>)

This consists of an old pannikin about three parts filled with clay, and the other part with tallow, in the middle of which is a small piece of rag of some sort (cotton, of course) sticking out of the fat about a quarter of an inch. The rag is lit with a match or a stick from the fire; the wick is fed by the surrounding fat, and the surrounding darkness is made visible. <i>(1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,30,1935 ed.</i>) [NOTES: 1872 Oct in c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 30]

Inst., vol. 2, pp.84 to 87, 1870] by the name of `smelt, Galaxias fasciatus'; but his three figures undoubtedly illustrate three stages of growth of the fish, Galaxias attenuatus. <i>Ibid.</i> 54 In some other localities these young [smelt, <i>Retropinna </i>] are called tuarenga. ## smokies
 
 <i>n.</i> opaque brown and grey marbles; also called OYSTERS [OED[S] check [1945 Baker Aust. Lay. 204 ca1950's Naenae, Wellington (p.c. G. Kennedy)]

>  <b>de MAUNAY</b> Once he gave him a bag of marbles, good ones, too, "smokies", not the useless little clay things. <i>(1949,Huntsman in His Career, The,136</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies. <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,174</i>)

>  <b>KEITH & MAIN</b> Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, [sic] chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles. <i>(1984,NZ Yesterdays,288</i>)

>  <b>HALL</b> The man on the bottom beat got into trouble. Some sheep had been smothered through a bit of poor shepherding ... <i>(1987,Shepherd's Year, A,84</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> see cit. 1933

>  There were <i>only ten</i> sheep smothered during the day. <i>(Mar 1, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2</i>)

>  <b>FORD</b> Aitken left a mob of sheep run [on] a wrong spur and smothered a large number ... [sic] <i>(Jan 10, 1867,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1867 Jan 10 Ford Diary in 1981 Crawford Station Years 181]

>  <b>OGONOWSKA-COATES</b> <i>Smother </i>. If the pens in a woolshed are filled too tight sheep may smother during the night. Sheep are kept in the pens overnight before they are shorn. <i>(1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,97</i>)

>  <i>Smother.</i>- Run sheep especially merinos, are very easy to s. on broken hill ground. An injudicious turn with a dog in an abrupt gully may stop the lead and cause some sheep to be knocked over. Other sheep make a rush and are brought down too, so that in a second or two there is struggling heap; and before the shepherd can pull them off one another the bottom ones are <i>smothered </i>. They <i> sd.</i> 1200 once on the Stew Point country at Mount Peel, and I believe there was a still worse <i> s </i>. on a station called Roxburgh in Otago. People who fill their woolsheds too tight often <i>smother </i> sheep on a smaller scale: perhaps half a dozen or so in a night. (C.) <i>(Dec 2, 1933,Press, The</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>BURDON</b> Difficulties arose only when they started to go in the wrong direction and had to be stopped, or when a large mob was in hand and a steep, narrow gully had to be crossed; then there was always the danger of a `smother.' Of all breeds the Merino is the easiest to smother, for he moves freer, faster, and more recklessly than any other. If pressed or carelessly handled, some of the leaders may fall or be knocked over and those behind will pile up on top of them until the gully is filled level to the top with struggling sheep. <i>(1938,High Country,108</i>)

>  <b>PHARAZYN</b> to lambs to drive them to pen, smothered 10 in a blind gully. <i>(Jan 15, 1848,Journal,97</i>) [NOTES: (also 152 chk) Teddy and W. [some of cit missing???]]

>  In a minute half the mob were in. We pushed our horses in and prevented the others from going in. [36] If they had 3 out of 4 would have been smothered. <i>(May 2, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,35,1950 ed.</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a suffocation of sheep, usually en masse [ when driven hard downhill or near water, or worried in a paddock by a dog and being forced together into a tight pack. ]

>  <b>ACLAND</b> They had a bad smother there. <i>(1930,Early Canterbury Runs,128</i>)

>  <b>BLAKISTON</b> Shepherds dread a 'smother' and when the last creek was crossed, and the sheep safe in a holding paddock we were all very pleased. <i>(1952,My Yesteryears,20</i>)

 <i>v.</i> sawmilling: to trim the end of a log to obviate snagging while snigging; sc a log ?variant of snip

>  If the weather is favourable, the log is `sniped' or rounded at one end, an iron grip driven into it, and to this the team is fastened. <i>(1902,NZ Illustrated Magazine,5/375</i>)

>  <b>R. GILBERD</b> A `ropey' will learn to `snipe' ... which is a highly-skilled operation. Butt-end of clean-trimmed log is trimmed of angles. Vees are cut at points opposite each other at the butt-end (usually) and are connected by a chopped Dee which runs around in a semi-circle from one to the other. In the Dee is laid a `strop', a short length of cable with an eye in each end. The eyes are connected with each other and to a short chain by a shackle; and the chain is attached to `the rope' with a hitch. <i>(1950,Personal Communication</i>)

>  <b>REED</b> In order to prevent the log from `biting' into uneven ground, and enable it to slip over minor obstacles, it was `sniped' - that is, somewhat rounded or tapered at the front. <i>(1953,Story of the Kauri, The,179</i>)

>  <i>(1958,NZ Timber Journal,87/2</i>) [NOTES: [ca -1914]]

>  After the logs were cut, each was sniped. To snipe a log, the end is chipped all the way round so that it can be handled without catching humps in the ground, stumps and so on; in fact you might say that a log when it is sniped looks rather like the blunt end of a whale. <i>(1951,Radio NZ / National Radio</i>) [NOTES: H.S. McCarroll The Days of the Kauri Bushmen [Radio Talk 2: TS]]

>  SNIPE To round off the end of a log in order to facilitate snigging. <i>(1952,NZ Forest Glossary</i>)

>  <b>MOORE</b> The front end of the log was carefully `sniped', that is, its sharp edge was rounded to allow it to skid like a sledge-runner. <i>(1969,From Forest to Farm,42</i>)

>  <b>OWEN & PERKINS</b> First of all they tapered one end, rounding the log so that it would be able to slide over impediments in its path, because it had to be dragged along the ground. Now these men were called `snipers', and having sniped the log, they then made two cuts, one on each side of the log opposite each other, right into the rounded part - the sniped end. That was for the purpose of holding a heavy chain which attached the log to the yoked bullocks ... <i>(1986,Speaking for Ourselves,159</i>) [NOTES: (Joe Gasparich, Northland kauri country)]

 <i>n.</i> a pole placed upright to mark out a road or track when it is covered with snow.

## snowball waltz
 
 <i>n.</i> A means of breaking the ice; a pre-selected split up when the music stops and each takes a new partner from others in the hall; this continues until all are on the floor. [Also the name of a book by Renee. Note on conversation with Deidre Macken (60 yrs) about her mother's story (86 yrs). She was in the Wellington Ballet Company in 1926 and on news of Pavlova's tour wrote to her manager enquiring how they could help make her tour and reception more pleasant, her favourite colours, foods, etc. She expressed a great liking for meringue (cakes) so they consulted a chef who produced 3 attempts (e.g. a square cake was rejected in favour of a round one); finally the `soft-centre' variety was chosen. In her honour they named it Pavlova (?cake) and they presented this to Pavlova (? at a gathering) and she liked it a great deal. D. Macken is to research this - ? Ballet company records, etc. Deidre Macken (04) 384-6073 - H.D. Macken, Nairn St.]

>  <b>LAING & BLACKWELL</b> The white fruit of <i>G. antipoda</i> is known as the snowberry in Otago, and is occasionally eaten. Like most of the products of the New Zealand bush, it cannot be recommended to the epicure. <i>(1949,Plants of NZ,344</i>) [NOTES: 5th edition]

## snowed in
 
 <i>n.</i> of the condition when shearers are ahead of the wool table, so that wool is lying around the floor waiting to go on the wool table

>  <b>BOWEN</b> SNOWED IN. Describing the state of affairs when the shearers are ahead of the wool table, so that wool is lying around the floor waiting to go on the wool table. With a good run shearers can sometimes snow the pressers in. Shearers will be seen at their best when they get ahead of the rest of the shed. They enjoy this snowing in, and usually they make the wool flow faster than ever. <i>(1956,Wool Away!,157</i>) [NOTES: (glossary: Shearing Terms)]

>  <i>Snowed in</i>: The condition of the sorting table or the shearing board when shearers are working too fast for the shed hands to keep up. <i>(Feb 26, 1965,Listener (New Zealand Listener)</i>) [NOTES: (H.A.L. Laing)]

>  SNOWED IN: The condition of the table or board when the shearers are working too fast for the shed hands to keep up. <i>(Feb 21, 1968,Straight Furrow,20</i>) [NOTES: [Shearer's language]]

>  <i>Snowed in</i>: When shearers are ahead of the wool table, so that wool is lying around the floor waiting to go on the wool table. Also described as woolled-up. <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,59</i>)

>  <i>snowed in</i>: When the shearers get ahead of the men on the wool table and fleeces lie around. <i>(1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/28</i>) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]



 
 <i>adj.</i> (Rural) [of a woolshed floor] filled with unrolled fleeces when shearers' work is ahead of shed-hands'.

## snowman
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>MACDONALD</b> All freezing was done for the first ten years [from c1882] by the cold air machines ...[66] The carcases were hung in the chambers, and the cold air was blown through kauri ducts or trunks at a temperature of minus 40[degree sign] Fahrenheit.
