 <i>n.</i> mainly pl 1. the head(s) of the common plantain ? <i>Plantago lanceolata </i> from the children's game: 2.

>  <b>HILGENDORF</b> PLANTAIN (<i>Plantago lanceolata</i>) is commonly called rib grass, lamb's tongue, horse plantain, and soldiers. It is common in pastures and waste places throughout. It forms a rosette of lanceolate leaves about 6 inches long, with prominent or converging veins, giving the name `rib grass' From the rosette rises the slender flower stalk a foot or more in length, with a crowded mass of tiny brown or black flowers at its tip. These heads are used by children for playing `soldiers,' and so in Scotland the weed is called `Carl Doddie'-that is `Charles and George'- a souvenir of 1745. <i>(1926,Weeds of New Zealand,161,1967 ed.</i>)

## soldier settlement
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a policy to assist returned soldiers on to land of their own following the Land Wars, and First and Second World Wars. [aka soldiers settlement, soldiers' settlement]

>  DEPUTATION TO THE PREMIER SUGGESTED SPECIAL SOLDIERS' SETTLEMENT .. A deputation of returned officers and troopers waited on the Minister for Lands yesterday to see if the Government would be prepared to offer them special terms for settling on land in this colony, instead of going to South Africa. The Minister promised to see what could be done, and pointed out that under existing conditions they could form a special settlement. <i>(Sep 25, 1902,Hawera & Normanby Star,2</i>)

>  Announcing the personnel of the board appointed to report on soldier settlements in the various land districts, the Minister for Lands.. said the selection.. had not been a simple one. <i>(Oct 26, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,21</i>)

>  The private land acquired for soldier settlement purposes aggregated 1,279,235 acres, upon which 5715 returned men were settled ... <i>(Jun 1, 1922,NZ Farmer,711</i>)

>  <b>VANCE</b> For soldier settlement, the Government took 48,000 acres of the upper part of Rhoborough in 1920 ... <i>(1965,High Endeavour,144</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> After the last war the bulk of this property was cut up for soldier settlement. <i>(1969,Big Country of the North Island,54</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> In 1950 Waihuka Station was cut up for soldier settlement. <i>(1969,Big Country of the North Island,219</i>)

>  <b>WRIGHT</b> Another are of land that had been cut up for soldier settlement was leased on January 1st 1923 to John J Candy ... <i>(1985,Farming in the Mohaka State Forest,47</i>)

>  MR. W. E. PARRY, Auckland Labor member, told the House the other night that "soldier settlement is the grinning skeleton of the Reform maladministration in this country." <i>(Jul 24, 1930,NZ Truth,4</i>)

>  Look at Onehunga, Howick, Panmure, Papakura, and Otahuhu, (discharged soldiers settlements), what produce comes from those places to the Auckland and other markets, which would not have been the case had no roads been made. <i>(Aug 28, 1869,Taranaki Herald,4</i>)

>  There is an immense area between Rotorua and taupo, Waiotapu and the soldiers' settlement at Reparoa ... <i>(Jul 2, 1923,NZ Farmer,923</i>)

>  Their prospective occupants were the same at Whangapoua as at every other soldier settlement I have visited. <i>(Apr 12, 1951,NZ Farmer,4</i>)

## solstice
 
 <i>n.</i> [Jim writes: As an attributive, in relation to the winter solstice, this has come into use in NZ recently in compounds such as <i>(winter) solstice carnival, solstice celebration, solstice dinner, solstice party</i>. Any similar usages in the Northern Hemisphere (none are recorded in NSOD or Collins) are likely to relate to the summer solstice, since the winter solstice coincides with Christmas. I havs also seen <i>winter Christmas</i> used in NZ. The development of "solstice" terms might usefully be watched.]

>  <b>MCLEOD</b> Another word for a lazy dog is a "sooner" which is intended to convey that he would sooner you ran than he did. <i>(1951,NZ High Country,43</i>)

>  You don't need a trial dog; in fact about the opposite. One of those noisy 'sooners' (sooner bite the sheep than head the mob.) <i>(Aug 24, 1972,NZ Farmer,29</i>)

>  <b>SINCLAIR</b> I went up to Ngamatea Station in the spring with a large team of useless 'sooners' except for one handy dog of great ability, named Wonk. ibid. 95 King was a great dog behind sick or slow sheep on a muster, giving them all the time in the world. In fact, while he waited for a seedy sheep to catch up to the string, he'd look like a proper old sooner. <i>(1973,Boot in the Stirrup,46</i>)

>  <b>STACEY</b> Because I had no dog I had to use a pot-licking sooner belonging to the boss. <i>(1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,40</i>)

>  <b>GORDON</b> While we're dealing with the lesser lights of the working dog world, there is also the 'sooner', a slack and useless critter which would sooner lie in the shade. <i>(1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,87</i>)

>  Dogs of every breed, or any breed, "sooners" and others who have as much pedigree as a chicken raised in an incubator, are permitted to roam on the beaches and swim - the latter when some crank throws a stone or a piece of wood in and tells his puerile pup to "fetchit" - where little children are endeavouring to have the time of their lives. <i>(Sep 9, 1922,NZ Truth,1</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i>

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> <i>Sooner.</i> 2. (Ex 1.) `A jibbing horse (one that would sooner go backward than forward),' Niall Alexander, letter of Oct. 22, 1939: New Zealand: since ca. 1920. In Australia, not only such a horse but also a useless dog (Baker). <i>(1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1178</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>sooner </i> a horse jibbing, one that would sooner go back than forward, a lazy horse- or person. NZA. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,106</i>)

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a quality or grade of fleece wool

## southerly buster
 
 <i>n.</i> ? orig Canterbury, but general South Island and Cook Strait. see esp. buster, and see butt=ender; see also south-easter, souther, southern buster, sou'west buster, threeday sou'wester Acland's note and description (1933) applies (also CR. 68): A strong wind with rain, snow or sleet from a southerly direction. The ordinary man in the paddock in Canterbury recognises only three winds: <i> East </i> (from N.E.),<i> sou'wester </i> (from S.E., S. etc, S.W. etc), and nor'wester. <i> As a matter of fact a three-day so'wester usually only lasts two and a half. They are said to be less fierce than in the early days, just as the nor'wester is said to have been softened by the planting on the plains. It may be so in Christchurch </i>; but I cannot say I notice any difference up-country. The <i> nor'</i> wester <i> may come from any where between due north and due west. In such places as Hororata, where the wind can get at you between two gorges a distinction is made between a Waimakariri and a Rakaia nor' wester; but both are called nor' westers. </i> [Empty but for the note under definition]

>  Southerly burster, - buster.- <i> Three-day Sou'Wester.</i> A strong wind with rain, snow or sleet from a southerly direction. ## sow down
 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to sow and harrow in seed or to make new pasture.

>  Three four-tooth ewes in lamb were placed on a paddock at Lichfield which had been ploughed and sown down ... <i>(Sep 15, 1913,NZ Journal of Agriculture,119</i>)

>  When sowing down a permanent pasture it should be given every chance to establish quickly with the least amount of competition from other plants. <i>(Jul 16, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,34</i>)

>  <b>TAIT</b> All areas capable of being worked by mechanised farm implements are now been sown-down. <i>(1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,159</i>)

>  <b>DEANS</b> Much of this breaking-in was done by contract, the land being leased for cropping and afterwards sown down in permanent pasture. <i>(1964,Pioneers on Port Cooper Plains,i</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Huge gangs of bushwhackers were employed; the bush was felled and burnt and the area fenced and sown down. <i>(1969,Big Country of the North Island,65</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> .. some years ago an area of about 3,000 acres at the Ngamatea homestead was broken in and sown down ... <i>(1969,Big Country of the North Island,151</i>)

>  <b>GORDON</b> .. fodder radish, the seed of which could be used to sow down short-term fodder crops on mixed crop and stock farms .. all these crops would have been cleaned, dressed and bagged in George's own seed-cleaning plant and as they were from certified stock, sold to the seed trade, or farmers, for sowing down the following season. <i>(1987,People, Places & Paddocks,49</i>)

>  <b>GORDON</b> .. there'd be at least six major jobs in progress: Doug sowing down a grass paddock .. His busiest period is between October and Christmas with hundreds of hectares to be cultivated, culminating in sowing down swedes, chou and grass. <i>(1987,People, Places & Paddocks,113</i>)

## sow thistle
 
 <i>n.</i> [aka sowthistle, sow-thistle, sour thistle, sour-thistle]

## span-'em

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> In the nineteenth century the ring game seems to have been the most popular marble game. (In more recent years marble games with holes have had the greater role.) There was Big Ring, in which a circle a yard or more in diameter was drawn on the ground; there was the mullibar variation, in which an outsize taw was catapulted amongst the marbles in this circle. There were Little Ring, Liney, Follows, Follow the Taw, Holey, and then, on a less important scale, Butcher's Board, in which the marbles were bowled through the holes in a board, Eye-Drop, Knock-Backs, Leggings-Out (or Leggin's-Out), Span-'Em, and Backits. ## spang-weazling
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  Perhaps the most intriguing game of this nature [sc. tormenting insects or animals] is `Spang Weazling'. This game was played at Denniston in 1930-35. A crawley was placed on the end of a stick the middle section of which lay balanced over a stone. Before the crawley could crawl off the stick a stone had to be thrown onto the other end of the stick so as to catapult the crawley off the stick and over the cliff. A variation of the same game was being played at Denniston when I visited there in 1949. It was called alternatively `Hit the Crawley' or `Strike the Crayfish'. In this version the other end of the stick was hit with a batting stick (as in Tip Cat) and when the crawley was catapulted into the air it was hit again with the bat. <i>(1953,Unorganized Games,1/406</i>)

>  Some years ago there was a game among boys [?in Dunedin] called `spangweaselling' - taking kingfishers' nests with the young birds in them and knocking them to bits in the air. <i>(Aug 2, 1965,TV1</i>) [NOTES: 1965 Aug 2 WNTV1 `Any Questions' (P. Smithell, Dunedin) [spg SPANGWEASELING]]

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> <i>Spang-Weazling</i> (K-9) was a rather odd hitting game and appeared in only one locality, namely, Denniston, a mining village on the West Coast. [1920] <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,161</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> There are games recorded in this period for which there is no record before 1900 though they may well have existed under other names. est Coast: Dunk and Davey, Spang Weazling; <i>Wellington:</i> Who Goes Round My Stone Wall, Beg o' My Neighbor, Bellahonie, Run a Mile, On and Off the Bridge, Here Come Two Nuns, Colours, Isaac and Rebecca. Scrag, Diabolo, Bumble Puppy, Homai, Fives; <i>Auckland</i>: My Fair Young Lady, Rushes and Reeds, Surrender the Tower, Walls, Ball Hopscotch, ball games, Solomon Says; <i>Hawkes Bay</i>: Wolf Wolf Go Home, Homai; <i>Canterbury</i>: Poor Old Tom, Rats and Rabbits and Rips, Steps, Skin the Snake, Steal a Peg, Toodle-em-Buck, The Gag; <i>Golden Bay</i>: Who's That Walking Round My House Tonight, I've Come to See Poor Mary Jane, Steps and Stairs, Creeping, Branding, O'Leary; <i>Otago</i>: Sir Roger de Coverley, Who's That Knocking at My Door. <i>(1981,History of Children's Play,231</i>)

## Spaniard
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a sharp-spiked native plant of spp. Aciphylla that grows in high tussock country. [also wild Spaniard] (See [giant Spaniard](../G#giant-spaniard),[bloody Spaniard](../B#bloody-spaniard),[wild Spaniard](../W#wild-spaniard))

>  <b>W.H.S. ROBERTS</b> Writing of the Waimea Plain in 1856: - `The ground was well grassed, but the speargrass was too plentiful. The pasturage was very good. There was a good deal of scrub in the bends of the Mataura known as `wire plant' (Olearia virgata). There were also manuka and koromiko. Maori-heads, a kind of grass tree about three feet high, abounded in the swamps, and in some we saw toitoi grass and raupo. We did not pass any cabbage trees to-day ... we proceeded slowly through tomatakuru scrub, speargrass, Spaniard, snowgrass, and other native grasses ... we camped in a bend with good feed at the Elbow and a swamp on one side. Maori cabbage abounded ...' <i>(1856,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1856 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 18]

>  <b>PAUL</b> <i>Aciphylla squarrosa</i> spaniard <i>(1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ</i>) [NOTES: (And)]

>  <b>THOMSON</b> A new plant appeared here, allied to the cactus, and colonially termed a <i>`Spaniard' </i>It has stout blades with sharp points. <i>(1857,Southern Districts of Otago,311</i>)

>  <b>BUTLER</b> ... the sluggish creeks and swampy ground thickly overgrown with Irishman, snow grass and Spaniard ... which extend on either side of the river for half a mile or more. ... I will now return to the subject of wild Irishman and wild Spaniard. The former is a thorny tree growing with ungainly unmanageable boughs sometimes as large as our own hawthorn trees ... <i>(Jun 1860,Forest Creek MS,40,1961 ed.</i>)

>  <b>BUTLER</b> [Wild plants] are few, and decidedly ugly. There is one beast of a plant they call spear grass or spaniard, which I will tell you more about another time. <i>(Mar 24, 1860,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,4/49</i>)

>  <b>BUTLER</b> The Spaniard (spear-grass or bayonet-grass) `piked us intil the bane... <i>(May 1860,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,5/72</i>)

>  <b>HAAST</b> After crossing a small stream ... we arrived at such an impenetrable thicket of `Wild Irishman' and `Spaniards', that ... we had at last to give up the attempt with ... hands and faces covered with blood. <i>(1848,Julius Von Haast,210</i>) [NOTES: 1862 Mar 31 Von Haast in 1848 Von Haast Julius Von Haast 210]

>  <b>VON HAAST</b> ... the gigantic Aciphylla Colensoi, the Spaniard or Bayonet-grass. <i>(1862,Geology of Westland,25</i>) [NOTES: [check against 1879 cit???]]

>  <b>TAYLOR</b> In the Middle Island ... a great proportion of the land ... is one grand plain of shingle scarcely covered with soil, and only supporting grass ... much inferior to that of the North Island, filled also with spiny bushes of the Tumatakura, and that singular family of plants, the Acifolia Taramea, commonly called Spaniards; . <i>(1868,Past and Present of NZ,202</i>)

>  <b>KENNAWAY</b> ... we struck up ... towards the [Canterbury] mountains, the country being all level ... with a strong growth of coarse tussocks, pampas-grass, snow-grass (similar to the pampas, but having a deep red tinge in the blade) and spaniard or spear-grass ... <i>(1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,40</i>)

>  <b>HAAST</b> Our road lay now ... across a grassy flat, mostly overgrown with the same dense vegetation met with on the banks of all our river-flats, namely the spiny Wild-Irishman, and the bayonet-like Spaniard (<i>Aciphylla Lyallii</i>). <i>(1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,124</i>)

>  [Fantastic names of plants] show the imagination running riot; they seem appropriate, though often it is impossible to give any definite reason for the name. ... `Spaniard' [like `Wild-Irishman' is] another name of unexplained origin. There seems even less connection between the human Spaniard and the vegetable spaniard than between the human wild Irishman and the vegetable wild-irishman; and the conjectured corruption `spine-yard', whilst improbable, is no more improbable than the fabled `Bill's-yard' as the origin of `billiard' <i>(1926,TrNZI,663</i>) [NOTES: Andersen Pop. Names]

>  <i>Spaniard, speargrass</i>.- Various species of <i>Aciphylla</i>. Plants with stiff sharp leaves like rapiers growing out thickly in all directions from the ground. They were thickest in the hills, but there were plenty on the plains before they were ploughed. Horses avoid them carefully, which makes riding through them unpleasant. There are stories of men falling off and landing on one. Shepherds use the flower stalks for torches when burning. In the 'eighties and 'nineties at Mount Peel they used to all the broader leaved sort Spaniards and the narrower <i>Speargrass</i>; but most people use both names indiscriminately. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) `There is one beast of a plant they call speargrass, or Spaniard.' (Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p. 48). <i>(Dec 16, 1933,Press, The,21/241</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>LEVY</b> ... shrubs common in the tussock zone: matagouri, native brooms, dwarf koromikos, monoao, sarmentose tutu, the grasslike spiky-leaved Spaniard, the harsh patotara, golden cottonwood, cushion-like pimeleas, and the low, matted, carpet-like growth of the scabweeds are characteristic of the low tussock country, ... <i>(1951,Grasslands of NZ,35,1970 ed.</i>)

>  ... tumatakuru, a small thorny scrub, one of the few deciduous plants of New Zealand, which Europeans nick-named `Wild Irishman', ... speargrass, or `Spaniard', as the stronger variety was called, ... <i>(1914,History of North Otago,4,1978 ed.</i>) [NOTES: 1906 W.H.S.Roberts in 1914 History of North Otago (1978) 4]

## Spanish cream
 
 <i>n.</i> a sweet dessert made with gelatine.

>  Spanish Cream... The top of the puddingshould be clear amber and the custardbelow, forming two distinct layers. <i>(Mar 25, 1912,Dominion,11</i>)

>  Spanish Cream. - Take three-quarters of an ounce of gelatine, and let it soak for an hour in half a pint of cold water ... <i>(Mar 3, 1896,Bruce Herald,2</i>)

>  Spanish Cream. - Soak one ounce of gelatine in half a pint of milk for two hours ... <i>(Dec 27, 1902,Evening Post,2</i>)

>  My aunt always brought pavlova, my grandmother made Spanish Cream and there'd be pikelets and scones. <i>(Dec 1996,North & South,106</i>)

>  <b>OWEN</b> It was a surefire recipe for literary success, because when you think of smouldering passion and strawberry meringues and unassailable virtue and cream puffs and violent death and Spanish cream, it was irresistible! <i>(1998,Snapshots of the Century,16</i>)

>  <b>THOMSON</b> <i>SPANISH CREAM</i>. Soak 1 oz. of gelatine ... <i>(1915,Amuri Cookery Book,42,1927 ed.</i>)

>  <b>KEITH</b> Coffee essence De Luxe was l/7d, Spanish Cream Base 4d. <i>(1991,Lovely Day Tomorrow, A,67</i>)

>  As a teenager reading novels of the Southern belles and the cooks making spanish cream for a grand ball supper, I realised it was angel's food. <i>(Nov 3, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42</i>)

>  SPANISH CREAM. - Take three spoonfuls of flour or rice, sifted very fine, the yolks of three eggs, three spoonfuls of water, two of orange-flower water; mix them well together; then put to them one pint of cream, then set it upon a good fire, stirring it till of a proper thickness, and pour it into cups. <i>(Apr 24, 1875,Otago Witness,19</i>)

>  SPANISH CREAM - One and a-half pints of milk poured on 1/2oz of gelatine, to soak one hour, three eggs and four tablespoonfuls sugar; beat sugar and yolks together and pour in boiling milk; let it boil one minute, then pour this mixture on whites of the eggs which have been previously well beaten and placed in the mould. Flavour with vanilla. Serve cold with cream. <i>(Feb 26, 1881,Otago Witness,26</i>)

>  Monteith's Black made a fine beverage and, with a dessert of Spanish Cream splashed with Cointreau, it was a happy Sunday dinner. <i>(Mar 24, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42</i>)

>  About Christmas I tried.. a recipe called "Three Minute Spanish Cream." <i>(Feb 23, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,24</i>)

>  About 100 members of the nursing staff ofthe Waikato Hospital became ill followinga meal which included spanish cream madewith duck eggs in aluminium saucepans. <i>(Dec 17, 1945,NZEF Times,IV/234 :6</i>)

>  <b>FARRELL</b> No ordinary housewife like the others onthe street, consumed by the mundane,swapping recipes for Spanish Cream. <i>(1992,Skinny Louie Book,78</i>)

[fn.] 15. [imp. & p. p.</i> SPELLED (sp&ebreve.ld);<i> p. pr. & vb. n.</i> SPELLING.] [See SPELL, <i>n.,</i> 1.<i> (b) </i>above.] To rest from work for a time.<i> Baldwin Spencer. </i> ... <i>Spell, v. t.</i> to allow an interval of rest to (one). <i>(1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2031</i>)

## Spiral
 
 <i>n.</i> [See also Raurimu Spiral]

>  EXPRESS ASCENDING THE SPIRAL. <i>(Jun 26, 1912,Evening Post,13</i>) [NOTES: Photo Caption]

>  NORTH ISLAND MAIN TRUNK RAILWAY: DIAGRAM SHOWING THE "SPIRAL" AT RAURIMU (PUKERIMU). <i>(Nov 1, 1906,Progress,22</i>) [NOTES: Illustration Caption]

>  Six cars of the Auckland express which left Wellington at 3 p.m. yesterday were derailed and dropped 14 feet four miles north of the Raurimu Spiral at 1.30 a.m. today. <i>(Jan 6, 1945,Evening Post,8</i>)

>  <b>LEITCH</b> On the 1 in 50 of the Spiral it [sc. anX-class loco] took 260-ton passengertrains, while on level track 900-tonfreight trains could be handled. <i>(1972,Railways of NZ,172</i>)

>  <b>LEITCH</b> As the railcar follows the succession ofcurves and circles on the uncompensated 1in 50, the traveller unused to the Spiralsoon loses all sense of direction asRaurimu station is glimpsed three timesat successive levels of the climb. <i>(1972,Railways of NZ,217</i>)

>  <b>MASTERTON</b> Look at the magnificent bush around here,and the abundance of ponga ferns, buttuck your head in now, for this is ourlast tunnel before we descend the famousSpiral. <i>(1973,Mountain Enginemen,68</i>)

>  <b>TROUP</b> [Caption] Here a small train of twoalready ancient cars, a van and twotrucks, headed by what looks like a D,waits to travel down the Spiral and on toTaumarunui. <i>(1973,Steel Roads of NZ,118</i>)

>  <b>PIERRE</b> F.G. Hall-Jones in his biography of hisfather.. avers that "on father'sinsistence the engineers had made furtherexplorations and had found the Spiralroute." <i>(1981,North Island Main Trunk,43</i>) [NOTES: [NB - What is in quotes is not exactlywhat Hall-Jones says; the original quoteis not usable for Spiral.]]

>  <b>PIERRE</b> On both ascent and descent of the spiralyour author could not but observe thesmooth progress of the train of twoSilver Fern units around Keller'salignment. <i>(1981,North Island Main Trunk,49</i>)

>  <b>PIERRE</b> The boxing of the compass by the spiralwas early adopted into King Countryfolk-lore. It tells of the consternationof an early driver who... found that hehad merely caught up with his own guard'svan. <i>(1981,North Island Main Trunk,46</i>)

## spit tacks
 
 <i>phr.</i> be angry [Jim Cameron writes: Collins gives this and <i>spit chips</i> (with same meaning) as <i>Austral</i>, with a cryptic reference <i>"also NZ"</i>. ## spit the dummy
 
 <i>phr.</i> to give way to a fit of anger, to have a temper tantrum [Orsman says originally Australian [1987]]

>  It wasn't the chef who spat the dummy. It was another customer who was irritated by what was filling his or her schnozz. <i>(Dec 19, 2001,Capital Times,17</i>)

>  I would spit the dummy and refuse right then and there to ever again accompany Gav to the stockcars. Sheesh, that's a bit heavy, he says. <i>(Sep 27, 2001,Evening Post,8</i>)

>  So while Warwick, a sort of male version of the Ingham twins, spat the dummy to play the field, and William courted legal agonies, enter Tyler and Kate, who prepared for the birth of their son Cyrone. <i>(Oct 3, 2001,Evening Post,16</i>)

>  As negotiations continued, the proposed rise in the lake level was reduced to 8.4m. But then New Zealanders spat the dummy. <i>(Jun 15, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36</i>)

>  He shouldn't spit the dummy; it doesn't do him credit. <i>(Dec 19, 2000,Independent Herald (Wellington),1</i>)

>  Jiang Zemin spat the dummy because - unlike his country - we have free speech, or so I thought. <i>(Sep 19, 1999,Sunday Star Times,A10</i>)

>  He has had enough setbacks in his time to have spat the dummy many times over. <i>(Nov 14, 1999,Sunday Star Times,B20</i>)

>  Coupled with a dazzling array of obscure antipodean slang expressions - marking the wood? spitting the dummy? - the effect is X-rated Kylie Mole. <i>(Sep 24, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5</i>)

## splendid perch
 
 <i>n.</i> Brightly coloured fish found in southern Australian and northern and central NZ waters, also known as Allport's perch. [<i>Callanthias allporti</i> aka Allport's perch] (See [Allport's perch](../A#allport's-perch))

>  <b>PAUL</b> <i>Splendid perch Callanthias allporti </i>Southern Australia and New Zealand. Sometimes called Allport's perch, but the name splendid is more appropriate, as it is a very colourful and variable species. <i>(1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,85</i>)

>  <b>PAUL</b> <i>Splendid perch Callanthias allporti </i>Southern Australia and New Zealand. Sometimes called Allport's perch, but the name splendid is more appropriate, as it is a very colourful and variable species. <i>(1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,85</i>)

>  <b>AYLING</b> <i>SPLENDID PERCH Callanthias allporti</i> The male splendid perch is surely one of the most colourful of the fishes found in the New Zealand region. ... In New Zealand they are only found off the east coast from North Cape to East Cape ... <i>(1982,Collins Guide,208,1984 ed.</i>)



## Splendour
 
 <i>n.</i> a variety of apple

>  Though a parent of the Pacific Rose, Splendour's own parents are unknown. All that is known is that it was discovered in New Zealand in 1948 and introduced in 1967. It's not a dramatic looker, being dull pinkish red, and though sweet, with a crisp texture, it is rather mild and lacks tartness. <i>(Mar 27, 2004,Dominion Post,E6</i>)

>  Work continues on a project using 'Gala' and 'Splendour' as parents to produce a red, high-quality mid-season variety. <i>(1983,AJHR,G.-21/17</i>)

>  The only experimental variety amongst these was Splendour. <i>(Feb 1967,Orchardist NZ,7</i>)

>  The new apple variety Splendour has a natural tendency to produce clusters of aerial roots on the main branches. <i>(Apr 1969,Orchardist NZ,101</i>)

>  Splendour. Plantings seem now to be restricted to gate sales, for which this variety is ideal. <i>(Nov 1974,Orchardist NZ,338</i>)

>  <b>Elizabeth Smither</b> Now they are sitting opposite each other at a wooden table with fixed seats, biting into the flesh of two Splendour apples. <i>(2007,Six Pack 2, The,50</i>)

>  SPLENDOUR. A chance seedling found in the late 1950's in a Napier garden and originally named after its owner, Mr Roberts. <i>(1991,New Zealand's Best Apple Recipes,13</i>)



## split
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [dog trials] 1. a departure of one of three competition sheep from the others during a trial run. 2. a successful division of a group of six competition sheep into two trios by a dog competitor.

>  Split - When one of a dog trial trio takes a fit of the 'hermits' and goes off on its own. Split is also used to describe the successful division of a sextet into two trios. <i>(Dec 15, 1983,NZ Journal of Agriculture,46</i>)



## split beef
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  Other changes include dropping the bobby calf levy and split beef levy. <i>(Aug 28, 2003,Dominion Post,C7</i>)



## split calving
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) the separation of a herd into two or more groups for conception and calving.

>  Split calving, where a portion of the herd (33% to 50%) is calved in autumn, the other half in spring. <i>(Sep 1997,NZ Dairy Exporter,47</i>)

>  They have found that split calving spreads the workload over the year ... <i>(1997,NZ Dairy Exporter,125</i>)

>  Couple required: 300 Friesian herd, split calving, experience essential. <i>(Apr 13, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,25</i>)



## split muster
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a muster in rugged country in which stock are mustered down or off in divisions.

>  <b>MCLEOD</b> It was another 'split muster' on the first day, with three men walking up the Cass River and following its western branch through the bush. <i>(1974,Kingdom in the Hills,133</i>)



## Split rostral gecko
 
 <i>n.</i> a newly recognised species of NZ gecko, found in Kahurangi National Park in 2003. [classification pending]

>  Mt Benson gecko/split rostral gecko: These probable new species were found in Kahurangi National Park, the first in 2002, the other last year. The split rostral species differs from all other geckos in the world, because the scale at the tip of its nose is divided into two. <i>(Aug 2, 2004,Dominion Post,A4</i>) [NOTES: classification pending]



## split sack
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a large sack, split on one side, which can be used as a saddle bag. (See [pikau](../P#pikau))

>  <b>ELLISON</b> I told them how we got our stores to Puaiti, carrying them in split sacks on the horses ... <i>(1956,Whirinaki Valley, The,52</i>)

>  <b>MILLS ET AL</b> When an otherwise doomed, shivering 'stray' is found huddled against a straggly rush-bush or wire fence for shelter, it should be placed in a split-sack, which will comfortably carry two, and placed over a horse-back shepherd's saddle. <i>(1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,93</i>)

>  <b>EASY</b> So it became my job to ride out to Otorohanga for anything wanted for the house or farm, mail, newspapers etc. We made a split sack, an idea copied from the Maoris. <i>(1991,Looking Back,26</i>)

>  <b>WATERSON</b> Already two horses had been saddled with split-sacks. [split-sack] <i>(1999,Some Buggers I've Seen,143</i>)

>  He ties the gelding in a gully out of sight of the road and gets the wire-strainers out of his split-sack. <i>(1989,Bullock Creek,94</i>)

>  Almost half of New Zealand's reptiles are threatened or endangered. It is now illegal to handle or keep in captivity any native lizard without a permit from the Department of Conservation. >  Spotted skinks also have a scattered distribution indicating that they may once havebeen widespread in lowland areas of the southern North Island south of HawkeBay. The species is also foundon islands in Wellington Harbour .. on islands in the MarlboroughSounds and is widespread in the eastern South Island ... In the North Island, spotted skinks coexist with brown, speckled and common skinks. <i>(2002,Internet - see Notes</i>) [NOTES: http://www.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/TSRP48.pdf Department of Conservation Te Papa Atawhai]

>  <b>Spotted skink</b>: Oligosoma lineoocellatum, 111mm in length from snout to vent (minus tail). It is much bigger than the common skink which is 73mm. Any alcoholic drinks, but usually spirits. The verbal forms `to spot' and `spotting' were common. <i>(1947,All Part of the Game,84</i>) [NOTES: `School Picnic [check title - not `Big Game'???]]

>  <b>CHERRILL</b> Pa wouldn't have got into the way of spotting the way he has ... . <i>(1950,Story of a NZ Sheepfarm,73</i>)

>  <b>HARTLEY</b> Mother believed dancing was worldly if not sinful, and she was frightened that we might start `spotting'. Mother's twin fears were carnal sin and having a `spot'. <i>(1987,Swagger on Our Doorstep,180</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (See [cf. spot v](../S#spot-v),[spoiling; gridironing](../S#spoiling;-gridironing))

>  <b>OLIVER</b> The runholder was protected against intruders: cottages, fences and homesteads gave him a pre-emptive right over a set number of contiguous acres. Fences and cottages could be so disposed as to give the runholder rights over the best of the land - sources of water and wood, strips surrounding isolated and thus inaccessible pockets. `Grid-ironing' and `spotting', as these selective practices were called, were certainly used by many runholders to tie up large areas, but probably not to the extent alleged by horrified land tenure radicals in later years. <i>(1968,Story of New Zealand, The,108</i>)

>  <b>CRAWFORD</b> `Gridironing' was the practice of buying twenty acre sections fronting on a road, so spaced as to leave sections of nineteen acres between them, and as these had to be auctioned the small farmer stood litttle chance of outbidding the run-holder who usually retained them without having to purchase them. `Spotting' was buying up key positions, fertile land, and leaving the barren, water courses, entrances to valleys, road lines, ... . <i>(1949,Sheep and Sheepmen of Canterbury,94</i>)

>  <b>SCOTTER</b> When investigating the change from pastoral lease to freehold in any locality, the student, brought up on Pember Reeves (see e.g. S.E.I. [State Experiments 1902] 234) searches immediately for evidences of the methods by which the runholder retained his grasp of the land. These practices called gridironing and spotting can be defended: there is no need to do so here. If spotting is practiced - the purchase of selected areas with water and shelter for the control this gave over the surrounding country - a study of the Crown grant index maps and of the dates of the original titles supplies no evidence of it. <i>(1948,Run, Estate and Farm,13</i>)

>  <b>CARR</b> The practice of which I speak is called in New Zealand <i>`spotting'</i> or <i>`spoiling'</i> country. [???a verbal not nominal use] <i>(1856,Waste Lands of Wellington, The,30</i>)

>  <i>Green</i>, one of the settlers, is endeavouring to purchase land in various places <i>spotting ... . </i> <i>(1865,McLean Papers,25/132 [1866 xxv/139]</i>) [NOTES: (Harris, Tauranga)]

>  <b>CRAWFORD</b> McLean brought to light some of the pitfalls of spot freeholding when he wrote in September 1970: The promiscuous `spotting' of this run with small blocks of freehold ... [sic] may have in a measure attained the primary object of excluding extensive purchase ... <i>(1981,Station Years,47</i>) [NOTES: 1870 Sep in 1981 Crawford Station Years 47]

>  <b>MORRIS</b> <i>Spotting, n.</i> New Zealand equivalent for the Australian `picking the eyes out,' and `peacocking.' Under <i>Free-selection</i> (q.v.), the squatter spotted his run, purchasing choice spots. <i>(1898,Austral English,431</i>)

>  spotting <i>n</i>. selecting the best parts of an area; peacocking.-spot v.t. <i>(1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,11</i>)

>  <b>BURDON</b> The other and yet more harmful method was to buy isolated sections all over a run to prevent or hinder large purchases by anyone else; to pick out the fertile and leave the barren; to take the grain and leave the husk. This was called `spotting.' <i>(1938,High Country,123</i>)

>  <b>BAKER</b> <i>Spotting</i> was applied to provinces other than Canterbury ... It was probably formed on the basis of the Australian terms <i>pick the eyes out of the country</i> and <i>peacocking. </i> <i>(1941,NZ Slang,26</i>)

>  <b>SINCLAIR</b> `Spotting' was the purchase of strategic points, such as the mouth of a gorge, river-banks and other watering-places, so as to exclude rivals from large areas of adjacent land. <i>(1959,History of New Zealand,156</i>)

>  <i>spotting N.</i> in New Zealand selecting the choicest parts of an area, picking the eyes out and leaving the poorer parts. See gridironing. <i>(1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),625</i>)

>  <i>spotting ... n.</i> in N.Z., selecting the choicest parts of an area, picking the eyes out, and leaving the poorer parts. See <i>gridironing. </i> <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),18</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a purchase of scattered strategic and productive areas of land to dissuade other purchasers.

>  <b>FULLER</b> For the capitalist, by what is colonially termed 'spotting a Run', that is, picking out parts of it only to buy, may command the pasturage of the whole of the remaining portion ... <i>(1859,Five Years' Residence in New Zealand,72</i>)

>  <b>MORRIS</b> spotting. New Zealand equivalent for the Australian 'picking the eyes out' and 'peacocking.' <i>(1898,Austral English,431</i>)

>  <b>STEWART</b> The squatters contended that they had to adopt all these expedients of spotting and gridironing in self-protection. <i>(1940,William Rolleston: a New Zealand statesman,61</i>)

>  <b>BAKER</b> With the opening up of new land in this country .. a host of new expressions came into being, among them the Canterbury Pilgrims, shagroons, prophets, pre-Adamites, v-hut, gridironing, and spotting. <i>(1941,NZ Slang,24</i>)

>  The method of either gridironing, that is buying up the freehold of strategic parts around, or spotting, buying the strategic and fertile patches of an area that was customary with hill country settlers of the early days, was adapted by Mr Hugh Duff when taking up Whakarara ... <i>(Nov 15, 1952,Weekly News,33</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) [aerial mustering] the sighting of stragglers and stray stock.

>  A Cattle Muster on Molesworth. With the spotting we've missed seventeen. <i>(May 4, 2000,Country Calendar (TVNZ)</i>)

>  <b>DOMINY</b> Now on occasion, when spotting or straggling, some run-holders save time by using a helicopter to drop them in the back country. <i>(2001,Calling the Station Home,169</i>)

 <i>v.</i> to catch, spike, snag the flesh or clothing on a protruding spike of wire, metal, etc. [(The NZ sense of <i>sprag </i> n and v would seem to derived from a dialect variant of <i>sprig </i>: cf. >  <b>CHAMIER</b> The men ... asked permission to `spread their blankets' in the wool-shed. <i>(1891,Philosopher Dick,415</i>)

>  We are informed by a gentleman who recently visited the Thames that, notwithstanding the great number of hotels and boarding houses, the towns of Shortland and Grahamstown are at present so overfull of population that arrivals by late steamers experience the utmost difficulty in obtaining room even to spread their blankets on the bare floor. <i>(Oct 27, 1869,Daily Southern Cross,7</i>)

>  The two men spread their blankets on their vehicle's spacious interior. <i>(Jan 23, 1941,Evening Post,7</i>)



## spread-man
 
 <i>n.</i> one who inserts spreaders between the back legs of carcases

>  <b>GORDON</b> <i>Spread-men</i>: those who put in <i>spreaders</i>. <i>(May 17, 1951,Personal Communication</i>) [NOTES: ca1951 May 17 Feilding Freezing Works terms p.c. Colin Gordon]



## spreader
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>WAKEFIELD</b> ... `spreaders' are blankets. <i>Ibid.</i> 1/319 Thus pigs and potatoes were respectively represented by <i>"grunters"</i> and<i> "spuds"</i>; guns, powder, blankets, pipes and tobacco, by<i> "shooting sticks, dust, spreaders, steamers,"</i> and<i> "weed".</i> <i>(1845,Adventure in NZ,1/318</i>)

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> <i>Spreader </i>. 2. A blanket: whalers': C. 19. E.J. Wakefield' <i>Adventure in New Zealand, </i>1845 (recorded by B., 1941). <i>(1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1181</i>)

>  spreader n . whalers slang for a blanket. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),18</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>SLATTER</b> Some of his best days had been spent working as a postal assistant ... He had been a spreader in the mailroom and a dragger on the landing. <i>(1968,Pagan Game, The,85</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>HENDERSON</b> SPREADER: Three-foot stout stick fitted to rear of horses' trace chains to keep chains apart. <i>(1961,Friends in Chains,189</i>) [NOTES: c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 189]



 
 <i>n.</i> see cit.

>  <b>GORDON</b> <i>Spreaders </i>: the hooks and bar for spreading back legs. <i>(May 27, 1951,Personal Communication</i>) [NOTES: ca1951 May 17 Feilding Freezing Works terms p.c. Colin Gordon]



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a metal device used in dressing a mutton carcass.

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> spreader: a metal device to hold the forelegs of a mutton carcass apart to facilitate some of the dressing, particularly the Y-cut. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,77</i>)



## spreader board
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a board fitted at the rear of a konaki, sledge or trailer, for the even spreading of animal manure on to paddocks.

>  The types of spreader boards in use are many and varied, some being more efficient than others. ..In this case the spreader board is 18in. to 24in. wide and 6 ft.long. The manure falls into this box and thus finds it way out through the opening between the front of the box and the spreader board ... <i>(May 15, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,513</i>)



## spree
 
 <i>n.</i> in NZ from c1840 used for happy drinking bouts, as well as for shearers' and sailors' drunken orgies:

>  <b>BEST</b> [On Lieutenant Shortland's show of official force to Wellington colonists, 18--] `You may easily imagine how disappointed I was that the [Wellington] Council did not shew [sic] fight. It would have been such a spree to have blown up their magazine and besides that I should have been entitled to ?10 and 9d. per diem tentage and forage money for actual service and should also have had the pleasure of licking them, instead of which no sooner did we appear than they all sneaked off.' <i>(1843,Letter</i>) [NOTES: a1843 (1837-1843) Best's letters in Mitchell Library undated newspaper article in Journal (1966) 410]

>  <b>CAMPBELL</b> Sailors having ... a harsh captain, or a desire for a <i>spree</i>. <i>(1840,Present State of NZ,24</i>)

>  ... he is altogether an adept at Colonial life. Instance, when he commences a drunken sprey (as he calls it) he invariably puts all his money into the soles of his shoes or boots, excepting that portion he intends spending .... <i>(Jan 24, 1852,Journal</i>) [NOTES: 1852 Jan 24 Monson's Prison Journal in 1978 Locke The Gaoler 54]

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> ... and after, perhaps three years of fearful hardship, so much of the [sealers'] money as might be uncondemned would be dissipated in Sydney in a few days' `spree'. <i>(1852,Whaling and Sealing,5</i>) [NOTES: 1843 May 2 in 1863 C.Heaphy `A Chapter on Sealing' Southern Monthly Magazine June I/No 4 pp173-176 in 1982 Richards Whaling and Sealing 5]

>  <b>ANTHONY</b> Mark, do you know this, I believe I'll have to break out in a good old woolly spree, pretty soon. <i>(1936,Follow the Call,102</i>)

>  <b>PHILLIPPS</b> J.P. who has been on the spree at W.W. is laid up with a bad head in consequence <i>(Apr 28, 1867,Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point,101</i>)

>  <b>WOOD</b> Rain came at last, and with it money, and Jim settled down to a regular spree. <i>(1875,Waiting for the Mail,106</i>)

>  English people are given to associating the idea of a `spree' with that of a bacchanal orgy. Not so We. With us the word is simply colonial for a festivity of any kind, public or private. And whatever may be the primary object of a spree, it is pretty certain to end with a dance. <i>(1882,Brighter Britain,1/272</i>)

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> A remittance man who was in receipt of at least [pounds]400 a year from Home would go on a spree and drink [pounds]5 away every day ... <i>(1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,55</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> I had made the money as they told me I would. So then I spent it. Not in a sudden spree like shearers come to town, but in a deliberate determination to go under and stay under. <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,13</i>)

>  <b>MANTELL</b> Lucky we found it [an abandoned car] first ... Before some larrikins commandeered it for a joy riding spree.' <i>(1980,Murder or Three, A,78</i>)

>  <b>ROCHFORT</b> [We] were shortly lulled to sleep by the heavy breathing of several sailors, who had evidently just come home from a `spree'. <i>(1853,Adventures of a Surveyor,19</i>)

>  <b>THATCHER</b> (The Caledonian Gathering) What a jolly spree the other day,/ Don't think that I am blathering,/ I'll give you just a short account/ Of the Caledonian gathering./ <i>(1864,Invercargill Minstrel,5</i>)

>  We hope his conscience pricks him, andthat he will spend all profits made on a"spree" for the boys. <i>(Mar 14, 1917,Chronicles NZEF,II/14 : 33</i>)

 <i>n.</i>

## sprig
 
 <i>n.</i> [Jim Blakeley (508 College St, Palmerston North, 5301; blakeley@ihug.co.nz) remembers pre-WWII usage of "sprigs" as opposed to "studs" in Scotland re soccor boots, also used with regard to golf shoes. "Am almost certain that the word was also used to describe the small nails that cobblers used in repairing leather shoes. Possibly derived from sprig of heather??" Alan Burnett (aged 75) writes from 21 Hector St, Herne Bay, (2/10/1999) that when he was a child in Scotland aged about 10 "we nailed SPRIGS on our soccer boots - obtained from the local cobbler.]

>  12 [pairs] Gents.' Shoes, Sprigs ... <i>(Aug 16, 1853,Daily Southern Cross,1</i>) [NOTES: Advert]

>  <b>CONEY</b> The English malthoid... almost trips me,dragging at my sprigs... <i>Ibid</i>. 124Like flies around an Australian, the sideclusters to borrow sprigs for a widerange of boots, and sprig tighteners formetric and AF dimensions. <i>(1986,Playing Mantis,112</i>)

>  ON SALE, at the Stores of the undersigned - Black and green teas .. an assortment of leather, hobnails, sprigs, &c. <i>(Mar 19, 1842,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,1</i>) [NOTES: Advert]

>  It's all right... You don't feel the sprigs when you're fit. <i>(Aug 18, 1979,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13</i>)

## spring
 
 <i>v.</i> to escape from prison

>  <b>NEWBOLD</b> Even one of the supervis or supervisors was a customer of mine, which worked out very handy one day when he sprung me pinching meat. <i>Ibid.</i> 254 SPRING (v) ... 2. Catch, realise, discover. <i>(1982,Big Huey, The,14</i>)

## spring burn
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [S.I. high country] an annual spring burning of tussock.

>  A little surface sowing with European grasses sometimes takes place after the spring burn. <i>(Jun 15, 1910,NZ Journal of Agriculture,8</i>)

>  Spring burns cause the destruction of all the accumulated dead material of the tussocks that are acting as a soil mulch ... <i>(Jun 15, 1910,BLANK ENTRY,9</i>)

>  The spring burns lessen the general vitality of the pasture ... <i>(Jun 15, 1910,BLANK ENTRY,10</i>)



## spring burning
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) an annual burning of noxious pasture growth or tussock in spring.

>  <b>COOP</b> In places where spring burning of fern, gorse, scrub or tussock is practised, shearing in August before the burn prevents any dirt and charcoal from entering the fleece. <i>(1950,Shearing Ewes before Lambing,24</i>)



## spring calving

>  Most farmers plan calving for July and August (euphemistically called spring calving) to take advantage of spring grass growth, which starts in September and usually peaks in late October or November. <i>(Mar 2003,NZ Geographic,62/26</i>)

## spruce
 
 <i>n.</i> also as attrib spruce(-)tree se also spruce fir 1. probably =RIMU

>  Also began to Brew Beer with the leaves and branches of a tree which resembles the Americo black Spruce Inspissated Juce of Wort and Melasses. [fn] cf. Cooper: ` ... began to make Beer from a Tree of a Rosinish quality intermixt with the Tea Plant. [fn] Rimu <i>Dacrydium cupressinus </i>: Tea plant Manuka <i> L. scoparium.</i> <i>(Apr 1, 1773,Cook's Journals,2/114,1961 ed.</i>)

>  ... the most considerable [timber] here [in Dusky Sound] ... is the spruce tree as we call'd it from the similarity of its leaves to the America black spruce, but the wood is more ponderous and of a reddish colour ... . <i>(May 11, 1773,Cook's Journals,2/135,1961 ed.</i>)

>  <b>BAYLY</b> The largest [NZ trees] are the spruce tree (from the tops of the branches of which we made Spruce Beer which was very good which are 12 or 14 feet round and 50 or 60 feet high and exceeding strait ...). <i>(Apr 12, 1773,Journal</i>) [NOTES: 1773 April 12 Bayly's Journal in 1908 McNab Historical Records 2/206]

>  <b>FORS</b> The next morning we drank Tea made of spruce which had afine [sic] taste ...[ed. fn] <i>Dacrydium cupressinum </i> Lamb; the Rimu or Red Pine. <i>(Mar 29, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/243</i>)

>  <b>FORSTER</b> ... the resemblance it bore to the fir tribe ... soon convinced us that it was fitter to serve the purposes of [130] the American spruce-tree, and that a palatable and wholesome liquor might be brewed from it, as a kind of substitute for spruce-beer. ... The spruce of New-Zeeland is a very beautiful tree, and conspicuous on account of its pendant branches ... <i>(1777,Voyage Round the World,1/129</i>)

>  <b>BELL</b> Many of the Trees were large enough for the Masts of Ships, - and the grain of the Spruce Tree is very close and durable. <i>(Nov 1791,Journal of Voyage in HMS 'Chatham',50</i>)

>  <b>FORSTER</b> The <i>Sprucetree </i> is not so copious [at Queen Charlotte Sound] as at <i>Dusky Bay </i>. The <i>Teatree </i> is more common than there, but for the greater part more shrubby, though there are likewise some very tall ones in this place. <i>(Jun 8, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/296</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i>

## spruce beer
 
 <i>n.</i> [Cook's <i> Journals </i> do not appear to use the collocation spruce beer, but speak of a beer brewed from SPRUCE, among other plants.]

## squat
 
 <i>v.</i> to defecate [cf. crouch ca1935 Havelock (also used occas as a noun ca1941 St Patrick's College, Silverstream] (See [cf. crouch](../C#crouch))



 
 <i>n.</i>

 <i>v.</i> (historical) to occupy a site temporarily, as newly-arrived emigrants, or while waiting for accommodation in houses or barracks

>  Some of the labouring emigrants sent out to me to have pointed out the site of the market place for them to squat upon. <i>(Dec 19, 1850,Torlesse Papers,183,1958 ed.</i>) [NOTES: [Canterbury]]

>  We therefore squatted upon the unsurveyed portion of the Palmerston Township, and have built thereon, hoping to be able to purchase the land when surveyed and put up for sale, as very many other settlers in this district have been allowed to do during the whole period since the Manawatu Block was first purchased. <i>(Mar 20, 1872,Evening Post,2</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to settle on an area of public land before acquiring a legal right to it; to occupy Maori (or Crown) without any legal title (cf. SQUATTER n1). squatter a) History: a runholder who originally held land by squatting. b) a rich farmer; a station-owner. (absol or constr with on)

>  It was a fine back-scratching celebration of the triumph of Reform which Squatter Hugh Campbell gave to the squatters, squatterines and appendages down in Hastings recently. <i>(Feb 8, 1913,NZ Observer,4</i>)



## Squatterland
 
 <i>n.</i> Hawke's Bay

>  [Leading article] SQUATTERLAND: ironic term for Hawkes Bay in which a dozen big landowners were said to have monopolised the bulk of the land during its early settlement. `Here in Upper Hutt the bulk of the land is also held by a dozen holders who, as was the case in Squatterland, steadfastly put up a fight for stagnation and oppose all progressive movements ... ' <i>(Sep 7, 1912,Hutt Valley Independent,1</i>)



## squatters meeting
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a horse race meeting organised and patronised by the squatters of Canterbury.

>  <b>ELDRED-GRIGG</b> It was known as the 'Squatters meeting' because of its gentry patrons, but all classes turned out to cheer. <i>(1980,Southern Gentry,96</i>)



## squatting
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural, historical) the occupation or leasing of pastoral land without ownership.

>  They seem to point out a very wide tract of open and fertile country available for the purposes of settling or squatting, where colonists might take their flocks and herds, and have the opportunity of readily communicating with Port Nicholson for the disposal of their surplus produce by the Wanganui. <i>(Nov 28, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3</i>)

>  1st. Can the pursuit of sheep-farming or squatting be recommended as a safe one at present in the North Island? 2nd. Is there grass land in possession of the Government available for that purpose, and if so how is it let, and at what price per run or per 1,000 acres? <i>(Jul 24, 1872,Daily Southern Cross,3</i>)

>  Squatting will now become the order of things in New Zealand, as well as in New South Wales; but with this difference in favour of this country, that the squatter requires no license in this country; that his sheep and cattle are always secure under the protection of the natives, with his own superintendance [sic]. <i>(Jun 24, 1843,Daily Southern Cross,3</i>)

>  Squatting and farming operations must now command attention - genuine ploughmen trained to all farm work are decidedly scarce. <i>(Sep 26, 1879,NZ Tablet,16</i>)

>  <b>WELD</b> ... I have referred chiefly to sheep-farming on wild pasture, generally held under licence from the Crown, in fact to what by an incorrect use of an Australian term, is usually called 'squatting.' <i>(1860,Hints to Intending Sheep-Farmers in New Zealand,31</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> .. the country was unfenced and in those days of 'squatting' there was virtually no limit to the areas which these early runholders might occupy. <i>(1973,Big Country of the South Island,141</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (See [cf. squat v](../S#squat-v))

>  Mr.Bidwill has started with sheep and cattle and Messrs. Clifford and Vavasour are about to send sheep and cattle there immediately. Squatting is evidently the order of the day. <i>(Apr 24, 1844,NZ Gazette</i>) [NOTES: 1844 April 24 `NZ Gazette' in 1956 Gore Levins 13]

>  <b>HURSTHOUSE</b> ... he will obtain a fair idea of the <i> first profits </i>of Squatting begun on a small scale and on a moderate scale. <i>(1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/400</i>)

>  That irregular occupation of native land [before extinction of title, or true sale], commonly designated as `squatting', which it is understood is now becoming the practice of European emigrants to New Zealand. <i>(1846,On the British Colonisation of NZ,vi</i>)



 
 <i>adj.</i> descriptive of actions of a squatter

>  The few large squatting freeholders, enjoying the land on that Branch, not content with the monoply [sic] they have already acquired, are moving the spheres to get a railway to inhance [sic] the value of their properties, while this populous district must needs be left out in the cold ... <i>(Oct 10, 1872,Tuapeka Times,8</i>)

>  The case of Glassford <i>v.</i> the Tinkers' miners appears to be another of the many bold attempts of the great squatting community to encroach upon the priviliges [sic] of their fellow settlers. <i>(May 9, 1874,Tuapeka Times,3</i>)

>  "Its [sic] a Pity's" letter also appears to contain a covert attempt to set class against class, for in advocating a selection from the gentlemen he mentions he distinctly confines himself to the old squatting element. <i>(Jul 8, 1884,Timaru Herald,3</i>)

>  I must say, when I came to New Zealand, in charge of the Bank of New Zealand I found that the bank was most lamentably deficient in its squatting connection. <i>(Oct 15, 1888,Wanganui Herald,2</i>)

>  In a recent issue of your paper I observed an article headed "Nokomai," in which your reporter states that "the squatting regulations are said to have driven the miners away" from this place, giving at the same time an instance in which this "arbitrary power" has been exercised in the case of a miner named Edge, who, says your reporter, by dint of steady perseverance had acquired "a few head of cattle," which the runholder caused him to remove under penalty of impounding for tresspass. <i>(Dec 12, 1868,Otago Witness,3</i>)

>  Talking of squatting property the other day, the Grenville Advocate was told by a party just returned from Camperdown that Mr Manifold, a land owner in that part of the colony, had been offered by an English company L1,500,000 for his property in that district, and that the offer had been refused. <i>(Sep 25, 1869,Otago Witness,15</i>)

>  The wicked special in question, a few days ago, wired up to the Squatting Metropolis a bogus speech purporting to have been delivered to the House by the Squatting Representative, in which the Government policy and the orator's XXX beer were lauded sky high, while the bursting up of large estates and the imposition of an export tax on frozen mutton and wool were advocated in the best interest of the beer trade and the good of the colony at large. <i>(Jul 18, 1891,Observer (Auckland),7</i>)

>  <b>SEWELL</b> He is jealous of Clifford and the Squatters - is addicted to Landscrip, Town Acres and Rural Sections, and therefore I can see evidently has a leaning in favor [sic] of cheap land. ... I suspect he gives the matter up, contenting himself with sinking his squatting interest in the equally lucrative pursuit of land and scrip jobbing. <i>(1853,Journal,1/189,1980 ed.</i>)

>  The squatting [interest] is the most important. <i>(1856,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1856 Waitt Letter to Joseph Thomas 12]

>  <b>HURSTHOUSE</b> [The squatter] rudely breeds, feeds, clips, and fattens his flock, under what is popularly termed the `Squatting system'. <i>(1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/197</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> The people we meet at our hotel [in Dunedin] seem entirely of the squatting class with a few regular town residents. The squatters are decidedly the nicest and most gentlemanly class. <i>(Feb 6, 1873,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1873 Feb 6 G.M.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 170]

>  <b>LADY BARKER</b> F- had ... many other squatting interests to attend to. <i>(1873,Station Amusements in NZ,93</i>)

>  <b>MEREDITH</b> farming (here pig-f) While the maize and pigs are grazing, I am filling my time with anything that will earn money, as I am very serious about this squatting project, which looks all right - ... <i>(1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,163,1953 ed.</i>)

>  <b>PURNELL</b> ... the squatting interest. <i>(1897,NZ Confederation, The,9</i>)

>  <b>DIEFFENBACH</b> A <i>squatting </i> population, therefore, living apart from each other, but connected by a safe water communication, are the best pioneers for a colonization of that part of Cook's Straits. Shipbuilders also should choose a position in Queen Charlotte's Sound where they can command a great variety of useful timber. <i>(1843,Travels in NZ,1/187</i>)

 <i>n.</i>

## squatting licence
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  That would not have been the case if the extension had not been granted, and many of the squatting licenses had only a few years to run - some only two or three - when they would be open for lease again, and more likely fetch a shilling an acre rental than twopence. <i>(Jul 3, 1867,Southland Times,2</i>)

>  The nature of their tenure was what the Maoris term "he noho noa iho" - to stay without restraint in the place mentioned, equivalent to a "squatting license" - (Southern Districts, p.86.) <i>(Oct 13, 1909,Otago Witness,63</i>)

## squatting system
 
 <i>n.</i> [aka squatter system]

>  The land reformer who opposed the squatting system which gave the pastoral tenant a small principality at a nominal rent, argued with energy and ability, that by adopting a methodic system of cultivation [sic] English and other grasses on pastoral land, the productiveness of the land would be increased tenfold, and prove a preventative to scab, and the other diseases that afflict stock that are kept for a length of time on virgin pasture. <i>(Dec 31, 1866,Southland Times,2</i>)

>  I am as warmly a land reformer as ever I was, but I am less hopeful of seeing an end to the squatting system than formerly. <i>(Apr 18, 1874,Otago Daily Times,5</i>)

>  He quoted from published lectures of the late Lord Lyttelton, certain experiences of his Lordship during a visit to Canterbury in 1868, when he visited a run of Mr Charles Harper, which run contained about 50,000 acres, and explains the old squatting system, with pre-emptive rights, spotting sections, &c., all of which will be familiar to Hawke's Bay readers. <i>(May 21, 1885,Hawke's Bay Herald,4</i>)



## squattocracy
 
 <i>n.</i> a. the party of wealthy sheepfarmers as a political force

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> The class of run-holders ... comprises for the most part men of refinement and education, and they are nicknamed by the [anti-squatter] Liberal Party the `Squatocracy', from the word squatter which is also a name frequently applied to them. <i>(1874,Colonial Experiences,205</i>)

>  <b>MORRIS</b> squatters collectively. <i>(1898,Austral English,434</i>)

>  The municipal muddlers in that centre of snobbery and squatocracy [Napier]. <i>(Aug 12, 1905,NZ Truth,8/1/7</i>)

>  We used often to talk about the plains of the Wairarapa as being likely to be monopolized by the squattocracy, instead of being laid open to the classes whose labour on that fertile territory would soon double the wealth of our Province and the population of our Capital town. <i>(Oct 4, 1854,New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian,2</i>)

>  "As a polititian he is a failure. A nominee of a squatocratic Government cannot be beneficial to a mining community. The squatocracy of New Zealand, as in the neighbouring colonies, care little for those who earn their bread by toiling in the earth for minerals ..." <i>(Mar 24, 1883,Wanganui Herald,2</i>)

>  The Otago Squatocracy ... <i>(1864,Saturday Review,IV/13</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> b. (?hist) the ruling class of large sheep-farmers

>  They are serious squatocracy. Waiting for the young couple was the Williams family's Matahiia Station, covering 3500 acres outside Ruatoria. <i>(Oct 1988,North & South,64</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>squattocracy </i> wealthy landowners who assume aristocratic airs. NZA. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,107</i>)

>  <b>CAMERON</b> He [the Christchurch inhabitant] is thought ... to inhabit an illusory world of colonial gentry, in keeping with the cultural pretensions of the Canterbury `squattocracy' for whom this city is the urban center, ... <i>(1965,New Zealand (various authors/titles),81</i>)

 <i>n.</i>

## St Peter's fish
 
 <i>n.</i> John Dory

>  <b>PHILLIPPS</b> CAESIOPERCA LEPIDOPTERA (Forster).</i> Red Perch </i>. Called `red snapper' or `St. Peter's fish' in Queen Charlotte and Pelorus Sounds, where it is occasionally taken in the seine net during July and August. ... Distribution* North island coasts and northern coasts of the South Island. <i>(Jun 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4/115</i>)

>  <b>PAUL et al.</b> [index to common names 283-293] St Peter's fish 1040, 1260 <i>(1987,Fishes: A Bibliography</i>)

>  <b>PARROT</b> The Red Perch, as is the case with many of our common fishes, has received many popular names. .../ It is also known as the `Red Snapper', `St. Peter's Fish' or `Butterfly Perch' It probably received the name of `St. Peter's Fish' on account of the two black marks, one on each side of the body, which suggest the thumb/and finger marks of St. Peter, as I have previously explained in the case of the John Dory. <i>(1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,73</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> JOHN DORY <i>Zeus japonicus</i>: A member of the family Zeidae, of which there are at least 6 species in New Zealand waters. Also known as St Peter's fish of kuparu (Maori). <i>Ibid.</i> 204ST. PETER'S FISH <i>another name for John Dory</i> <i>(1981,Fisherman's Bible,129</i>)

>  <b>PARROTT</b> The large circular mark on each side of the body of the John Dory gave rise in earlier days to the tradition that this fish represented the species from which St. Peter obtained tribute money; the spot on either side being regarded as inherited marks left by the Apostle's finger and thumb... Unfortunately for this interesting legend the John Dory does not inhabit the lake whence St. Peter's fish was said to have been taken. <i>(1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,55</i>)

>  <b>DOOGUE & MORELAND</b> John Dory... <i>Zeus japonicus</i>; St Peter's fish, Kuparu. <i>(1960,Sea Anglers' Guide,201</i>)

>  <b>FOORD</b> BUTTERFLY PERCH. <i>Cassioperca lepidoptera</i>... Red perch... Red snapper... St Peter's Fish. <i>Ibid.</i> 207 JOHN DORY. <i>Zeus japonicus</i>... Kuparu... St. Peter's Fish. <i>(1990,NZ Descriptive Animal Dictionary,76</i>)

## stamp
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>McARA</b> <i>Stamps</i>: The stamps pulverised the ore after it had passed through the crushers and been reduced to minus-two-and-a-half-inch size. They crushed it to a pulp, with water, until it passed through the 10-mesh (to the linear inch) screens on the mortar-box. There were five stamps (each weighing 1250 lb) to a mortar-box and they operated at 110 drops a minute from a height of 8 ins, crushing approximately 7 tons per 24-hour-day. They were driven by a camshaft, tappets attached to the long stamp stems being lifted in a particular sequence and then the whole weight of the stamp allowed to fall on the ore. Wear of iron was approximately half a pound per ton of ore crushed; the shoes and dies were cast in the Waikino foundry. <i>(1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),333</i>)

>  <b>NOLAN</b> <i>Stamp</i>: a heavy weight, operated by machinery, used to crush ore in a stamping battery. <i>(1983,Gold Fossicker's Handbook,113</i>)

>  <i>Station, n.</i> Sometimes <i>sheep s., cattle- s.</i>, or <i>dairy-s</i>., (PAUL, p. 68); originally the hut, yards, and buildings where a squatter stationed himself to work his run; but now usually the whole property, including the stock and leasehold country. It has been used in both these senses in Australia (whence the word came) since the 'thirties. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) (1) The original sense is still preserved up country, where the men always speak of <i>in at the s</i>., when they are out on the run; also in the word <i>out-s</i>. (q.v.), which has no other meaning than the house, yards etc. (2) The secondary sense of a property with freehold, leasehold, buildings, and stock. (3) Any fairly large property, carrying over 2000 or 3000 sheep. (4) Adjective as in s.horse, belonging to the owner, not to one of the man, whose horses are<i> private; s. sheep</i>, not one belonging to a neighbour; <i>s.-bred,</i> not a bought sheep. (5) Since the 1890s, auctioneers in their advertisements have taken to speaking of <i>s. lines</i> of sheep, though 70 per cent. of those so designated at the autumn ewe fairs come from farms or grazing runs. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) <i>(Dec 16, 1933,Press, The,21</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> The custom in the old days was to call the buildings on a run `the station,' and the land that went with it was `the run.' On a big property you could find several `stations,' and the principal one was called `the home station,' while the others were `out-stations.' This was the old Australian usage which was carried over to New Zealand at first, but gradually the signification was altered by loosely calling the whole run a station, and then the real station became a homestead and the out-stations became shepherds' huts. In this present book it will be noticed that generally the writer has preserved the olden custom of calling the main buildings the station and the land the run. The runs over in Australia being, as a rule, much larger than those in New Zealand, the `station' and `out-station' phraseology was preserved much longer than over here, where even in advertisements in the late `fifties we see the English word `homestead' ousting the colonial word `station.' <i>(1947,Early Runholding in Otago,11</i>)

>  It is usually understood that in the early days the word `station' denoted the owner's house and its immediate buildings, while `run' meant the whole property. Strange to say, I only noted the word `station' twice, and each time with a diverse meaning. On July 21, 1865, the diary says: `Sold 17 head of cattle - remaining on station 15 head.' Then on September 11, 1865, we read: `Wilkinson returned to the Home Station.' The first of these entries means the whole run - the second the homestead or main buildings. <i>(Jul 21, 1856,Puketoi Station Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 115 quoting 1856 July 21 Puketoi Station Diary]

So aghast was I that I spent weeks collecting every old term for `runholders' I could, and I found thirteen, viz., `flock owners,' `flock masters,' `pastoralists,' `run holders,' `run owners,' `sheep owners,' `sheep holders,' `sheep masters,' `squatters,' `station holders,' `station owners,' `stock holders,[sic] and `stock owners.'  <i>v.</i> (See [cf. stick up to](../S#stick-up-to))
