## stick up
 
 <i>v.</i> to book up on credit; to put on the slate; to chalk up [ca1949 (Havelock) Commonly used in booking up groceries]

>  <b>THATCHER</b> The loafer ... you'll find in hotels often lingers/ And orders a glass on the bounce./ `Stick it up, you know me, it's all right' <i>(1865,Colonial Songster,30</i>)

>  <b>THATCHER</b> The loafer who ne'er soils his fingers, And of gold who won't work for an ounce, You'll find in hotels often lingers, And orders a glass on the bounce. And his tumbler with brandy half filling, He'll drink and commence then to skite; And replies when he's asked for the shilling, `Stick it up, you know me, it's all right.' <i>(1875,NZ Songster,No.3/69</i>)

>  <b>McKEE WRIGHT</b> [He was] sticking up his tucker at the store. <i>(1897,Station Ballads,19</i>) [NOTES: (`Prospector')]

>  <b>ELKINGTON</b> We then `stick up' provisions in the store. <i>(1906,Adrift in NZ,244</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>stick up</i> to delay, hold up or bring to a standstill; used in shearing; eg `We could do without this stick up, now we're certain to be late.' <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,107</i>)

>  The Ashburton Club travelled in an express with four horses, and one of the incidents of the journey was a "stick up" in the river. <i>(May 26, 1896,Ashburton Guardian,3</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> in phr. stuck up with porpoises: of a whale, to be slowed by playful porpoises

>  <b>GRADY</b> <i>Stuck-up with porpoises</i> - Porpoises that have slowed a swimming whale down by playing with it. This assisted the whalers. <i>(1982,Perano Whalers</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to bring (a vehicle, thing, a person, a job) to a standstill (often in passive form: be, get stuck up) [(1) The regular word for the action of bush-rangers stopping passers-by on the highway and robbing them.(2) In the case of a bank or a station, simply to rob. [1846] (3) Humorously applied to a collector or a beggar. In `Twenty - five Years of St. Andrews' (vol. ii. p. 87), A. K. H. B. tells a story of a church dignitary, who was always collecting money for church building. When a ghost appeared at Glamis Castle, addressing the ghost, the clergyman began - that `he was most anxious to raise money for a church he was erecting; that he had a bad cold and could not well get out of bed; but that his collecting-book was on the dressing-table, and he would be `extremely obliged' for a subscription.' An Australian would have said he `stuck up' the ghost for a subscription. [1890]]

>  - if you get stuck up by any creeks you'll very likely see cattle marks ... (a creek is a stream) but there is nothing that ought to stick you up at all if you keep out of the big swamp at the bottom of the valley. <i>(Jun 1860,Forest Flora,37,1960 ed.</i>)

>  The cow and steers stuck us up at the yards so we left them in the paddock. <i>(Jul 9, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,47,1950 ed.</i>)

>  An old cow stuck me up about a mile from the stockyard ... Millett and I worked our whips well on her. When she rushed one, the other stock-whipped her. <i>(Feb 21, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,78,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>BUTLER</b> At last we came to a waterfall. This `stuck us up', as they say here concerning any difficulty. <i>(1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,64</i>)

>  <b>MEREDITH</b> We started all right [on our journey], but had not got beyond the city boundary when the horses stuck us up. <i>(1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,80,1935 ed.</i>)

>  <b>WHITWORTH</b> ... when we told him ... we'd been stuck up by the water, he ... said ... `Ah, stuck up, were you?' <i>(1879,Spangles and Sawdust,26</i>)

>  <b>REID</b> Push on or you will be stuck up. Not by bushrangers, ... but by time and tide which wait for no man. At the first opportunity he `stuck up the mail' ... merely to secure a passage to town <i>(1884,Rambles on the Golden Coast,73</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> Far more often have the rivers to be forded, as is the case with the Otira ... where ... it is so wild that the coaches are sometimes `stuck up' for days, lest in trying to cross they should be washed away. <i>(Jun 3, 1894,In the Land of the Tui,88</i>)

>  <b>HARPER</b> At present, owing to the unbridged state of the rivers and frequent rain, there is great risk of loss of time by being `stuck up' by floods. <i>(1896,Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ,32</i>)

>  <b>MACDONALD</b> These places taken together with frequently flooded rivers ..., often `sticking us up' for hours or days at a time. <i>(1910,Reminiscences,19</i>)

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> The back blocks of Southland are not inaccessible places. Until you are stuck up by the great West Coast mountains ... you can get round ... <i>(1913,Trade Hunting,[12]</i>)

>  <b>DAVIDSON</b> The only drawback to these trips was the likelihood of being stuck up now and then by flooded rivers. <i>(1930,Sketch of His Life,75</i>)

>  <i>Stick up</i>.- Bring to a standstill. (A bushranger was said to s.u. his victims.) `If you get stuck up by any creeks ... you'll very likely see cattle marks by following the creek up and down.' (Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p. 143; [1898 Morris Austral-English]). <i>(Dec 16, 1933,Press, The</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>MASTERS</b> When they got stuck up in trying to get over the saddle, as they invariably did, they naturally made back to get him to help them over with his horses. <i>(1959,Tales of the Mails,25</i>)

>  You see there was a judgement summons up against me and I stuck up Dr. McArthur, as I thought, in the street and explained to him if my name went in the papers and ward saw it, he might stick up my promotion. <i>(Dec 13, 1902,New Zealand Free Lance,14</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to hold up (a job, etc.)

>  Commenced shearing. Meikana and Piripi Nehu as press men stuck me up. I gave them five minutes and sacked them. ... I put on young Wood as pressman as he was near at hand ... and put on my two station boys as fleece boys. The shed did not stop one minute. <i>(Nov 4, 1889,Chudleigh Diary,368,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>DAVIN</b> You might want it to coax Pompey [a ferret] out if he sticks you up. <i>(1949,Roads from Home,161</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to refuse to sail (a vessel)

>  <b>PUGH WIL.LIAMS</b> <i>stick her up</i>: used among seamen when they refuse to sail a vessel. <i>(1951,Letter</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to stop dead; to be hindered from proceeding

>  The river was very high ..., having got over that you had to walk some way and then get into a bullock dray and cross a branch that people at home [sc. England] would look at a long time ..., the bullocks sticking up in the middle each time. <i>(Nov 4, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,203,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>TUCKER</b> We passed only two vehicles on the road - one being an old coach `stuck up' two years ago and left. <i>(1884,Letter from Abroad,83</i>)

>  <b>CHAMIER</b> ... one cursed lot [of sheep] stuck up in the middle of the stream. <i>Ibid.</i> 429 <i>(1891,Philosopher Dick,247</i>)

>  Two drays belonging to the Messrs. Baird of Waikouaiti, were the first to be "stuck up" in this manner, and though a stout resistance was made, the drivers were compelled to yield, and the flour was sold at the price dictated by the diggers, viz., 1s. 6d. per lb. <i>(Sep 9, 1862,Otago Daily Times,5</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to bail up (pigs)

>  <b>MEREDITH</b> It sometimes takes up to half an hour to scramble through the rough gullies to where the dogs have the pig stuck up. If the bulldog were released before reaching the quarry, he would `go in' at once, and would probably be exhausted with holding the pig before we could get there, and possibly get killed. A bailed-up pig makes periodical rushes at the baiting dogs, ... <i>Ibid.</i> 97 In the morning our dogs stuck up a mob of pigs on a small, clear-topped rise. <i>(1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,64,1935 ed.</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>v.</i> to accost (a person for a favour) [ca1951 Wellington He stuck us up for a donation]

>  <b>BODELL</b> ... one day he passed my store and I stuck him up and asked for my money, ... <i>(1890,Soldier's View of Empire, A,211,1982 ed.</i>)

>  <b>THOMPSON</b> ... he ... shtuck me oop in street ... und borrowed the rhino to file. <i>(1909,Ballads about Business,11</i>)

>  <b>HARPER</b> Suppose we stick him up tomorrow [sc. about a job]. <i>(1934,Windy Island,236</i>)

>  <b>SARGESON</b> stuck: <i>stuck him up (on the street)</i>, accosted him;<i> stuck up (by the police),</i> questioned. <i>(1964,Collected Stories,303</i>)

>  <b>BURGESS</b> ... had he attempted to stick him up Mr Fox would have shot him dead. <i>(1866,Confessions,107,1983 ed.</i>)

>  <b>FARJEON</b> `We can stick up the escort in the Black Forest', he ses ... <i>(1866,Grif: a Story of Colonial Life,7</i>)

>  <b>CLAYDON</b> I was `stuck up' - to use a favourite colonial expression - by a newly arrived immigrant from England, in a New Zealand city not long ago, and asked ... <i>(1886,Popular Handbook to NZ,10</i>)

>  You see there was a judgement summons out against me and I stuck up Dr. McArthur, as I thought, in the street and explained to him if my name went in the papers and Ward saw it, he might stick up my promotion. <i>(Dec 13, 1902,NZ Free Lance,14</i>)



 
<b>3</b> <i>v.</i> to hold up (a person or vehicle) and rob on the highway; thence, to rob (a bank)

>  <b>WEKEY</b> The consequence [of many leaving ill-equipped] was, that some of those who carried up provisions with them were `stuck up' on the road, and the principles of communism were practically realised on the way to the Dunstan El Dorado. The first detachment of gold-seekers gradually arrived ... <i>(1862,Otago As It Is,51</i>)

>  Two of them enter[ed] the bank after the hour of closing ... `sticking them up' <i>(1855,Maungatapu Murders,11</i>)

>  <b>NESFIELD</b> Burgess ... insisted on `sticking' the old fellow up. <i>(1881,Chequered Career,79</i>)

>  <i>Stick</i> (st&ibreve.k), <i>v. t. [Add.] To stick up. (a)</i> To detain, especially on the highway, for the purpose of robbing; as, <i>to stick up</i> a traveler or a mail coach. <i>(b)</i> To rob on the highway; also, to rob, in general. <i>(c) </i>To apply to, for money, for one's signature for a petition, or the like. <i>[Colloq.] (d)</i> to accost in the street. <i>[Colloq.] (e)</i> To pose; to puzzle. <i>[Colloq.] </i> <i>(1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2031</i>)

>  <i>stick ... stickup</i> v.t. to hold up and rob; <i>(1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,11</i>)

>  <i>v.tr.</i> of bushrangers, to hold up and rob: whence sticker-up a bushranger: by extension any such hold-up, as of a bank. <i>(1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),625</i>)

>  <i>stick-up v.t.</i> of bushrangers, to hold up and rob; whence sticker-up, bushranger; by extension any such hold-up, as of a bank. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),18</i>)

>  A local business man states that on Monday night he was stuck up by a local man with two revolvers, who apparently was not clear as to what he was doing. <i>(Apr 13, 1910,Hawera & Normanby Star,5</i>)

>  The escort is not considered safe by the diggers, who decline sending gold in bulk with an insufficient guard, to be almost certainly "stuck up" on its way to Dunedin. <i>(Sep 20, 1861,Daily Southern Cross,3</i>)

>  A sensation has been caused in this district by a Maori being struck up by an armed man at Waihua Hill, Napier road, and relieved of his horse, saddle and bridle. <i>(Oct 30, 1906,Hawera & Normanby Star,5</i>)

>  On their way they called at the smithy, stuck up the blacksmith, and took from his chest some articles of clothing and provisions, besides a double-barrelled gun, powder and shot; one rummaging the cottage, while the other stood sentry at the door. <i>(Nov 18, 1857,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,3</i>)

>  A[b]out nine miles from the Armed Constabulary station, the coach was stuck up by twenty or thirty natives, who rescued the prisoner from the Armed Constabulary escort. <i>(Sep 12, 1877,Evening Post,2</i>)



 
<b>3</b> <i>v.</i> to run up; knock up

## sticker
 
 <i>n.</i> fillet

>  FILLET, used as a noun only. <i>(1952,NZ Forest Glossary</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

 <i>n.</i> a notice of a traffic offence (usually gummed onto the vehicle or `stuck' under a windscreen wiper); a bluey

 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a holder or hunting dog that keeps hold of its bail.

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a slaughterer of stock.

He is still called this when killing sheep though these do not receive a stab-like thrust as do the cattle or the pigs .. retain it in a suitable position for the sticker's grisly stroke. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,78</i>)

## sticking box
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a device that holds one beast at a time for slaughtering.

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> sticking box: a device which holds one beast at a time, so designed that it can roll its victim on its side and retain it in a suitable position for the sticker's grisly stroke .. sticking pen: that one which feeds the sheep into the sticking box. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,78</i>)



## sticking pen
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a small enclosure to hold stock for slaughter.

>  <b>SLATTER</b> The sticking-pen far below me down the tunnelled slope from the top of the ramp. From there comes the pained lowing of goaded cattle and the sharp crack of the lethal hammer wielded by the nonchalant bloke leaning over his platform above the trapped beast. <i>Ibid.</i> 67 I'd like to see them ... racing the chain, that remorseless heartless chain. And when the last is scrubbed and the chain is switched off, going down for a shower ... I'd like to see them on the chain. Even the learners' chain. In that narrow cell of concrete with the lambs swinging in quick time up the ramp from the sticking-pen ... Lambs hooked on to the chain and progressing slowly along while the row of men standing alongside slash and tear and nick with knives while others punch briskets or pull the skins from the swinging carcases. More men rip out the guts and throw the heart and liver on to the small-goods table ... and the skins and innards and hooves and ears all go by chutes to the departments below. <i>Ibid.</i> 227 The tourists ... never see the dogs running over the backs of the sheep jammed in the saleyards or the pet sheep leading them slyly up the ramp into the sticking pen at the works ... <i>(1958,Gun in My Hand, A,12</i>)

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> sticking pen: that one which feeds the sheep into the sticking box. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,78</i>)

>  <b>KERR</b> Freezing works yarders reward an individual sheep, called the Judas sheep, to lead others to the sticking pen. <i>(2000,High Times in the High Country,82</i>)

 <i>n.</i> a minke whale

>  <b>GRADY</b> [glossary] <i>Stickleback</i> - A minke whale. <i>Balaenoptera acutorostrata.</i> The Peranos killed only one of these. They found them uneconomic to hunt. The stickleback was also sometimes called the pike whale by the Perano whalers. <i>(1982,Perano Whalers,228</i>)

## sticky weed
 
 <i>n.</i> catchfly

>  <b>HILGENDORF</b> CATCHFLY (<i>silene [gallica</i>]). Varieties of this species have been named S.anglica and S.quinque vulnera. [1967 quinquevulnera] Common names are spotted catchfly, flycatcher, sticky weed, and five wounds. It is common in cultivated land and waste places such as gravelly river-beds throughout both islands. ... The flowers are white or often dark red, or sometimes white with a blood red blotch on each petal so that this variety is called <i>quinque vulnera</i>, `five wounds' <i>(1926,Weeds of New Zealand,74</i>)

The `Grab your dumps' was the roar, as we all rushed in for our own, and anybody else's one could get. <i>(1943,Pure Gold,22</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies. <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,174</i>)

>  <b>KEITH & MAIN</b> Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, [sic] chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles. <i>(1984,Yesterdays in Maoriland,288</i>)

>  Stinkies - these were marbles made from clay, they did not work very well. <i>(1987,Alfredton,75</i>) [NOTES: Quote from c1935]

>  <b>ADSETT</b> Sixpence was a hell of a lot of money when you come to think of it. Worth about twenty marbles, more if they were only stinkies. <i>(1962,Magpie Sings, A,124</i>)

## stirabout
 
 <i>n.</i> a thin gruel made of flour, sugar, and boiling water (See [lillipee](../L#lillipee))

>  One day the native cooks opened the bag of lime, thinking it was flour, and proceeded to mix it with water and sugar, in order to provide "stirabout" or "lillipee," dear to the palate of the Maori. <i>(Apr 13, 1912,NZ Free Lance,5</i>)

>  <b>SELWYN</b> This [promise] gave huge satisfaction as did a great supply of stirabout, simply ordinary Paste with sugar, which I brought forward. <i>(1961,Reminiscences,23</i>) [NOTES: 1842 in 1961]

>  <b>LAMBERT</b> ... porridge, or as the Irish people [in Ireland] call it, `stirabout'] <i>(1936,Old Wairoa,4</i>)

>  <b>BRERETON</b> Irishisms were in daily use, one was pronounced `wan', clothes `cloes', an apron was a `praskeen', an idiot was an `omadhaun', to be naughty was to be `bold' ... and porridge `stirabout' <i>(1947,No Roll of Drums,69</i>)

>  <b>BURTON</b> '..[sic] twenty pots of stirabout' (Stirabout, otherwise known as lillipee, consisted simply of flour and sugar mixed together with a little a boiled water.) [part from Marianne Williams's journal] <i>(1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,17</i>)

>  <b>WILLIAMS</b> Gave out some flour for stir-about and concluded peace [with the Maoris]. <i>(Apr 16, 1829,Journal,152,1961 ed.</i>)

>  His sick wife had a mess of stirabout and a piece of salt beef, according to her particular request. [ed fn] A mixture of flour and water sweetened with sugar, of which the Maoris were very fond. The Maori name was <i> kororirori </i>. <i>(Jul 30, 1828,Journal</i>) [NOTES: check year]

>  <b>WILLIAMS</b> Some of our friends expressed a wish for some stir-about, and as the boys had caught a great quantity of fish we did not hesitate to comply with their request. <i>(Jan 13, 1832,Journal,217,1961 ed.</i>)

>  I gave them some flour with which they manufactured <i>stir about</i> and soon finished it using their fingers for spoons. <i>(Nov 13, 1839,Journal,42/168</i>) [NOTES: Full dateline missing]

>  Our barrel of meal gives us stirabout and oaten bread daily. <i>(1851,Canterbury Papers,2/310</i>)

>  <b>MOSER</b> In that state it [rotten corn] is boiled in water, and made into `stir-a-bout', and I have been told it has a strong taste of old Stilton cheese. <i>(1863,Mahoe Leaves,22</i>)

>  <b>PRENTICE</b> .. a hearty breakfast of oatmeal stir-about. <i>(1879,Tale of NZ,59</i>)

>  <b>GRACE</b> `Begorra, sir, there is no stirabout and milk in this country at all, at all; ...' <i>(1899,Sketch of the NZ War,23</i>)

>  One family resisted desperately, using pitchforks and boiling "stirabout." <i>(Aug 25, 1902,Hawera & Normanby Star,2</i>)

>  <b>HUTT</b> Popular among pre-1840 Bay of islands Maori was 'stirabout', a boiled mixture of flour, sugar and water. <i>(1999,Maori & Alcohol,14</i>)

>  Tents were then pitched, and the food brought in, which consisted of 72 pigs, 150 kits potatoes, and 10 large troughs of a kind of stirabout, made from rye, &c. <i>(Oct 1, 1870,Otago Witness,4</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> [cheese stirabout]

>  <i>CHEESE STIRABOUT </i> ... oatmeal ... salt ... cheese (cut up) ... mustard ... water ... stir it all the time ... <i>(1902,Brett's Colonists Guide,852</i>)



## stirrer
 
 <i>n.</i> [First heard by HWO in the early 1970s in Wellington, and possibly popularised by frequent use applied to Robert Muldoon on account of his aggressive style]

>  You will be told that we are men discontented and factious - stirrers of sedition - rebels against established authority. <i>(Apr 16, 1842,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,23</i>)

>  That an agent should be employed to transmit intelligence, who is notoriously the mouthpiece of certain cliques, and subservient to the influence of certain individuals, while he is the stirrer up of strife between local bodies, and at the same time the exponent of the views of a member of the most unreliable ministry New Zealand has ever seen, is simply unheard of. <i>(May 16, 1878,Wanganui Chronicle,2</i>)

>  Nearly all low-income earners are trade unionists and we all know what trade unionists are - commie stirrers determined to bring down the government. <i>(Nov 6, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),80</i>)

>  These changes were often spearheaded by blind "stirrers" and "trouble makers". <i>(May 31, 1992,Dominion Sunday Times,24</i>)

>  Debate is of course an essential step in the development of geological ideas, and most of us owe a great deal to the many stirrers, and to the arch-stirrer himself, of that time. <i>(Oct 1980,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,50/3</i>)

>  <i>stirrer ... NZ & Austral. colloq.</i> political agitator, troublemaker. <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,755</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 474]]

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>stirrer </i> troublemaker, especially in politics; eg `Parkin, gentlemen, is just your typical union stirrer, kneejerk demands every time he opens his agricultural mouth.' NZA. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,108</i>)

>  Mr Skinner, on the subject of new industrial legislation, described Mr Muldoon as a `stirrer' <i>(Oct 24, 1972,Radio NZ / National Radio</i>) [NOTES: Oct 24 2YA Wellington, 8.30 p.m. national news]

>  He was not afraid of authority but he was not a stirrer. His provocations were incidental to caring for the losers who came to him, for shelter or for guidance. <i>(Oct 25, 1972,Dominion,4</i>)

>  So Bob Jones wrote a blank book ... and got a well known stirrer to help launch it - ... <i>(Mar 20, 1974,Dominion,Cartoon in 1982 Jones Letters 26</i>)

>  <b>SINCLAIR</b> The men behind the abortive coup were the remnants of the credit reformers, or Leeites, in the caucus of the 1930s: Mason (who detested Nash), Bill Anderton, and Nordmeyer who, while probably never a creditite, had been numbered in the ranks of the dissidents as an ambitious young `stirrer'. <i>(1976,Nash,292</i>)

>  No stirrers need apply...The SIS are looking for recruits. <i>(Nov 24, 1979,Listener (New Zealand Listener),113</i>)

>  <b>LELAND</b> <i>stirrer:</i> short for shitstirrer, a TROBLEMAKER of you don't agree with them, a crusader if you do. <i>(1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,97</i>)

>  <b>KENNEDY</b> Was the barman right when he said that outside `stirrers' were to blame? <i>(1981,Straight from the Shoulder,24</i>)

>  <b>HULME</b> Going flat on his face in the slime, I couldn't give a damn for him, the two-faced stirrer, going to the police behind everyone's back ... [sic] <i>(1983,Bone People, The,395</i>)

>  <b>SINCLAIR</b> By 1939 the leading academic agnostic, stirrer, and radical, and soon `establishment figure', `Tommy' Hunter of Victoria, was knighted. <i>(1983,History of the University of Auckland, A,151</i>)

>  <b>MITCALFE</b> `And, if it's jus' the paper "stirring", what then?' ... `Now you jus' a "stirrer" too,' said Vaine. <i>(1985,Hey Hey Hey,108</i>)

>  We don't have enough agitators and stirrers left in society and in the art world, artists have to be more and more well-behaved. <i>(Jul 16, 2000,Sunday Star Times,F5</i>)

>  Public apathy, centralised power, censorship, a mindless hostility towards "stirrers" and an almost continuous stream of old movies on television. <i>(Jul 24, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),90</i>)

>  <b>GRANT</b> Once a Pommy stirrer, always a Pommystirrer. <i>(1979,I Rode with the Epigrams,19</i>)



## stitchbird
 
 <i>n.</i> aka hihi, <i>Notiomystis cincta</i> (See [hihi](../H#hihi))

>  Sir Walter [Buller] confirmed the storyof there being over 80 specimens of thestitchbird in the Tring Museum... For aperiod of 10 months prior to theprotective proclamation two men wereliving on [Little Barrier] island doingnothing all the time but collectingstitchbirds, which they procured withdust shot, and skinned to the order of anAuckland dealer. <i>(Jan 23, 1896,Otago Witness,14</i>)

>  It had been thought that the stitchbird, which is a beautiful native of New Zealand, was almost extinct, specimens being found only on island sanctuaries, and the fact that a pair has been seen on the mainland is hailed with delight by bird lovers as an indication that the species is increasing. <i>(Oct 15, 1936,Evening Post,17</i>)

>  Thrity stitchbirds/hihi were successfully transferred to Karori Wildlife Sanctuary in Wellington from their home in the Hauraki Gulf in February. <i>(Jul 2005,Conservation Action,19</i>)

>  [Robinson] reported to Boscawen that he had seen none of the rare stitchbirds, but admitted that he had seen none of the rare stitchbirds, but admitted he would try to shoot some for "scientific purposes." <i>(Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/22</i>)

>  The song from such stunning native birds such as stitchbirds, saddlebacks, bellbirds, tui etc was like being in a great choral symphony. <i>(Jun 1999,North & South,24</i>)

>  Most New Zealanders are familiar with the tui and bellbird - our endearing nectar-sipping songsters. But few people will have seen the third member of the local branch of the honeyeater family: the hihi or stitchbird. <i>(Sep 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 53/88</i>)

>  There is an undeniable thrill as one does homage in this [sc. Little Barrier Island], the last stronghold in the whole world of the stitch-bird. <i>(Apr 27, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,38</i>)

## stock camp
 
 <i>n.</i>



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a place where farm stock congregate [often on a sunny face, under a tree or around a gateway.]

>  On the motion of the chairman, seconded by Cr Tawse, it was decided that a reply be sent to the chief surveyor re the Tokomaru Road, that the road runs in a valley, and the bulk of stock camp therein, and destroy the work done by the Council. <i>(Aug 6, 1888,Wanganui Herald,2</i>)

>  <b>LEVY</b> One direct outcome, however, of this increased carrying capacity was to overcrowd the stock camps on the knolls and ridges and to submit the former danthonia-dominant turf to such intensity of wear by treading, scratching, and rubbing, together with rank fertilising of the camps by dung and urine, ... <i>Ibid.</i> 255 ... there will be a considerable expansion in the size and area of stock camps. <i>(1951,Grasslands of NZ,31,1970 ed.</i>)

>  Wright Stephenson and Co., Ltd., report having sold, on account of Messrs Ross and Glendinning, of Dunedin, their well-known "Swamp" property, situated in Ida Valley, containing 1,672 acres freehold, of which nearly the whole is first class land, there being just sufficient lighter terrace land to provide dry stock camps, and shelter from southerly weather. <i>(Oct 16, 1907,Tuapeka Times,3</i>)

>  The chairman of the Waitaki County Council requested that the portion of section 2 of block III, Oamaru district, agreed to be disposed of by auction be reserved for sale as a stock camp. <i>(Apr 2, 1896,Otago Witness,24</i>)

>  Variegated thistle established on a stock camp site under a tree. <i>(Aug 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,141</i>)

>  <b>LEVY</b> The more stock we can carry, the broader and more numerous will these terraces become, and there will be a considerable expansion in the size and area of stock camps. <i>(1970,Grasslands of NZ,254</i>)

>  <b>LEVY</b> Bare-ground camps may be the inevitable outcome of a high carrying capacity.. <i>(1970,Grasslands of NZ,300</i>)

>  <b>MAF</b> As with tree height, basal areas vary with the topography and farm management throughout Otago; the nutrient rich 'stock camp' areas associated with ridge tops being particularly high. <i>(1989,BLANK ENTRY,44</i>) [NOTES: Economic Evaluation of Agroforestry in Otago 44]

>  <b>WHITE ET AL</b> Stock camps are areas where grazing animals tend to congregate. Significant quantities of nutrients are transferred from adjacent pasture to stock camp areas. <i>(1999,NZ Pasture and Crop Science,71</i>)

## stock farming

## stock unit
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  A few more years of graft and, by March 1994, they could afford 184ha of Manawatu hill country, running 1800 stock units. <i>(Mar 22, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20</i>)

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a measure of land's carrying-capacity [ the annual feed requirements of an animal, e.g. 1 ewe = 1.0 SU, 1 Jersey cow = 6.0 SU. One stock unit requires approx 520 kg of good quality pasture dry matter per year.]

>  Eighty years ago New Zealand was without grazing animals or herbage, but to-day its stock unit was 71 as compared with 100 of the Mother Country. <i>(Apr 20, 1928,Evening Post,8</i>)

>  <b>MAF</b> Stock unit .. also referred to as ewe equivalent. It is the feed requirement used as the basis of comparison for different classes and species of stock. It expresses the annual feed requirements equivalent to one 55 kg ewe rearing a single lamb. <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,7</i>)

>  Stock units are based on the conversion ratios first recommended by Professor Coop from Linclon College in 1965. These ratios are ewes per head 1.0, hoggest [sic] 0.6, others per head 0.8, cows per head 6.0.. <i>(Aug 1984,NZ Journal of Agriculture,28</i>)

>  Steers are equivalent to about six stock units ... <i>(Sep 1986,NZ Journal of Agriculture,8</i>)

>  <b>GORDON</b> One young couple is running over 20,000 stock units in a low labour system that was established by a lot of hard work ... <i>(1987,People, Places & Paddocks,46</i>)

>  The property has been well managed by the current owners for several generations ans carries approx 7000 SU.. Assessed at 3800 SU wintered being 80% sheep and 20% cattle. <i>(Nov 10, 2001,Hawke's Bay Today,22</i>)

>  They run 8000 SU of sheep, beef and deer with the majority, 6000 SU, in sheep. [sU] <i>(2002,Wool Grower,Spring 25</i>)

>  Buy from the lowest-priced furniture store in Wellington ... <i>(Dec 31, 1945,Evening Post,1</i>)

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [stock sales] an animal in an unfinished condition, to fatten or to breed with.

 <i>n.</i>

## store pen
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a sale pen of livestock that require fattening or finishing.

## store sheep farmer
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a hill country farmer who runs sheep to sell to finishing farmers and for wool.

>  <b>REED</b> The store sheep farmer produces wool and some store lambs, and sells his older ewes to the fat lamb farmer. <i>(1961,Pastoral Farming in New Zealand,14</i>)



## store sheep run
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a property that is basically a grazing and breeding pastoral property, where stock are sold for finishing.

>  <b>GASCOIGNE</b> Between the shearing shed practice of the store sheep run and the fat lamb farm there should be a fundamental difference so far as the owner or manager is concerned. <i>(1965,From the Top of a Hill,165</i>)



## store stock
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [sp. use] lambs, sheep and cattle that have the potential to be fattened or finished.

>  The property is run in conjunction with a 3500 acre breeding unit at Rangiwahia and serves as the finishing unit for the store stock produced on the Rangiwahia farm. <i>(Aug 4, 2001,Dominion,33</i>)

The bulk of the store stock movement out of the province is to the southern regions of Wanganui, Rangitikei, Manawatu, and Hawke's Bay. <i>(Nov 7, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,13</i>)

## store-roll
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a style or method of rolling a wool-fleece, where the fleece is folded from both sides and rolled from both ends.

>  <b>BOWEN</b> With the store-roll the bulk of the wool showing is back wool, which is not a fair example of the average fleece. <i>(1955,Wool Away!,94</i>)

## storm petrel
 
 <i>n.</i> (aka Jesus Christ bird, skipjack, dancing dolly, (all from its apparent ability to `walk' on water), =takahikaremoana ) a very small black seabird with a white rump, which follows ships and whose appearance was thought to announce a coming storm. [also storm bird]

>  When seeing you two months ago, I promised to send you a couple of storm petrel's eggs. <i>(Oct 18, 1905,Otago Witness,67</i>)

>  Birds that, like the albatross and storm petrel, live far out to sea except at nesting time, cannot obtain fresh water. <i>(May 28, 1921,Ashburton Guardian,4</i>)

>  Came a storm petrel flying past; / Perched upon the bending mast. <i>(Oct 31, 1888,Tuapeka Times,6</i>)

>  <b>WILLIAMS</b> <i>Reoreo, ... Garrodia nereis, storm-petrel</i>. [so 1957/336 ...grey-backed storm petrel] <i>(1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,391</i>)

>  <b>HARPER & KINSKY</b> If.. the albatrosses.. and the storm petrels.. are separated from the other Procellariiformes, a large and varied assemblage of birds still remains: to many people these are the 'true' petrels. <i>(1978,Southern Albatrosses & Petrels,41</i>)

>  WHICH BIRD CAN LIVE THE LONGEST TIME WITHOUT WATER? - - The petrels, especially the Fulmar petrel, which rarely strays from the Arctic Ocean, and the storm petrel, which is met with in all parts of the world except very high nothern [sic] or southern latitudes. <i>(Jan 5, 1893,Otago Witness,44</i>)

>  <b>SALE</b> ... [The storm petrel] has many other names - skipjack, Dancing Dolly, frigate petrel - from the Pakeha; and takahikaremoana from the Maori. <i>(1982,Four Seasons,38</i>)



## stoush
 
 <i>n.</i> [brawling; includes military and sports references as well as general interpersonal brawling, some fig.]

>  When Ormrod took his idea to Sid Holland, the Prime Minister was fresh from his stoush over the waterfront lockout and wasn't much interested in dealing with an enthusiast who had been secretary of the local wharfies' band for 20 years. <i>(Mar 9, 2000,Evening Post,7</i>)

>  Unquestionably the constable was wrong in dealing out stoush; a private citizen would have been wrong in so doing, but to err is human. <i>(Oct 20, 1923,NZ Truth,6</i>)

>  Who gave H Mc stoush? <i>(Mar 3, 1900,Observer (Auckland),21</i>)

>  The popular impression of successive council-chamber stoushes is, in fact, erroneous. <i>(Dec 1996,North & South,97</i>)

>  Some people get gung-ho at the sight of soldiers and guns, at the thought of a stoush somewhere safely far away. <i>(Sep 26, 1999,Sunday Star Times,D2</i>)

>  Through the veiled comments of bureaucrats, one detects that an almost stoush is going on behind the scenes over Kimberley. <i>(Oct 9, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29</i>)

>  But, then, the referee was not backed up by an Association and a Union. .. He heard any amount of "blanky" (in which his name was freely interspersed), and saw much "stouch." Did he order the offenders off? Not he. Knew better, had a family to keep. <i>(Jun 22, 1901,New Zealand Free Lance,20</i>)

>  The proceedings in the House.. are what members politely call "stoush." <i>(Aug 9, 1913,NZ Observer,3</i>)

>  Stoush? My oath! <i>(Sep 13, 1913,NZ Observer,16</i>)

>  Everyone knew the worst stoush in history was looming [sc. in 1939] but no-one was game to throw the first punch. <i>(Jul 6, 1992,Evening Post,6</i>)

>  Leo, together with ex-wife Sandra Lee.. fought the loop road stoush for years, but never once met the opposition. <i>(May 12, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),34</i>)

>  What's wrong? A stoush? Who's in it? <i>(May 1, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,85</i>)

>  Hdg] Wharfies v Seagulls : Scene setfor big stoush on the Aucklandwaterfront. <i>(Mar 24, 1995,Independent (Auckland),6</i>)

>  We met opponents' boastsWith boots and stoush. <i>(Aug 8, 1919,Hawke's Bay Herald,7</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to fight, bash [stoush n. also stouch (1891 cit.) Also passive: to be fought, bashed.] (See [stoush n](../S#stoush-n))

>  And if any people want to try an' stoush your Royal pa, / We'll come an' 'elp 'im scrap 'em, every time! <i>(Jul 17, 1901,West Coast Times,4</i>)

>  He began badly and got stoushed the whole way, eventually finishing well back. <i>(Aug 13, 1910,NZ Truth,2</i>)



 
 <i>adj.</i>

## straggle
 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [stragglers and wild sheep] to wander without direction.

>  <b>GUTHRIE-SMITH</b> In one way or another hundreds of sheep thus straggled from the run. <i>(1921,Tutira,140</i>)

>  <b>WESTMACOTT</b> The sheep straggled up the valley and we followed ... <i>(1977,After-Breakfast Cigar, The,115</i>)

>  <b>OGONOWSKA-COATES</b> .. sheep sometimes went wild, wandering the back country and straggling up the river flats. <i>(1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,11</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a small group of sheep evading muster.

>  These musterers who climbed several hundred metres around dawn to drive straggles of sheep down to the valley floor might work their way in time to be head musterer, foreman or manager, amd ultimately perhaps attain their own lease. <i>(Aug 2002,Forest & Bird,27</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) to find straggler sheep [and often to blade-shear bellies and under-necks so that they can walk out in a muster.]

>  <b>MOWAT</b> McWhirter and self straggled the Trig. <i>(Dec 28, 1916,Alexander Mowat Diaries</i>)

>  <b>STRONACH</b> So after three days of mustering about the paddocks, with a dagging thrown in, we were glad to get away up Yoe Creek again to straggle the ewe country. To straggle a block of country means of course to muster in the stragglers. <i>(1953,Musterer on Molesworth,31</i>)

>  <b>WESTMACOTT</b> In bush country they have to straggle the new burns after a first muster. <i>(1977,After-Breakfast Cigar, The,145</i>)

>  <b>PETER</b> We straggle a block and trace the roughies as they usually have a double fleece. i.e. we muster for the stragglers and blade-shear bellies and under neck so they can walk out. <i>(2000,Peter Glossary</i>)

>  <b>DOMINY</b> Now on occasion, when spotting or straggling, some run-holders save time by using a helicopter to drop them in the back country. <i>(2001,Calling the Station Home,169</i>)



## straggle hunting
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) searching for straggler sheep

>  <b>NEWTON</b> His partner is a well-known flying man and is one of the originators of the practice of straggle hunting by air. <i>(1952,High Country Journey,13</i>)



## straggle muster
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a secondary muster to collect stock missed in initial muster.

>  The local knowledge of each committee is and has been invaluable, particularly in ensuring proper mustering ands where necessary, subsequent 'straggle musters' before shearing and dipping operations. <i>(Feb 1966,NZ Journal of Agriculture,25</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to have a second muster to gather stragglers that have missed a first or main muster.

>  <b>STRONACH</b> For the rest of us, fifteen long days, if the weather kept fine, and then fifteen more days to straggle muster the same block. <i>(1953,Musterer on Molesworth,25</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> .. we finished up by straggle mustering the whole of the summer country again. <i>(1964,Straggle Muster,107</i>)

>  <b>MACGREGOR</b> On one occasion we were out straggle mustering for sheep missed in the main muster. <i>(1980,Dog's Life, A,12</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> There was a good gang up the Ant.. at which the gang could camp during the fortnight the sheep were held there, and from which they could straggle-muster the rest of the country. <i>(1966,Boss's Story, The,38</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to clear the bar at closing time.

>  Straggle muster - gathering sheep missed during the main muster. Also pertains to the [Dog Trial] Club Secretary on his third attempt at clearing the bar! [straggle] <i>(Dec 15, 1983,NZ Journal of Agriculture,46</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) sheep that have missed an initial muster, and are gathered in the straggle muster.

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> Before leaving Otupae, Roger Pearce and I had been asked if we would return in three weeks to shear the 'straggle muster.' <i>(1989,Pioneer's Life, A,47</i>)



## straggle tally
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a total number of sheep missed in an initial muster, but mustered in later.

>  <b>NEWTON</b> .. the Lake Coleridge station itself at that time shore 22,000 sheep and that season the straggle tally (sheep missed) was under 400. <i>(1947,Wayleggo,37</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> The other day the talk got round to 'straggle' tallies ( sheep missed in a muster.) I reckon that place must hold a world record for a straggle tally. <i>(1964,Straggle Muster,106</i>)



## straggle-mustering
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a second gathering to collect stock missed in an initial muster.

>  Straggle mustering. <i>(Feb 11, 1868,Castle Station Diary,260</i>) [NOTES: in Vance (1965) High Endeavour]

>  <b>NEWTON</b> This straggle-mustering after the autumn muster had never been practised at Mount White. <i>(1966,Boss's Story, The,38</i>)



## straggler
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) 1.a sheep or cattle beast missed by a mustering team or a sheep or cattle beast that has strayed on to a neighbouring property, more common when natural boundaries preceded fences. 2. a ewe that is late to lamb; a late-lamber. 3. a slow-moving sheep at the back of a mob. (See [hermit; double-decker; double-fleecer; stray](../H#hermit;-double-decker;-double-fleecer;-stray))

>  The bulk of the wools offered was made up largely of stragglers and other late shorn sheep, and its character therefore was not up to the usual average, and it could not therefore be expected to establish a high range of values ... <i>(Apr 5, 1894,Otago Witness,13</i>)

>  The lamb was found by defendant in a paddock adjoining one of his camping paddocks, and taking it to be a straggler he had it killed under a custom which he said was long prevailed of accommodation paddock owners killing stragglers and accounting for them if called upon to do so. <i>(Jun 3, 1904,Wanganui Herald,6</i>)

>  <b>ORMOND</b> A good shearing day - got through 1431 sheep - all greasy ewes with exception of stragglers from the wether block. Jan 19. David out all day clearing off stragglers. <i>(Jan 18, 1865,JD Ormond Stockbook 1864-1866</i>)

>  <b>MURISON</b> Sent Wilkinson to Drysdales to head weaners whilst Read searches for stragglers. <i>(Sep 13, 1865,Puketoi Station Diary</i>)

>  <b>MURISON</b> Shearing stragglers. <i>(Mar 29, 1867,Puketoi Station Diary</i>)

>  CHS, TS, Kite and Jim went mustering the reserve for stragglers. <i>(Mar 1, 1879,Tutira Station Diary</i>)

>  <b>BRABAZON</b> Went around big section. Saw no stragglers. <i>(Nov 24, 1892,Brabazon Diaries</i>)

## stripping
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  To prevent contamination of the milk after it has been drawn, some precautions unusual in New Zealand are taken. The main one is the use of a covered stripping-bucket. <i>(Oct 1938,NZ Journal of Agriculture,348</i>)

>  He put the stripping weight on, took the cups off the next cow, swung the gate open with one hand and flipped the back rope on the hook with the other. <i>(Mar 10, 1960,NZ Dairy Exporter,96</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) the removing of the first and last milk from a cow's udder.

>  By double stripping you make sure that all the cows are thoroughly milked. <i>(Aug 1, 1919,NZ Farmer,1064</i>)

>  There has been no stripping for four years. <i>(May 1, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,14</i>)

>  No stripping has been done at milkings for the last 15 years. <i>(1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,123</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) the continuous cultivating and cropping of land in the same ground, usually with the same crop.

>  <b>CRAWFORD</b> To counteract the effect of 'stripping' or continuous cropping, he advocated better cultivation, rotation of crops, mixed farming and manuring. <i>(1949,Sheep and Sheepmen of Canterbury,107</i>)



## strippings
 
 <i>n.</i> (See [stripping](../S#stripping))

>  Wherever [the milking machines] were used the cows soon went dry, owing to the machines not having attained the knack of drawing the "strippings" of the last of the milk. When cows are not "stripped" properly. as every dairyman knows, they soon go dry. <i>(Jun 19, 1890,Otago Witness,7</i>)

>  Silently and swiftly there steals up "She who drinks skim milk or steals the strippings," and into that bucket goes her nose. <i>(Dec 18, 1926,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,36</i>)



## strong-combing
 
<b>1</b> <i>adj.</i> (Rural) [of wool] strong and dense.

## strong-eye/strong-eyed
 
<b>1</b> <i>adj.</i> (Rural) [of heading dogs] that control sheep with a hypnotic stare.

>  A good many strong-eyed dogs are spoiled in their "come on" by undue haste on the trainer's part to teach them to "pull" or bring back sheep. <i>(Oct 31, 1906,Otago Witness,31</i>)

>  The naturally careless or, to use the shepherd's term, "slack" dog can never be taught to perform like this, though he may up to a certain stage be infinitely less trouble than the strong-eyed, keen one, but, then, no matter what amount of trouble is taken with him, he always requires to be kept at high pressure in training to keep him up to the mark, whereas with the other, once perfect always so. <i>(Nov 9, 1899,Otago Witness,39</i>)

>  <b>LILICO</b> ... how to prevent the several faults that the strong-eyed young dog will assuredly acquire if not taken in time. <i>(1934,Sheep Dog Memoirs,4</i>)

>  <b>HARTLEY</b> If the pup is from a 'strong-eye' strain he will begin to stalk the rubber and the trainer can begin to employ the whistle of command intended to bring him on to sheep. <i>(1949,Shepherd's Dogs, The,5</i>)

>  <b>DU FAUR</b> .. the sue of 'all-rounders' or huntaways instead of quiet strong-eyed dogs, are also contributing factors to this unsettledness. <i>(1966,Sheep Farming for Profit,87</i>)

>  <b>MCGREGOR</b> Today few farmers are without a strong-eyed dog. <i>(1980,Dog's Life, A,5</i>)

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> strong-eye: intensive and powerful use of eye by a dog. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,81</i>)

## stubbies
 
 <i>n.</i> skimpy men's shorts [usually in pluraL]

>  Knox, nearing 50, still takes to the road several timnes a year and performs - the man in jandals and stubbies - mixing songs with drinks, making us mad, or making us laugh... <i>(Aug 20, 2002,Dominion Post,B9</i>)

>  [Advt] Sporty stubbies. Available now in sizes 78cm - 104 cm. Cool, comfortable polyester cotton mix makes these great wearing... Basic stubbies. These are also available in the colours as the sporty stubbies... Sizes are 78 cm - 104 cm and feature front and hip pocket. <i>(Oct 22, 1980,Evening Post,20</i>)

>  Almost 30 years ago Aussie businessman Philip Levy saw a gap in the market for an inexpensive, all-purpose men's short. What else could you get for less than $2 other than a handkerchief or a crass tie in a bargain bin? They were launched in July 1972 and within two days inhabitants of Brisbane, always a place of limited cullture and unlimited heat, had snapped up 50,000 pairs.... The pollution of New Zealand male wardrobes with stubbies began with the first exports in 1977... "The stubby was a cheap short, revolting. They reminded me of rugby shorts only ruigby shorts were more comfortable. They're still out there in country towns... They were revolting, everything exposed. You couldn't afford to sit down in them." <i>(Jan 9, 2002,Evening Post,10</i>)

>  [Hdg] And they call it Stubbie love... Writer Dianna Dekker called them zipless. Wrong. The sporty Stubbies in your picture had a zip. A very fine zip... What Stubbies did have was class, plenty of ass and a little pocket perfect for keeping change and stones without disturbing your stride - walk, skip or run. <i>(Jan 16, 2002,Evening Post,6</i>)

>  I refuse to wear jandals anywhere, and will not entertain picnic pals who wear stubbies, but an esky is the only way to go for picnic packaging. <i>(Feb 2, 2002,Dominion Weekend Magazine,4</i>)

>  The tennis gear is a tribute to those 1970 icons of mate attire, stubbies. "Pixie and I had both been to different op shops and without knowing it had bought the same stubbies. To do something with them, we went for a run - just a fitness run - both wearing our stubbies. People were laughing so much we thought we would do it again... Because our stubbies were awfully short we'd stop at intersections and do lunges and stuff. <i>(Nov 3, 2004,Capital Times,5</i>)

## stud book
 
 <i>n.</i> (figurative) a PSA book detailing employees' work history/status

>  <b>SMITH</b> In order to prove beyond all doubt where you fitted in, a book was produced each year, called the stud book. Now at one point there were 42,000 people in the Post Office, every person was in there in seniority order, with your name, your grading, your rank, your salary. When you applied for a job, 30 others might apply for it with similar status, so the Promotion Board would refer back to the stud book - which everyone had access to - and it would show you that 'he gets that because he's the most senior person, not the most suitable, the most senior person. <i>(1997,Reining in the Dinosaur,17</i>)

## stuff
 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) [dummying] to apply for a land ballot for a family member.

>  Under the heading of 'Stuffing the Ballot' the Canterbury Times shows how the above can be done. The Canterbury Commissioner furnishes even more striking illustrations of the method in which the ballot is 'stuffed' by eager applicants. 'Out of three hundred and three applicants at our last ballot,' Mr Humphries says, 'there were no fewer than forty-two single women, besides a great number of married women, and there was not one of either condition that did not bear the same name as some one of the male applicants.' Mr John Hay, the Southland Commissioner says that he can see no way by which the system provided by the Act of 1892 could be improved upon, but he strongly urges that only one mode of ballot for all tenures and all classes of land should be adopted, and that this should prevent more than one member of a family applying for the same section. <i>(Nov 5, 1903,Hawera Star,2</i>)

## summer sickness
 
 <i>n.</i> a form of food poisoning, a usually brief but prostrating illness characterised by vomiting and diarrhoea and associated with hot weather. [Jim writes : Not in DNZE or overseas dictionaries available to me. the British equivalent may be <i>summer flu</i>, a term I have seen in English fiction but itself not in dictionaries. <i>Summer sickness</i> has perhaps become less common with the ubiquity of refrigeration.I recall press references to it in the 50s and 60s. It is also more medically diagnosed these days - e.g. it is attributed to salmonella or campylobacter or even giardia. It has been associated with the collection of rainwater from house roofs - that can be contaminated by bird droppings.]

On enquiring why, my New Zealand friend said in a hushed, embarrassed voice that it was "summer sickness". adding that the citizens of Auckland were laid low every year with this. ## sundowner
 
 <i>n.</i> formerly, a swagger who arrived at a place at sunset so that he could claim traditional food and shelter without the need to work for it.



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a dog reluctant to work in hot sunny conditions [ preferring to lie in the shade or in a water-trough. ] (See [sooner](../S#sooner))

>  <b>STRONACH</b> My dogs I tied to the iron fence outside the hotel. They were...; Maud, a bob-tailed bitch, one of the borrowed ones and already under suspicion as a 'sundowner.' <i>(1953,Musterer on Molesworth,2</i>)

>  <b>MACNICOL</b> The playful pup grew to a large .. dog. He proved too easy-going and too much of a 'sundowner' for hill work. <i>(1967,Skippers' Canyon,129</i>)

>  <b>SINCLAIR</b> He looked a true sundowner, and this job he was, but get him on lambs breaking at a gate at shearing time and he'd toil until his feet were raw. <i>(1973,Boot in the Stirrup,95</i>)

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> sundowner: (i) a lazy dog. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,81</i>)

>  <b>MAF</b> Sundowner: Dog that leaves its work, especially when hot and noisy. A lazy dog. <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,25</i>)

>  <b>SCURR</b> Sundowner:- A dog that won't work in the sun. [sun-downer] <i>(2000,Rabbiters' Glossary,2</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a swagger or itinerant who arrives at a property in the evening when work is finished, hoping for a bed.

>  They are delighted to see the "sundowner" again; to see the "swagger" on the roads. <i>(1909,NZ Parliamentary Debates,146/102</i>)

>  Only let him occupy one of the many roadside farms to which he alludes for a few months, and be subjected to the daily and hourly pesterings to which we are subjected by hundreds of swagmen, sundowners, and other loafers - the majority of whom cannot do a day's work when they get the chance - and it strikes me very forcibly that his goodly Samaritan learnings [sic] would receive such a shock that he would experience no difficulty in understanding the reception he met with. <i>(Feb 22, 1871,Bruce Herald,6</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> .. they were odd members of the idle class known as the swaggers and sundowners. <i>(1894,In the Land of the Tui,248</i>)

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> sundowner: (ii): a swagger who times his arrival just at the right time for the evening meal. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,81</i>)

>  The moon was shining brightly as the three "sundowners" approached. <i>(Feb 12, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8</i>)

>  <b>BRADSHAW</b> The [peripatetic labourers] in the colony are known by the name of `Swaggers' or `Sundowners' Swaggers, because they carry a swag or bundle on their backs ... Sundowners, because they never approach a habitable place before sundown lest they should be requested to take a further stroll. <i>(1883,New Zealand As It Is,26</i>)

>  Old sun-downers told ... yarns of ferocious mastiffs ... It was quite certain that the most persistent swagger had never obtained the inevitable feed and shake down there. <i>(1889,Zealandia,1/31</i>)

>  <b>DAVIDSON</b> Kelly [a detective] had on more than one ocasion swagged it for weary miles after his prey as an orthodox sundowner, or in taking his turn in the harvest field, or at a threshing mill. <i>(1889,Stories of NZ Life,2</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> About these wayfarers Mr. Cameron had something to tell me, for they were odd members of the idle class known as swaggers and sundowners ... [249] So far as I could discriminate, swaggers (those who, snail-like, carry their worldly possessions on their backs) are men occasionally willing to do a day's work for a night's lodging and a couple of meals. Sundowners (those who have no possessions to carry) walk from station to station during the day, and, sleeping under a haystack until sunset, make their appearance at that hour before the `whares' or huts provided for them, and demand from the owners supper and shelter, which are generally granted. <i>(1894,In the Land of the Tui,248, 249</i>) [NOTES: 1891 Dec 21 in 1894 Land of the Tui]

>  <b>MORRIS</b> a tramp who takes care to arrive at a station at sundown, so that he shall be provided with <i>tucker',/I>(q.v.) at the squatter's cost: one of those who go about the country seeking work and devoutly hoping they may not find it. <i>(1898,Austral English,444</i>)

>  Possibly before next harvest we shall hear a cry raised by the squatter.. that those who are about do not want work; that they are sundowners. <i>(Mar 20, 1890,Otago Witness,15</i>)

>  <b>BRADSHAW</b> fn The term `swagger' is applied to a man who tramps from place to place in quest of work, carrying all his worldly goods in a swag, or bundle, thrown across his back. The `sun-downer' is one who tramps from place to place pretending to seek employment, but, as a matter of fact living upon the supper and breakfast with which he is supplied at most up-country stations. He fears to arrive too early in the day, lest he should be requested to seek a bed elsewhere, and hence the name with which he has been endowed. <i>(1888,New Zealand Of Today,181</i>)

>  <b>PYKE</b> Now, a `sundowner' or `tussocker' for the terms are synonymous - is a pastoral loafer; one who loiters about till dusk, and then makes for the nearest station or hut, to beg for shelter and food. <i>(1873,Wild Will Enderby,Bk III ch x 105</i>) [NOTES: (1889)]

>  <b>D'AVIGDOR</b> Those who join it [the professional unemployed] are distinguished from `sundowners' ... by working chiefly in towns instead of in the open country, and in swarms instead of alone. It has, therefore, several advantages over `sundowning'. The professional unemployed need not tramp ten, twelve, or twenty miles a day, and he always has congenial company. <i>(1888,Antipodean Notes,154</i>)

>  <b>D'AVIGDOR</b> The language of the Australian Colonies is not in the least like the last mentioned [`Daily telagraphese']. <i>(1888,Antipodean Notes,165</i>) [NOTES: [check spg???]]

## supervision

[Jim Cameron writes : It subjects the offender to the oversight and control of a probation officer. <i>Supervision</i> in England is primarily a welfare order placing a child under local authority or probation officer supervision, although it may also be an adjunct to a suspended sentence. >  By far too little attention is paid to surface-sowing of grass seed by those who have stretches of land in the native state. <i>(Mar 5, 1896,Otago Witness,5</i>)

>  His main improvement has been cutting down tea-tree on the better land, burning off, and surface-sowing: and he now has 120 acres down in turnips. <i>(Jan 30, 1913,Evening Post,11</i>)

>  <b>JOHNSTON</b> Rode out to run and looked at surface sowing. <i>(Apr 1, 1874,Johnston Diary</i>)

>  Its [cocksfoot's] chief value lies in it being a strong, hardy grower, and specially adapted for surface sowing upon bushland, hillsides and other places ... <i>(May 1909,NZ Farmer,338</i>)

>  A little surface sowing with European grasses sometimes takes place after the spring burn. <i>(Jun 15, 1910,NZ Journal of Agriculture,8</i>)

>  .. districts which were either firstly infested with blackberry or Californian thistle; or secondly, bush-districts where the surface-sowing of grass-seed was the customary method of laying down grass. <i>(May 22, 1914,Hawke's Bay Herald,3</i>)

>  What grasses are best adapted for surface-sowing on this class of country, bearing in mind the dryness of the summer months? <i>(May 20, 1921,NZ Journal of Agriculture,313</i>)

>  Pastures were slowly established by felling the bush in winter and spring, burning the fallen timber and underscrub in the summer, and surface sowing English grasses and clovers on the ash of the burns. <i>(Apr 16, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,346</i>)

>  <b>TAIT</b> By underscrubbing, burning off and surface sowing of seed, a beginning was made in the grim struggle of developing the land into a farm. <i>(1958,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol III,123</i>)

>  On the other side similar country is being developed by surface sowing, fertiliser and stocking. [surface sowing] <i>(Aug 13, 1970,NZ Farmer,51</i>)



## surface-sown
 
<b>1</b> <i>adj.</i> (Rural) [of land] sown in seed without tillage.

>  This finely undulating ground is exhausted by hundreds of years growth of fern and ti-tree, which returns nothing to the soil, so that surface-sown grass is found to be a failure. <i>(Mar 25, 1876,Daily Southern Cross,1</i>)

>  There were 137 acres under crop and 150 acres of rough feed surface-sown. <i>(Oct 13, 1866,Weekly News,5</i>)

>  The uncultivated land was surface sown, and the grass has grown for over twenty years .. high fern, flax and tutu covered the ground. <i>(May 12, 1888,Egmont Star,6</i>)

>  I have seen turnips surface sown in a bush clearing the first opportunity after burning off the felled bush, and the yield has been exceptionally good. <i>(Sep 1888,Egmont Star,22</i>)

>  450 acres burnt fern (surface-sown.) <i>(Jun 3, 1909,Weekly News,4</i>)

>  This is usually surface-sown country, and may be limestone hills in cocksfoot and ratstail, or sandstone hills in danthonia and browntop. <i>(Jan 15, 1945,Journal of the Polynesian Society,13</i>)

>  The improvement of the surface-sown hill-country grazing land will be very important in the post-war economy of the Dominion. <i>(Jul 16, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,13</i>)

>  The more fertile surface-sown hill country of the North Island. [surface sown] <i>(Feb 20, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,121</i>)



## surface-sown country
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) land upon which seed has been sown without tillage [usually hill country or land difficult to plough.]

## surfaceman
 
 <i>n.</i> a workman who keeps road surfaces in repair, and verges and gutters clear.

>  Salaries .. Surface man [GBP]117 0 0. <i>(Dec 1, 1862,Otago Daily Times,6</i>)

>  The council decided to instruct surfacemen to clear the roadsides where there were long stretches of unoccupied land. <i>(Jan 27, 1939,Evening Post,8</i>)

>  We understand surface men will be employed on the Great South Road during the winter. <i>(May 30, 1863,Daily Southern Cross,10</i>)

>  I want to know how it is that one surfaceman can monopolise work by employing his sons, whilst other surfacemen get orders to dismiss their relations at once? <i>(Aug 30, 1882,Tuapeka Times,6</i>)

>  Attention was drawn, amongst other matters, to the near termination of the engagements of surfacemen, nightman, and lamplighter. <i>(Jun 9, 1899,Timaru Herald,3</i>)

>  After hearing Mr Ross, the Board decided to instruct one of the surfacemen to attend to the necessary repairs. <i>(Feb 13, 1905,Wanganui Herald,6</i>)

>  <b>GUTHRIE-SMITH</b> ... the only bipeds who upon their feet utilize the King's Highway are surfacemen and swaggers, ... the surfacemen preoccupied with the more material problems of metal and mud. <i>(1927,Bird Life on Island & Shore,/15</i>)

>  <b>Studholme</b> ... as we were putting 120 head [of cattle] across the Waitaki Bridge, something frightened them, they set off at top speed, ... nearly killing two surfacemen, who had foolishly come on to the bridge at the far end. <i>(1940,Te Waimate,141,1954 ed.</i>) [NOTES: -]

>  Within a few miles of Lawrence, I noticed two surfacemen just emerging from their homes - about half-past nine - apparently traversing the locality in search of something to do, while the condition of the roads was such that they need not have gone ten yards without finding an abundance of scope for their energies. A lttle further on two other surfacers were at work, with overcoats comfortably buttoned up to the chin, pretending to rake gravel into the wheel-ruts on a new-made piece of road. <i>(Jun 6, 1877,Tapanui Courier</i>) [NOTES: Tapanui Courier in 1977 Marks Hammer and Tap 371]



## surfacer
 
 <i>n.</i> OED 2. one who mines near the surface

## surfer
 
 <i>n.</i> a surfacer q.v.

>  <b>VON HAAST</b> Generally the greater portion of the sand is removed, but in favourable spots, sheltered either by a slight indentation in the coast-line, or by some large pieces of drifted timber, its heavier particles remain; these consist [529] of black iron-sand (both magnetic and titaniferous oxide of iron) associated with small garnets and with gold. These black layers are often one or two inches thick, and repose upon coarse quartzose sands. As soon as a storm has subsided, the `beachers' or `surfers' as they are called, examine the coastline near their houses. When they come upon one of the rich spots, the fine particles of gold being often visible to the naked eye, they at once remove the black layer of sand out of the reach of the tide, and wash it when convenient. <i>(1948,Life & Times of Sir Julius von Haast,528-529</i>) [NOTES: 1868 Von Haast in 1948 Von Haast Julius Von Haast]

## swag
 
 <i>n.</i> a load, often as a bundle

>  He did not see a swag open in the loft of the stables on the morning of the 29th, nor did he hear the police had removed one from the loft. <i>(Jul 1, 1899,Marlborough Express,4</i>)

>  I here experienced the utility of tying my baggage to the side of the canoe, had I not adopted this method, I should possibly have lost the whole of my <i> swag </i>. <i>(Sep 9, 1842,NZ Colonist,4</i>)

 <i>v.</i> to carry as or in a swag

>  A few of the Waikato diggers have left for the Anatoki, owing to the difficulties they had to encounter in "swagging" their provisions over "Kill Devil Hill." <i>(Feb 15, 1860,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,2</i>)

<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) to travel on foot, carrying a swag. (See [also swag it](../A#also-swag-it))

>  <b>CHINN</b> After a while two of my working companions suggested that we "swag" our way through the country. <i>(1963,Packtrack to Highway,43</i>)

LOOK (OUT) FOR ONE'S SWAG STRAPS -->1937 Partridge Dictionary Slang 1190 Swag-straps, look for one's. `To consider leaving one's job in search of another', B., 1941: New Zealand (mostly rural): late C. 19-20.
